5.405. Prohibited Conduct
5.406. Sales On Credit Forbidden
5.407. Persons Under Age
5.408. Contributions To Elected Officials Or Local Liquor Control Commission
Members
Sec. 5.401. Consumption On Premises.
   A.   No liquor shall be sold, offered for sale, kept for sale, displayed or
advertised for sale at retail or delivered to any person purchasing same at
retail except at a location, place or premises described in a retail license.
      1.   It shall be unlawful to peddle alcoholic liquor in the City.
      2.   A license shall permit the sale of alcoholic liquor only in or from
the premises described in the application and license and only in the manner
therein authorized and in compliance with the terms thereof.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for anyone not having a license providing for
consumption on the premises where sold, to offer for sale, sell or donate any
alcoholic beverage for consumption on any premises open to the general public
or to permit the same to be consumed where sold or donated.
      1.   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner, however, may grant a daily
permit 1  to any Class P licensee under this chapter, which permit may
authorize the donation of alcoholic beverages by such licensee for sampling
purposes only in conjunction with sales promotional efforts on the premises of
such licensee and authorized and sponsored by such licensee. No more than
twelve (12) such daily permits shall be issued to any one such licensee during
the period of one year.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to consume or permit the consumption of
alcoholic beverages in public restaurants and/or catering establishments not
having a license for the sale thereof.
   C.   No person, except a manufacturer or distributor or importing
distributor, shall fill or refill, in whole or in part, any original package of
alcoholic liquor with the same or any other kind or quality of alcoholic
liquor, and it shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession for
sale at retail any bottles, casks or other containers containing alcoholic
liquor, except in original packages.
   D.   It shall be unlawful to sell or serve any alcoholic liquor unless the
manager or other employee of the license holder, having satisfactorily
completed a liquor seller and server education program, shall be present on the
licensed premises, any time liquor is being served or sold except where the
Liquor Commissioner, as provided for in subsection 5.302C3 of this chapter has
excused compliance with the liquor and server training requirement. (Ord. O-15-
028, 12-17-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 5.304 of this chapter.
Sec. 5.402. Hours Of Operation.
   A.   It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale any alcoholic liquor at
retail in the City or to permit any person to consume any alcoholic liquor in
or on any premises for which a license providing for consumption on the
premises has been issued pursuant to this chapter, except during the hours set
forth herein.
      1.   For Class A and A-R licenses:
         Monday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M. the
following day;
         Tuesday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Wednesday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Thursday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Friday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until two o'clock (2:00) A.M. the
following day;
         Saturday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until two o'clock (2:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Sunday: From eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day.
      2.   For Class GS, H, N, and T licenses:
         Monday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M. the
following day;
         Tuesday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Wednesday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Thursday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Friday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until two o'clock (2:00) A.M. the
following day;
         Saturday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until two o'clock (2:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Sunday: From twelve o'clock (12:00) noon until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day.
      3.   For Class E, P, and TG licenses:
         Monday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M. the
following day;
         Tuesday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Wednesday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Thursday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Friday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until two o'clock (2:00) A.M. the
following day;
         Saturday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until two o'clock (2:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Sunday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M. the
following day.
      4.   For Class O licenses:
         Monday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M. the
following day;
         Tuesday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Wednesday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Thursday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Friday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until two o'clock (2:00) A.M. the
following day;
         Saturday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until two o'clock (2:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Sunday: From ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day.
      5.   For Class B, CA, M, M-R, R, and RVG licenses:
         Monday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M. the
following day;
         Tuesday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Wednesday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Thursday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Friday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until two o'clock (2:00) A.M. the
following day;
         Saturday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until two o'clock (2:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Sunday: From twelve o'clock (12:00) noon until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day.
If the Liquor Commissioner has given the licensee permission, wine or alcoholic
beverages may be sold with meals commencing at ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. on
Sunday.
      6.   For Class G licenses:
         Monday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M. the
following day;
         Tuesday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Wednesday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Thursday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Friday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until two o'clock (2:00) A.M. the
following day;
         Saturday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until two o'clock (2:00) A.M.
the following day;
         Sunday: From six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until one o'clock (1:00) A.M. the
following day.
         On New Year's Eve Day of each year it shall be unlawful to sell or
offer for sale any alcoholic liquor at retail in the City or to permit any
person to consume any alcoholic liquor in or on any premises for which a
license providing for consumption on the premises has been issued pursuant to
this chapter, except between the hours of six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on New Year's
Eve Day and two o'clock (2:00) A.M. the following day.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any premises for which a retail liquor
dealer's license has been issued pursuant to this chapter to keep open for
business or to admit the public to any premises in or on which alcoholic liquor
is sold at retail except during the hours within which the sale of such liquor
is allowed; provided, that retail establishments, restaurants, clubs, and
premises for which a Class O license has been issued may be kept open during
hours when the sale of alcoholic liquor is not allowed, but no alcoholic liquor
may be sold or served to or consumed by the public during such hours. Nothing
contained in this section shall be deemed to authorize any such retail
establishment, restaurant, club or premises to keep open for business or to
admit the public to such premises at or during any hour when such premises are
required to be closed by virtue of the regulations or restrictions imposed by
any other provisions of this Code. (Ord. O-19-006, 4-4-2019)
Sec. 5.403. Conditions Of Licensed Premises.
   A.   All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor or for the
storage of such liquor for sale shall be sanitary and shall be kept in full
compliance with the ordinances regulating the condition of premises used for
the storage or sale of food for human consumption 1 . Additionally, if a Class
VG license has been issued for the premises under section
5.304 of this chapter, the premises or the video gaming terminal area shall at
all times be in compliance with subsection
5.313A6 of this chapter, and any violation thereof shall in addition constitute
a violation of this subsection.
   B.   Except in the case of hotels and clubs, no alcoholic liquor shall be
sold at retail upon any premises which has any access which leads from such
premises to any other portion of the same building or structure used for
dwelling or lodging purposes and which is permitted to be used or kept
accessible for any use of the public. This provision shall not prevent any
connection between such premises and such other portion of the building or
structure which is used only by the licensee, his family and personal guests.
   C.   Every licensee shall cause his license or licenses to be framed and
hung in plain view in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises. (Ord. O-15-
028, 12-17-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 4, article IV of this Code.
Sec. 5.404. Employees.
   A.   It shall be unlawful to employ in any premises used for the retail sale
of alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with or who is a carrier of any
contagious, infectious or venereal disease, and it shall be unlawful for any
person who is afflicted with or is a carrier of such disease to work in or
about any premises or to be engaged in any way in the handling, preparation or
distribution of such liquor.
   B.   No licensee licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall deny or
permit his agents and employees to deny any person the full and equal enjoyment
of the accommodations, advantages, facilities and privileges of any premises in
which alcoholic liquors are authorized to be sold subject only to the
conditions and limitations established by law and applicable alike to all
citizens. (Ord. O-15-028, 12-17-2015)
Sec. 5.405. Prohibited Conduct.
The following kinds of conduct on premises in the City licensed to sell
alcoholic liquor are prohibited:
   A.   The performance of acts, or simulated acts, of sexual intercourse,
masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual
acts which are prohibited by law.
   B.   The actual or simulated touching, caressing or fondling of the breasts,
buttocks, anus or genitals.
   C.   The actual or simulated displaying of the breasts, pubic hair, anus,
vulva or genitals.
   D.   The permitting by a licensee of any person to remain in or upon the
licensed premises who exposes to public view any portion of his or her genitals
or anus.
   E.   The displaying of films or pictures depicting acts, a live performance
of which is prohibited by this section.
   F.   There shall be no automatic amusement device located upon, maintained
in and/or conducted by licensees of premises for which a Class B license has
been issued.
   G.   There shall be no dancing without the premises having first secured a
special use permit from the City pursuant to the terms of the Unified
Development Ordinance 1  of the City.
   H.   There shall be no live music or other entertainment without the
premises having first secured a special use permit from the City pursuant to
the terms of the Unified Development Ordinance 2  of the City. (Ord. O-15-028,
12-17-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 17 of this Code.
2 1. See chapter 17 of this Code.
Sec. 5.406. Sales On Credit Forbidden.
Other than holders of Class H and Class N licenses with respect to members and
registered guests, no licensee shall sell or furnish alcoholic liquor at retail
to any person on credit or on a passbook, or order on a store, or in exchange
for any goods, wares or merchandise, or in payment for any services rendered,
and if any person shall extend credit for such purpose, the debt thereby
attempted to be created shall not be recoverable at law; provided, that nothing
herein shall be construed to prevent payment by credit card. (Ord. O-15-028,
12-17-2015)
Sec. 5.407. Persons Under Age.
   A.   No licensee, nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent
or employee of such establishment operator, shall sell, give or deliver
alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of twenty one (21) years, to any
intoxicated person or to any person known by him or her to be under legal
disability or in need of mental treatment. No person, after purchasing or
otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor, shall sell, give or deliver such
alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of twenty one (21) except as
provided in subsection C3 of this section. Additionally, if a Class VG has been
issued for the premises under section
5.304 of this chapter, no person under the age of twenty one (21) years,
visibly intoxicated person, or any person known by the licensee or any officer,
associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such licensee to be
under legal disability or in need of mental treatment shall be allowed to play
a video gaming terminal or be within the video gaming terminal area. Whoever
violates the provisions of this subsection is guilty of a Class B misdemeanor.
      1.   For the purpose of preventing the violation of this section, any
licensee, or his agent or employee, may refuse to sell or serve alcoholic
beverages to any person or refuse to permit any person to play a video gaming
terminal or be within the video gaming terminal area who is unable to produce
adequate written evidence of identity and of the fact that he or she is over
the age of twenty one (21) years.
      2.   Adequate written evidence of age and identity of the person is a
document issued by a Federal, State, County or Municipal government, or
subdivision or agency thereof, including, but not limited to, a driver's or
motor vehicle operator's license, a registration certificate issued under the
Federal Selective Service Act or an identification card issued to a member of
the armed forces. Proof that the licensee, or his employee or agent, demanded,
was shown and reasonably relied upon such written evidence in any transaction
forbidden by this section is competent evidence and may be considered in any
proceedings for the suspension or revocation of any license based thereon.
      3.   Any person who sells, gives or furnishes to any person under the age
of twenty one (21) years any fictitious or unlawfully altered driver's license,
as defined in section 6-301.1 of the Illinois Vehicle Code 1 ; fraudulent
driver's license; or any false or fraudulent written, printed or photostatic
evidence of the age and identity of such person, or who sells, gives or
furnishes to any person under the age of twenty one (21) years, evidence of
age, any driver's license or identification of any other person shall be deemed
to be guilty of a Class B misdemeanor.
      4.   A person under the age of twenty one (21) years is guilty of a Class
B misdemeanor if: a) he or she presents or offers to any licensee, or agent or
employee of the licensee, any fictitious or unlawfully altered driver's
license, as defined in section 6-301.1 of the Illinois Vehicle Code 2 ;
fraudulent driver's license; or other written, printed or photostatic evidence
of age and identity which is false, fraudulent, altered, or not actually his or
her own for the purpose of ordering, purchasing, attempting to purchase or
otherwise procuring or attempting to procure the serving of any alcoholic
beverage; or for the purpose of play or attempting to play a video gaming
terminal or entering or attempting to enter a video gaming terminal area on the
licensed premises; or b) if he or she has in his or her possession any such
fictitious or unlawfully altered driver's license, fraudulent driver's license
or other false or fraudulent written, printed or photostatic evidence of age
and identity while on the licensed premises.
      5.   Any person under the age of twenty one (21) years who has any
alcoholic beverage in his possession on any street or highway or in any public
place or in any place open to the public is guilty of a Class B misdemeanor.
This subsection does not apply to the possession by a person under the age of
twenty one (21) years making a delivery of an alcoholic beverage container in
connection with his or her employment. It shall be unlawful for any such person
under twenty one (21) years of age as an employee or agent of any licensee to
draw, pour and/or mix alcoholic liquor or to maintain or service any video
gaming terminal or to be within any video gaming terminal area. All delivery or
service must be conducted by persons who have completed Beverage Alcohol
Sellers and Servers Education and Training (BASSET) in accordance with section
5.302.C.3 of the City of Wood Dale Municipal Code.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any holder of a retail liquor dealer's
license, or his agent or employee, to suffer or permit any person under age to
be or remain in any room or compartment adjoining or adjacent to or situated in
the room or place where such licensed premises is located; provided, that this
subsection shall not apply to any person under age who is accompanied by his or
her parent or guardian or to any licensed premises which derives its principal
business from the sale of service or other commodities than alcoholic liquor in
his possession.
   C.   It shall be unlawful for any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery
of any alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of age to purchase, accept a gift
of such alcoholic liquor or have such alcoholic liquor in his possession.
      1.   If a licensee or his agents or employees believes or has reason to
believe that a sale or delivery of any alcoholic liquor is prohibited because
of the age of the prospective recipient, he shall, before making such sale or
delivery, demand presentation of some form of positive identification
referenced in subsection A2 of this section, containing proof of age, issued by
a public officer in the performance of his official duties.
      2.   No person shall transfer, alter or deface such an identification
card, use the identification card of another; carry or use false information;
or otherwise misrepresent his age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining
alcoholic liquor or beverage in any tavern or other place in the City where
such alcoholic liquor or beverage is sold. No person shall purchase, accept
delivery, or have possession of alcoholic liquor in violation of this
subsection C. The consumption of alcoholic liquor by any person under twenty
one (21) years of age is forbidden.
      3.   The possession, dispensing or consumption by a person under twenty
one (21) years of age of alcoholic liquor in the performance of a religious
service or ceremony, or the consumption by a person under twenty one (21) years
of age under the direct supervision and approval of the parents or parent or
those persons standing in loco parentis of such person under twenty one (21)
years of age in the privacy of a home is not prohibited by this chapter.
   D.   In every tavern or other place in the City where alcoholic liquor is
sold, there shall be displayed at all times in a prominent place a printed card
which shall be supplied by the Local Liquor Control Commission and which shall
read substantially as follows:
         WARNING TO MINORS
You are subject to a fine up to $500.00 under the ordinance of the City of Wood
Dale if you purchase any alcoholic liquor or misrepresent your age for the
purpose of purchasing or obtaining any alcoholic liquor.
(Ord. O-15-028, 12-17-2015; amd. Ord. O-20-022, 8-20-2020)
 
Notes
1 1. 625 ILCS 5/6-301.1.
2 2. 625 ILCS 5/6-301.1.
Sec. 5.408. Contributions To Elected Officials Or Local Liquor Control
Commission Members.
No licensee or applicant for a retail liquor license; any owner, partner,
managing member, officer, stockholder or member of the licensee owning an
aggregate of more than five percent (5%) of the stock of or other ownership
interest in the licensee or applicant; or any manager of the licensee or
applicant shall make any gift, donation, or contribution of money, services,
goods, or other items of value to an elected official of the City or a member
of the Local Liquor Control Commission of the City. (Ord. O-15-028, 12-17-2015)
ARTICLE V
REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION OF LICENSES
SECTION:
5.501. Revocation Or Suspension Of License
5.502. Complaints
5.503. Penalties Upon Hearing Before The Local Liquor Control Commissioner
Sec. 5.501. Revocation Or Suspension Of License.
   A.   The local liquor control commissioner may revoke or suspend any license
issued by him if he determines that cause exists for such revocation or
suspension by reason that such licensee has:
      1.   Violated any local ordinance or state law; or
      2.   Violated any applicable rules or regulations established by the
local liquor control commission or the state commission; or
      3.   Failed to pay any license fee or any tax imposed on alcoholic liquor
or the sale thereof; or
      4.   Been convicted on a felony charge under the laws of the state of
Illinois or the United States; or
      5.   Been convicted for being the keeper of a house of ill fame; or
      6.   Been convicted for pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed
to decency and morality.
   B.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, however, no such license shall be
revoked or suspended except after a public hearing before the local liquor
control commissioner, on his own initiative, with or without a sworn complaint
having been filed as set forth in section
5.502 of this article. Such hearing shall not commence sooner than three (3)
days after written notice shall have been personally served upon the licensee
at the licensed premises, affording the licensee an opportunity to appear and
defend. All proceedings before the local liquor control commissioner shall be
recorded and placed in a certified official record of such proceedings taken
and prepared by a certified court reporter.
      1.   If the local liquor control commissioner has reason to believe that
any continued operation of a particular licensed premises will threaten
immediately the welfare of the community, he may, upon the issuance of a
written order stating the reason for such conclusion and without notice or
hearing, order a licensed premises closed for not more than seven (7) days,
giving the licensee an opportunity to be heard during that period regarding the
suspension or revocation of the license therefor.
In the event that a payment for an initial license fee or a renewal fee is
returned from the financial institution for insufficient funds, the license
shall immediately be suspended in writing by the liquor commissioner, and
notice will be served upon the licensee. No retail sales of any alcoholic
liquor will be conducted after this notice or the licensee will be subject to
revocation of the license. The liquor license will then not be valid until
appropriate payment has been made by cashier's check.
         a.   Such order shall contain notice of the date, time and place of
the hearing thereon, which hearing shall commence not less than three (3) nor
more than seven (7) days from the date of service, personally or by certified
United States mail, of said notice upon the licensee or any employee thereof in
charge of the licensed premises.
         b.   If such licensee shall also be engaged in the conduct of another
business or businesses on the licensed premises, such initial closing order
shall be not applicable to such other business or businesses.
      2.   The local liquor control commissioner shall, within five (5) days
after such hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license should
be revoked or suspended or that the licensee should be fined, state the reason
or reasons for such determination in a written order of revocation or
suspension or fine and shall serve a copy of such order within the five (5)
days upon the licensee.
   C.   In the event of any appeal from an order or action of the local liquor
control commissioner, the appeal to the Illinois liquor control commission
shall be limited to a review of the official record of the proceedings before
said local liquor control commissioner. In such event, the local liquor control
commissioner shall file with the Illinois liquor control commission the
certified official record of the proceedings within five (5) days after notice
of the filing of such an appeal. (Ord. O-15-028, 12-17-2015)
Sec. 5.502. Complaints.
   A.   Any five (5) residents of the city may file a complaint with the local
liquor control commissioner alleging that any licensee has been or is violating
the provisions of this chapter or the rules or regulations issued pursuant
hereto.
      1.   Such complaint shall be in writing, in the form prescribed by the
local liquor control commissioner and shall be signed and sworn to by the
parties complaining.
      2.   The complaint shall state the particular provisions, rule or
regulation believed to have been violated and the facts in detail upon which
such belief is based.
   B.   If the local liquor control commissioner is satisfied that the
complaint substantially charges a violation and finds probable cause to believe
the same, he shall set the matter for hearing and shall serve notice upon the
licensee of the time and place of such hearing and of the particular charges in
the complaint, such hearing to take place not sooner than three (3) days from
the date upon which such notice is personally served upon the licensee at the
address of the licensed premises. (Ord. O-15-028, 12-17-2015)
Sec. 5.503. Penalties Upon Hearing Before The Local Liquor Control
Commissioner.
   A.   After a hearing on any alleged violation, if the Mayor, as Local Liquor
Control Commissioner, finds that there was any violation of the ordinances of
the City or Statutes of the State of Illinois, he or she may revoke any retail
liquor dealer's license, in which case any bond of the licensee shall thereby
be forfeited. In lieu of revocation of the license and forfeiture of bond, the
Local Liquor Control Commissioner may suspend and/or fine such licensee as
follows:
      1.   If the Local Liquor Control Commissioner determines to suspend such
licensee, the term of the suspension shall not be less than one day nor more
than thirty (30) days.
      2.   If the Local Liquor Control Commissioner elects, in addition to or
in lieu of suspension to fine the licensee, the fine shall be assessed for a
first and second violation within a twelve (12) month period as specified in
the master fee schedule.
      3.   For a third violation within any twelve (12) month period, the Local
Liquor Control Commissioner shall not suspend the retail liquor dealer's
license and/or fine the licensee, but shall revoke the license, and any bond of
the licensee shall thereby be forfeited. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
   B.   A separate offense shall be deemed to have been committed on each day
during or on which a violation is found to have occurred or continued. (Ord. O-
15-028, 12-17-2015)
ARTICLE VI
VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES
SECTION:
5.601. Penalties For Misdemeanor
5.602. Disposition Of Fines And Penalties
Sec. 5.601. Penalties For Misdemeanor.
   A.   It is a misdemeanor for any person to violate any of the provisions of
this chapter unless such violation is by this chapter or other law of the State
of Illinois declared to be a felony.
   B.   It is a misdemeanor for any person, firm or corporation to fail to heed
or otherwise ignore any suspension issued by the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner or his agent.
   C.   Every person, firm or corporation convicted of a misdemeanor for a
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished by a fine
as specified in the master fee schedule for each offense, and a separate
offense shall be deemed to have been committed on each day during or on which a
violation occurs or continues. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
Sec. 5.602. Disposition Of Fines And Penalties.
For offenses committed within the corporate limits of the City or within the
limits and jurisdiction of the City, fines and penalties recovered under the
provisions of this chapter shall be paid over to the General Fund of the City.
(Ord. O-15-028, 12-17-2015)
CHAPTER 6
PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY
ARTICLE I
GENERAL HEALTH AND SAFETY PROVISIONS
SECTION:
6.101. Endangering Public Health Prohibited (Rep. by Ord. O-18-002, 2-1-2018)
6.102. Contagious Diseases
6.103. Open Fires
6.104. Dense Smoke Emissions
6.105. Smoking Prohibited In Certain Places
6.106. Spitting
6.107. Cemeteries
6.108. Heating Apartments
6.109. Common Drinking Cups
6.110. Penalty
Sec. 6.101. Endangering Public Health Prohibited.
(Rep. by Ord. O-18-002, 2-1-2018)
Sec. 6.102. Contagious Diseases.
   A.   Report Of Disease Required: Eery person caring for, treating or in
charge of a person afflicted with a contagious or epidemic disease shall make a
report of it within twenty four (24) hours to the Chief of Police. (1976 Code
§12-22)
   B.   Quarantine:
      1.   Authority: The Chief of Police shall have the power and authority to
place any premises within which a contagious or epidemic disease occurs under
quarantine. He shall enforce the rules that determine the termination time of
the quarantine. (1976 Code §12-23)
      2.   Entry Of Food Handlers Upon Quarantined Premises: No person engaged
in the delivery of food or drink intended for human consumption shall enter any
premises quarantined because of the existence of a contagious or epidemic
disease. (1976 Code §12-25)
      3.   Containers Or Bottles In Quarantined Premises: No containers or
bottles shall be removed from any quarantined premises until the termination of
the quarantine, nor shall such bottle or container be again placed in use for
the carrying of food or drink until it has been thoroughly sterilized. (1976
Code §12-26)
   C.   Spreading Disease Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to
spread wilfully or carelessly any contagious or epidemic disease or to so cause
the spread of same. (1976 Code §12-24)
Sec. 6.103. Open Fires.
It shall be unlawful to cause, start, have and/or maintain any open fire;
except that this prohibition shall not apply:
   A.   To fires used for cooking food at public or private gatherings; and
   B.   To fires commenced by members of the Wood Dale Fire Protection District
No. 1 Fire Department pursuant to orders of the Chief of the department;
provided, that:
      1.   Such orders pertain to the training of the departmental members in
firefighting techniques;
      2.   Such orders have been given pursuant to authorization granted by the
Illinois Environmental Protection Agency and further authorization granted by
the City Council;
      3.   At least forty eight (48) hours before commencing any such training
exercise, the Chief or his duly authorized agent notifies the City Manager of
the location and time of such training exercise; and
      4.   The Fire Chief shall cause the removal of all debris from the
location of such exercise and shall oversee the filling in of any open
excavation left as a result thereof. (1976 Code §12-3)
Sec. 6.104. Dense Smoke Emissions.
It shall be unlawful to cause or permit the emission of dense smoke. For the
purpose of testing and grading the density of smoke, the Ringelmann Smoke
Chart, as published and used by the United States Geological Survey, shall be
and is hereby adopted as a standard for such grading, and smoke is hereby
defined as dense when it is of a degree of no. 3 of said chart, or greater, for
more than six (6) minutes in any one hour. (1976 Code §12-4)
Sec. 6.105. Smoking Prohibited In Certain Places 1 .
It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke or light a cigarette, cigar or
pipe in the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad Company Depot
located south of Irving Park Boulevard, at Cedar Street, adjacent to the
commuter parking lot. The City Manager shall cause printed signs, on which the
words "NO SMOKING" shall appear in letters at least four inches (4") high, to
be placed in at least two (2) conspicuous places in the depot.
Any person violating any provision of this section shall be subject to
enforcement as defined in chapter 1, article IV of this Code. (Ord. O-18-024,
7-19-2018)
 
Notes
1 1. See also subsection 14.508H2 of this Code.
Sec. 6.106. Spitting.
It shall be unlawful to spit or expectorate on any public sidewalk or other
public place or on the floor or walls of any store, theater, hall, public
vehicle or other place frequented by the public or to which the public is
invited.
Any person violating any provision of this section shall be subject to
enforcement as defined in chapter 1, article IV of this Code. (Ord. O-18-024,
7-19-2018)
Sec. 6.107. Cemeteries.
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish a cemetery or to bury any
person except in a previously established cemetery. (1976 Code §12-1)
Sec. 6.108. Heating Apartments.
   A.   Except as otherwise provided by the Federal Energy Office, apartment
houses shall be kept at a temperature of not less than sixty eight degrees
Fahrenheit (68°F) between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M. each day.
   B.   It shall be the duty of the owner or person in charge of any apartment
house where there is a central heating plant controlled by him to maintain and
provide the required heat during the period between October 1 and April 30 of
each year when needed. (1976 Code §12-2)
Sec. 6.109. Common Drinking Cups.
It shall be unlawful to maintain any common drinking cup, dipper or other
similar utensil in any place frequented by the public. (1976 Code §12-8)
Sec. 6.110. Penalty.
Any person who shall be convicted of violating any provision of this article,
where there is no provision to the contrary, shall be subject to enforcement as
defined in chapter 1, article IV of this Code. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
ARTICLE II
NUISANCES
SECTION:
6.201. Definitions
6.202. Unhealthful Premises
6.203. Stagnant Water
6.204. Obstructing Or Dumping In Watercourses
6.205. Storage Of Inoperable Or Junk Motor Vehicles
6.206. Nuisance Greenery
6.207. Penalty
6.208. Abatement
6.209. Abatement Liens
Sec. 6.201. Definitions.
For the purpose in this section, wherever in this article the following words
and phrases are used, they shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them
in this section, except when the context of the said words and phrases
otherwise indicate:
INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLE: A vehicle which cannot be driven upon the public
streets for reason including but not limited to being unlicensed, wrecked,
abandoned, in a state of disrepair, or incapable of being moved under its own
power.
NEGLECT: The lack of property maintenance for a building, structure, or
property.
NUISANCE: Any object, condition, or conduct that endangers health and safety,
or unreasonably offends the senses, or obstructs the free use and comfortable
enjoyment of property, or essentially interferes with the comfortable enjoyment
of life.
STAGNANT: Pertaining to a body of water having no current or flow.
WATERCOURSE: A natural or artificial channel through which water flows. (Ord.
O-17-024, 11-16-2017)
Sec. 6.202. Unhealthful Premises.
It shall be unlawful to permit any building, structure, or place to remain in
such a condition as to be dangerous to the public health and safety in any way.
Any such structure, building or place is hereby declared to be a nuisance.
(Ord. O-17-024, 11-16-2017)
Sec. 6.203. Stagnant Water.
All stagnant accumulation of water is hereby declared to be a nuisance. It
shall be unlawful for any person to permit any such nuisance to remain or exist
on any property. (Ord. O-17-024, 11-16-2017)
Sec. 6.204. Obstructing Or Dumping In Watercourses.
It shall be unlawful and a nuisance for any person to obstruct or dump in a
watercourse or source of water supply. (Ord. O-17-024, 11-16-2017)
Sec. 6.205. Storage Of Inoperable Or Junk Motor Vehicles.
   A.   Storage And Parking: Storage and parking of any inoperable motor
vehicle, except when fully enclosed within a garage, shall be declared a
nuisance.
   B.   Exemptions From Provisions: Nothing in this section shall apply to any
motor vehicle on the properly zoned premises of a place of business engaged in
the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles. (Ord. O-17-024, 11-16-2017)
Sec. 6.206. Nuisance Greenery.
   A.   Nuisance Declared: Any neglected and overgrown weeds, grass or plants;
neglected and overgrown shrubs and trees found growing in any lot or tract of
land are hereby declared to be a nuisance, and it shall be unlawful to permit
any such nuisance to grow or remain in any such place.
   B.   Restrictions On Growth:
      1.   Weed And Grass Height Restrictions: It shall be unlawful to permit
any weeds or grass to grow to a height exceeding nine inches (9").
      2.   Overgrown Trees, Bushes Grass and Weeds:
         a.   Private Property: It shall be unlawful to permit any trees, OF
bushes, grass or weeds to become neglected and overgrown to the extent, among
other things, they cover windows, doors, sidewalks, driveways and/or encroach
onto other property.
         b.   Public Property: Any tree or shrub which overhangs any sidewalk,
street or other public place in such a way to impede or interfere with traffic
or travel on such public place shall be trimmed by the owner and/or occupant of
the abutting premises on which such trees or shrubs grow, so as to remove said
obstruction shall cease. Any limb of a tree or shrub which is likely to fall on
or across any public way or place shall be removed by the owner and/or the
occupant of the premises on which such tree or shrub is located.
         c.   Parkway Maintenance: The owner and/or occupant of any premises
abutting any public street. road or way shall maintain the area between the
edge of pavement or curb and the private property line. commonly known as
parkway, in a neat, clean and orderly condition and in conformance with the
provisions of the city code. If the owner and/or occupant of any such abutting
premises fails to remove limbs or shrubs overhanging any public way or fails to
properly maintain the parkway, such shall be declared a nuisance and enforced
as provided for in the city code.
      If the owner and/or occupant of any such abutting premises fails to
remove limbs or shrubs overhanging any public way or fails to properly maintain
the parkway, such shall be declared a nuisance and enforced as provided for in
the city code.
      3.   Aquatic Weeds: Any aquatic weeds such as duckweed, curly leaf
pondweed, water milfoil or other aquatic weeds of like kind, found growing in
any manmade body of water such as detention or retention ponds or basins or
other stormwater management facilities are hereby declared to be a nuisance,
and it shall be unlawful to permit any such aquatic weeds to grow or remain in
any such place.
   C.   Trees And Shrubs On Private Property: Any tree on private property that
is deemed diseased, dead, dying and/or poses a threat to the health, safety,
and/or welfare of the public or other property shall be declared a nuisance.
(Ord. O-17-024, 11-16-2017; amd. Ord. O-20-020, 8-6-2020)
Sec. 6.207. Penalty.
Any person who violates, neglects, refuses to comply with, or assists or
participates in any way in the violation of any of provisions or requirements
of this article shall be subject to enforcement as defined in chapter 1,
article IV of this Code, unless otherwise specified. (Ord. O-17-024, 11-16-
2017)
Sec. 6.208. Abatement.
   A.   Notice To Remove: The Community Development Director or his designee
shall have charge of the operation of the City's Nuisance Abatement Program and
shall cause a visual inspection to be made of all properties in violation of
the provisions of this article. Whenever an inspection discloses the existence
of a violation of any of the regulations contained in this article, the
Community Development Director or his designee shall cause notice to be served
upon the owner or occupant of the premises upon which the violation is found to
exist.
   B.   Abatement: In the event any person notified of a violation pursuant to
this article does not abate a nuisance declared by this article within seven
(7) days, the City may proceed to abate such nuisance, including but not
limited to removal, cutting, trimming or disposal of said nuisance. The City
shall keep an account of the expense incurred in the abatement, which shall be
charged to and paid by such owner or occupant. (Ord. O-17-024, 11-16-2017)
Sec. 6.209. Abatement Liens.
   A.   Lien Claim: Costs and expenses incurred by the City for its abatement
activities shall be a lien against private property pursuant to section 11-20-
15 of the Illinois Municipal Code, as amended from time to time, and against
abandoned residential property pursuant to section 11-20-15.1 of the Illinois
Municipal Code, as amended from time to time.
   B.   Foreclosure Of Lien: Property subject to lien for unpaid nuisance
abatement costs shall be sold for nonpayment of the same pursuant to the
applicable sections of the Code of Civil Procedure, and the proceeds of such
sale shall be applied to pay the charges after deducting costs, as is the case
in the foreclosure of statutory liens. Such foreclosure shall be in equity in
the name of the City.
   C.   Authorization: The City Manager or his designee may authorize any
action, in addition to the above authorized claim for lien, for the collection
of the nuisance removal charges authorized in this article. (Ord. O-17-024, 11-
16-2017)
ARTICLE III
GARBAGE AND REFUSE
SECTION:
6.301. Prohibited Accumulation And Disposal
6.302. Refuse Containers
6.303. Mandatory Collection Of Refuse
6.304. Scavenger Service Rates And Charges; Buildings Containing Not More Than
Two Residential Dwelling Units
6.305. Licensing And Regulation Of Scavengers (Rep. by Ord. O-16-033, 11-17-
2016)
6.306. Vehicle Requirements (Rep. by Ord. O-16-033, 11-17-2016)
6.307. Penalty
6.308. Littering Prohibited
6.309. Theft Of Recyclables
6.310. Definitions
Sec. 6.301. Prohibited Accumulation And Disposal.
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any uncovered piles of
refuse, garbage, offal or carcasses of dead animals. Such material must be
buried at least two feet (2') below the surface of the ground or burned in
properly constructed incinerators or otherwise properly disposed of. Any
uncovered piles of such material are hereby declared to be a nuisance. (1976
Code §12-9)
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to burn garbage, other than in
incinerators approved by the environmental protection agency of the state of
Illinois, or to bury garbage within the corporate limits of the city, or to
permit garbage and/or debris to accumulate in any manner so as to create a
nuisance or to attract flies, vermin or rats. Any garbage accumulated for more
than seven (7) days, unless interrupted by a legal holiday, shall be considered
a violation of this subsection notwithstanding any other provision herein
contained.
      1.   If the garbage and/or debris referred to hereinabove is allowed to
accumulate for more than seven (7) days or in fact attract flies, vermin or
rats, the health officer of the city may proceed to cause the removal of such
garbage and/or debris from such private property in the following manner:
         a.   Whenever the health officer observes that garbage and/or debris
is attracting flies, vermin or rats, and/or such garbage and/or debris has
accumulated for more than seven (7) days, he shall serve written notice upon
the owner or occupant of any such premises whereon such garbage and/or debris
is located. Such notice shall inform such person of the violation and shall
order removal of said garbage and/or debris within forty eight (48) hours from
the time notice is so served.
         b.   If, after lapse of the aforesaid forty eight (48) hour period,
such owner or occupant of such property refuses or neglects to remove such
garbage and/or debris, the health officer shall cause such garbage and/or
debris to be removed from the said property and shall cause collection from
such owner or occupant, the cost of such removal which shall be paid over to
the city treasurer.
         c.   If, upon receipt of such invoice, such owner or occupant refuses
or neglects to pay the cost for such removal, the health officer, on behalf of
the city or the person performing the service by authority of the city, in his
or its own name, shall file a notice of lien within sixty (60) days after such
cost and expense is incurred, which notice of lien shall be filed in the office
of the DuPage County recorder of deeds, or in the office of the DuPage County
registrar of titles where the real estate affected is registered under the
torrens system. This notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting
out:
            (1)   A description of the real estate sufficient for
identification thereof;
            (2)   The amount of money representing the cost and expense
incurred or payable for the service; and
            (3)   The date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by
the city.
Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner of or persons interested in
such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released
by the city or person in whose name the lien had been filed, and the release
may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. The lien may be
enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in case of mortgages or mechanics'
liens. Suit to foreclose this lien shall be commenced within two (2) years
after the date of filing notice of lien; however, the lien of the city shall
not be valid as to any purchaser whose rights in and to such real estate have
arisen subsequent to removal of the garbage and/or debris and prior to the
filing of such notice, and the lien of the city shall not be valid as to any
mortgagee, judgment creditor or other lienor whose rights in and to such real
estate arise prior to the filing of such notice. Nothing hereinabove shall
preclude filing of a complaint with the court of proper jurisdiction for
violations of this subsection and/or other remedies at law or in equity which
may be available to the city for the enforcement of this code. (1976 Code §12-
57)
   C.   No scavenger shall dispose of or store any refuse of any kind within
the city limits or within one and one-half (11/2) miles thereof without the
prior written consent of the city council of the city. (Ord. 2016, 5-18-2000,
eff. 6-22-2000)
Sec. 6.302. Refuse Containers.
   A.   Garbage To Be Wrapped: All garbage and other disposed of animal or
vegetable matter shall be wrapped in paper or in plastic before being placed in
an approved receptacle.
   B.   Approved Receptacles:
      1.   Required: It shall be the duty of every owner, or his agent, or
occupant of all residential premises, including hotels and motels, restaurants
and/or other premises where animal or vegetable matter is prepared or served,
to maintain at all times in good order and repair approved receptacles for
garbage, tin cans, bottles, ashes and other refuse.
      2.   Specifications: Approved receptacles for refuse shall be watertight
and made of plastic or galvanized metal and shall have a tightfitting cover, a
capacity not exceeding thirty five (35) gallons, and suitable handles. In
addition, 4-ply waterproof paper or plastic garbage bags with tie down tops may
be used. (Ord. 2016, 5-18-2000, eff. 6-22-2000)
Sec. 6.303. Mandatory Collection Of Refuse.
   A.   Buildings Containing One Or Two Residential Dwelling Units: At least
one resident of each building containing one or two (2) residential dwelling
units located within the corporate limits of the City must pay the City the
applicable rate set forth in section
6.304 of this article and subscribe to the scavenger service contracted for by
the City for the collection and removal of all refuse generated by the
occupants thereof or otherwise located on the lot occupied by such building.
      1.   On the assigned day for pick up, the subscriber shall place or cause
to be placed at the curb all refuse to be collected. It shall be unlawful for
any person to deposit garbage or refuse or garbage containers or any metal
container in any street, alley or public way except for a period no earlier
than four o’clock (4:00) P.M. the day before scheduled collection, nor later
than eight o’clock (8:00) P.M. the day of collection. At all other times, the
garbage or refuse of any kind or garbage containers or metal containers of any
kind shall be stored in the rear of the premises.
A maximum of two garbage toters that are issued by the City or the scavenger
service provider may be stored in a location other than the rear of the
premises, provided that they are not stored directly in front of an overhead
garage door or the driveway leading to the garage, where the front edge of the
garage has a setback from the street that is similar to, or closer to the
setback of the residence, or on any sidewalk that leads to the front door of a
residence. The installation of a cover, landscaping, or other screening that
minimizes the visibility of the refuse container as one of the most pronounced
elements of the front of the premises would also satisfy this regulation.
Installation of these types of covers, landscaping, or screening must meet any
applicable City Code for installation. Any additional refuse beyond that which
is fully contained within the two issued garbage toters must be stored in the
rear of the residence and is not allowed to be stored at any location in the
front of the premises at any time.
      2.   The City contracted for scavenger service shall remove all refuse,
except as otherwise provided by contract. At their cost and expense,
subscribers shall make arrangements with any other scavenger registered by the
City to secure the removal of items which the City’s contract for scavenger
service will not remove.
      3.   Subscribers shall cause brush, tree trunks and wood to be bundled,
and bundles shall not exceed two inches (2") in diameter and four feet (4') in
length.
      4.   No person shall combine the refuse from two (2) or more residential
dwelling units to be placed in such a manner as to be collected and billed as
though from one residential dwelling unit
   B.   All Other Buildings And Uses: All occupants of premises other than
residential buildings containing not more than two (2) dwelling units shall
make the contractual arrangements with any scavenger registered by the City to
secure the removal of all refuse generated by the occupants thereof or
otherwise located on the lot occupied by such building or use. All apartment
buildings must provide the occupants a central location where refuse is held
for pick up and disposal by a scavenger. (Ord. 2016, 5-18-2000, eff. 6-22-2000;
amd. Ord. O-09-003, 2-5-2009; Ord. O-16-033, 11-17-2016; Ord. O-22-010, 3-17-
2022; Ord. O-23-017, 6-15-2023)
Sec. 6.304. Scavenger Service Rates And Charges; Buildings Containing Not More
Than Two Residential Dwelling Units.
   A.   Rates And Charges: The monthly rate of scavenger service provided by
the City to subscribers for the collection and removal of all refuse generated
by the occupants of residential dwelling units in buildings containing not more
than two (2) residential dwelling units or refuse otherwise located on the lot
occupied by such building shall be the monthly rate currently charged by the
scavenger service provider plus a monthly administrative charge as specified in
the master fee schedule.
   B.   Application And Provisions For Rate Reduction: Upon written application
of any subscriber whose household income is not more than the very low income
figures established by the income eligibility rates published by HUD effective
July 1, 1979, and as these rates have been and may be revised from time to time
thereafter, as verified by the resident's previous year's United States Federal
Income Tax return, the City Collector shall authorize a reduction as specified
in the master fee schedule; provided, however, that such subscriber provides
annual proof of eligibility and is also a:
      1.   Head of household entitled to and receiving benefits under the
social security act or benefits under other pension plans and is at least sixty
two (62) years of age; or
      2.   Widower or widow having a dependent child or dependent children; or
      3.   Person who is totally disabled; or
      4.   United States military veteran.
Proof of eligibility shall be submitted annually thereafter to said City
Collector. Said rate reduction shall not result in a credit to any user's
account.
   C.   Statements: City statements for scavenger service shall be rendered as
of the first day of each month succeeding the period for which service is
billed and shall be payable upon receipt and not later than the close of
business on the twenty first day of the month the statement is sent. Bills paid
after the said twenty first of the month sent shall be subject to a penalty as
specified in the master fee schedule.
   D.   Termination: The City may terminate scavenger service to any dwelling
unit wherein the subscriber is in arrears to the City for any amount for fifty
(50) or more days. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
Sec. 6.305. Licensing And Regulation Of Scavengers 1 .
(Rep. by Ord. O-16-033, 11-17-2016)

Sec. 6.307. Penalty.
   A.   Failure to comply with any regulation contained in this article shall
be deemed a violation thereof. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate
any regulation contained in this article. (Ord. 2016, 5-18-2000, eff. 6-22-
2000)
   B.   Any person who shall be convicted of violating any provision of this
article shall be subject to enforcement as defined in chapter 1, article IV of
this Code. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
Sec. 6.308. Littering Prohibited.
   A.   Littering Prohibited In Public Places:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit litter in or
upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the City except in
public receptacles, in authorized private receptacles for collection or in
official City dumps. The foregoing shall not apply to any person placing litter
(or causing litter to be placed) in proper bundles for collection at the curb
upon the parkway adjacent to private property owned or leased by such person.
      2.   No person while a driver or passenger in a vehicle shall throw or
deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the City or upon
private property.
      3.   The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all
times maintain the premises free of litter; provided, however, that this
section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private
receptacles for collection.
      4.   Unless placing litter in an authorized private receptacle, no person
shall throw or deposit litter on any private property within the City whether
owned by such person or not. Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in
authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent such
litter from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street,
sidewalk or other public or private property.
   B.   Clearing Of Litter From Private Property By The City:
      1.   Notice To Remove: The City Manager is authorized and empowered
hereby to notify the owner of any open private property within the City or the
agent of such owner to properly dispose of litter located on such owner's
property which is dangerous to public health, safety or welfare; such notice
shall be by registered or certified mail addressed to said owner at his last
known address as shown on the records of the collector of taxes of DuPage
County, Illinois.
      2.   Action Upon Noncompliance: Upon the failure and neglect or refusal
of any owner or agent so notified to properly dispose of litter which is
dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare within fifteen (15) days
after receipt of the written notice provided for in subsection B1 of this
section or within ten (10) days after the date of such notice in the event the
same is returned by the Post Office because of its inability to make delivery
thereof, provided the same was properly addressed to the last known address of
such owner or agent. The City Manager is authorized and empowered hereby to
effect the removal and disposal of such litter.
   C.   Dumping Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit
litter upon private property or in any authorized private receptacle located
upon private property whenever such private property is not owned or leased by
such person. (Ord. 1600, 7-18-1991)
   D.   Penalty: Whoever violates any provision of this section shall be
subject to enforcement as defined in chapter 1, article IV of this Code. (Ord.
O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
Sec. 6.309. Theft Of Recyclables.
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to collect, obtain, possess or pick
up any recyclable item placed for collection in front of any residential
structure as part of the City of Wood Dale recycling program, unless said
person is registered as the exclusive recycling contractor under the provisions
of section 4.502 of this Code. (Ord. 1591, 5-17-1991; amd. Ord. O-16-033, 11-
17-2016)
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with the terms of
subsection A of this section. Any person found to be in violation of subsection
A of this section shall be subject to enforcement as defined in chapter 1,
article IV of this Code. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
Sec. 6.310. Definitions.
   A.   When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense
include the future tense, words used in the plural number include the singular
and words used in the singular number include the plural number. The word
"shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. In addition, the
masculine includes the feminine and neuter.
   B.   For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words
and their derivations shall have the meanings given hereinbelow:
   APPROVED RECEPTACLE: A container which complies with the regulation
contained in section
6.302 of this article.
   GARBAGE: Putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the
handling, preparation, and cooking of food or foodstuffs.
   HUD: The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.
   LITTER: Refuse and all other material which, if thrown or deposited as
herein prohibited, tends or may tend to create a danger to public health,
safety and welfare.
   PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation of any
kind.
   PRIVATE PROPERTY: Real estate not under the ownership of any government or
school district.
   PUBLIC PLACE: Any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other
public ways, any and all public parks, squares, spaces, and grounds, and the
areas of public buildings into which the general public is authorized to
assemble.
   REFUSE: All putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body wastes)
including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned
vehicles, and solid market and industrial wastes, including, but not limited
to:
      1.   High density polyethylene (HDPE) #2 blow molded containers: plastic
milk and water jugs, laundry detergent, shampoo, personal care, and other
similar blow molded containers used inside the home.
      2.   Other high density polyethylene (HDPE) #2 containers: margarine
tubs, baby wipe containers, and other similar molded containers used inside the
home.
      3.   Juice boxes: aseptic cartons consisting of a high grade paperboard
coated with polyethylene plastic and aluminum foil, excluding milk cartons.
      4.   Polyethylene terephthalate (PET #1) blow molded containers: soft
drink, liquor, cooking oil, personal care, and other similar blow molded
containers used inside the home.
      5.   Other polyethylene terephthalate (PET #1) containers: plastic
plates, trays, cups, and other similar ejection molded containers used inside
the home.
      6.   Polypropylene (PP#5): yogurt, cottage cheese and sour cream tubs,
syrup bottles, etc.
      7.   Polystyrene (PS#6) plastic containers: foam packaging peanuts,
drinking cups, plates, carryout containers, egg cartons, meat and produce
trays, and other similar foam materials.
      8.   Polystyrene (PS#6) plastic packaging materials: white and clear
packing grade.
      9.   Polyvinyl/Chloride (PVC #3): health and beauty aid bottles.
      10.   Recyclables (also referred to as recyclable materials): materials
which have a useful second life in the economic cycle if they are successfully
collected, separated, processed, and marketed for return to the economic
mainstream. Recyclable materials shall include aluminum cans, tin/steel/bimetal
cans, colored and clear glass bottles, HDPE, PET and PS, plastic containers #1,
#2 and #6, newspaper, magazines, catalogs, telephone directories, corrugated
cardboard, chipboard, 6-pack rings, and any other items the City and the
contractor agree to recycle in the future.
   RUBBISH: Nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and
noncombustible wastes such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin
cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, trash, glass, bedding, crockery and similar
materials.
   SCAVENGER: Any person registered by the City who collects refuse and hauls
same away to locations outside of the corporate limits of the City.
   SUBSCRIBER: A resident of a dwelling unit in a one or two (2) residential
dwelling unit building who subscribes to the scavenger service contracted for
by the City. (Ord. 2016, 5-18-2000, eff. 6-22-2000; amd. Ord. O-16-033, 11-17-
2016)
ARTICLE IV
NOISE CONTROL
SECTION:
6.401. Sound Amplification Devices
6.402. Steam Whistles
Sec. 6.401. Sound Amplification Devices 1 .
   A.   License Required: It shall be unlawful to maintain or operate any sound
amplification device by which sounds are projected over any public street or
place without a license. (1976 Code §16-1)
   B.   Application For Device License: Any person desiring a license for the
use or operation of a sound amplification device shall file an application with
the city clerk upon a form provided by him, setting forth his name and address,
the name and address of the owner of the sound amplification device, the date
upon which it is intended to be used and such other information as may be
required. (1976 Code §16-3)
   C.   Issuance Of License; Conditions: A sound amplification device shall be
issued upon the payment of the required fee to the city clerk and shall permit
the use of any such device as regulated by law only upon the dates specified on
the license. (1976 Code §16-4)
   D.   Restriction Of Use Of Sound Amplification Devices: It shall be unlawful
for any person using a sound amplification device to use such device:
      1.   So as to be heard for a distance greater than three hundred feet
(300').
      2.   When passing a hospital.
      3.   When passing a church or other place of worship during the hours
when services are being held.
      4.   When any vehicle he is using is stopped for the purpose of making a
sale.
      5.   Before the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. on weekdays and ten
o'clock (10:00) A.M. on Sundays or after seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. on any day.
      6.   Within five hundred feet (500') of any school during the school
year.
This subsection shall not apply to radios in homes or in private pleasure
vehicles when they are operated in a manner as not to be audible at a distance
of fifty feet (50') from such vehicle, nor shall it apply to bands or musical
devices used in any public parade or procession operating under a city permit 2
. (1976 Code §16-5)
   E.   Prohibited Acts and Conditions: No person shall cause or permit to be
emanated or emitted from any sound amplification device any lewd, obscene,
profane or indecent language or sounds, or any false representation of any
matter, or any advertisement for any product or project whose sale is
prohibited. (1976 Code §16-7)
 
Notes
1 1. See also prohibitions set out in subsection 14.508O of this code.
2 1. See chapter 14, article 7 of this code.
Sec. 6.402. Steam Whistles.
It shall be unlawful to blow or cause to be blown or sounded any steam whistle
of any engine except as a signal for starting or stopping work or in
emergencies in order to avoid injury to persons or property. (1976 Code §16-8)
ARTICLE V
COMPREHENSIVE TREE ORDINANCE
SECTION:
6.501. Purpose
6.502. Definitions
6.503. General Provisions
6.504. Public Trees And Shrubs
6.505. Private Trees And Shrubs
6.506. Penalty
Sec. 6.501. Purpose.
Trees, both on public and private property, play a vital role in the well-being
of a community. Trees provide multiple benefits for both the public and private
property owners including enhancing air quality, reducing stormwater run-off,
providing shade, reducing noise pollution, and improving the aesthetics of the
community. This article will provide regulations and requirements to help
maintain a healthy tree canopy. (Ord. O-17-024, 11-16-2017)
Sec. 6.502. Definitions.
As used in this article, the following terms shall be defined as follows:
DECIDUOUS: Tree or other plant that sheds all of its leaves according to a
genetically scheduled cycle as impacted by climate factors, usually during the
cold season in temperate zones.
DIAMETER AT BREAST HEIGHT (DBH): The diameter of a standing tree measured at
4.5 feet above the ground. This measurement applies to mature trees.
DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS: The individual designated by the City Manager to
enforce this article, or his or her designee.
PARKWAY: The area between the edge of the existing paved street or curb and the
property line.
PUBLIC PLACE: An area that is used or intended to be used by the general
public, including but not limited to rights-of-way, parks and playgrounds.
PUBLIC PROPERTY: Any property owned by a governmental entity, including but not
limited to the City, township, County, special districts (such as the Library
District, Fire Protection District, School District, etc.) and the State or
Federal government.
PUBLIC TREE: Trees now or hereafter growing within a right-of-way or on any
property owned or maintained by the City.
RIGHT-OF-WAY: An area of land not on a lot that is dedicated for public or
private use to accommodate a transportation system and necessary public utility
infrastructure (including but not limited to water lines, sewer lines, power
lines and gas lines). In no case shall a right-of-way be construed to mean an
easement. (Ord. O-17-024, 11-16-2017)
Sec. 6.503. General Provisions.
   A.   Trees Permitted:
      1.   Public trees and trees required by section
17.606 of this Code shall be selected from the list of approved tree species
approved by the Director of Public Works.
      2.   A list of said approved trees shall be kept on file with the City
and reviewed annually to ensure a variety of tree species are being planted and
no species on said list are susceptible to common diseases.
   B.   Prohibited Trees:
      1.   A list of trees that are prohibited from being planted on public
property or on private property meeting the requirements of section
17.606 of this Code shall be approved by the Public Works Director and kept on
file with the City.
      2.   The list of said prohibited trees shall be reviewed annually to
ensure that the list includes species that are considered susceptible to
disease or undesirable.
   C.   Tree Planting Requirements:
      1.   Minimum Size For Public Trees And Trees Required By Section
17.606 Of This Code:
         a.   When planted, deciduous trees shall have a minimum size of two
inches (2") in diameter at breast height (DBH), except as otherwise specified.
         b.   When planted, coniferous trees shall be a minimum six feet (6')
in height.
      2.   Shape: When planted, trees shall have a continuous single straight
trunk and shall be free from deformity and indication of undesirable growth
characteristics.
      3.   Quality: When planted, trees shall be free of infectious diseases or
insect infestations.
      4.   ANSI Requirements: All trees must meet requirements as listed in the
American Standard for Nursery Stock (ANSI Z60.1-2004) latest edition.
   D.   Prohibited Locations:
      1.   The planting of trees is prohibited if such planting will interfere
with existing utilities.
      2.   The planting of trees is prohibited if such planting will interfere
with traffic, usual use of public property, impact a right-of-way or have an
adverse impact on motorist and pedestrian safety.
      3.   Trees shall not be planted within the sight triangle as defined in
subsection
17.601P of this Code to ensure adequate intersection visibility in accordance
with subsection
17.606C3r of this Code.
   E.   Nuisance Trees: Any tree diseased, dead, or otherwise declared a
nuisance in accordance with article II of this chapter shall be promptly
removed and disposed of in accordance with article II of this chapter. Removal
of public trees under this provision requires approval of the Public Works
Director.
   F.   Interference: It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or
interfere with the Public Works Director, or any of the City's agents, while
engaging in and about the planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying,
or removing of any public trees or trees on private property, as authorized in
this article. (Ord. O-17-024, 11-16-2017)
Sec. 6.504. Public Trees And Shrubs.
   A.   Authority And Supervision: The Director of Public Works is hereby
empowered to superintend and direct the planting, preservation, protection,
maintenance and removal of public trees and other vegetation in accordance with
this article and chapter 17 of this Code.
   B.   General Provisions:
      1.   Damage To Public Trees And Shrubs Prohibited:
         a.   Utilities: Any person maintaining any utility lines in the
streets or other public places shall take proper care to avoid causing injury
to the roots of any tree or shrub.
         b.   Excavations: When excavating in the right-of-way or other public
places, proper care shall be taken to avoid causing injury to the roots of any
tree or shrub.
         c.   Damage: Except as otherwise provided, it shall be unlawful to
injure, including but not limited to removing, destroying, breaking, cutting,
defacing or injuring or interfering with the growth, of any tree or shrub
planted in any public place.
      2.   Spraying Of Public Trees:
         a.   Spraying of public trees for the prevention and elimination of
disease and insect infestation shall be performed to meet the specific
requirements of the species of tree and the particular disease of insect
infestation which exists or threatens as set forth by the Director of Public
Works.
         b.   It shall be the Director of Public Works' responsibility to
determine the need and extent of spraying requirements for public trees.
      3.   Tree Trimmers And Sprayers:
         a.   Permission Required: No tree trimmer or sprayer shall trim or
spray any public tree without the permission of the Director of Public Works.
         b.   Certification: All tree trimmer and sprayer contractors must be
certified arborists provided by the International Society of Arboriculture.
   C.   Planting Public Trees And Shrubs:
      1.   Authority To Plant:
         a.   No person other than the City shall plant public trees and shrubs
except as otherwise authorized by the Director of Public Works either through a
contract or in accordance with section
17.606 of this Code.
         b.   The Director of Public Works shall be solely responsible for
selecting tree species and planting locations that are in the best interest of
the City.
      2.   Planting Requirements:
         a.   Parkways: It is the intention of the City to plant public trees
in all parkways, where space permits. The City will plant new and replacement
public trees in accordance with the forestry program budgeted annually.
         b.   Planting Line: Public trees in parkways should be planted on the
centerline of the parkway or as approved by the Public Works Director.
         c.   Guidelines: All planting and transplanting of public trees must
adhere to the guidelines found in the latest editions of Principles and
Practices of Planting Trees and Shrubs and the latest edition of the
International Society of Arboriculture and American National Standards
Institute for Tree Care Operations - Transplanting (ANSI A300).
         d.   Spacing:
            (1)   New Trees: All new trees planted in parkways shall meet the
following minimum and maximum footage between trees, where possible:
 
Tree Size1             Minimum Space Maximum Space
Large (over 40 feet)   35 feet       70 feet
Medium (up to 40 feet) 25 feet       50 feet
Small (up to 20 feet)  15 feet       40 feet
 
      Note:
         1.    Tree size refers to the mature height of the tree species.
            (2)   Existing Trees: Spacing of existing trees shall be brought
into conformance with the above table through normal attrition and gradual
planned removal of undesirable trees.
   D.   Removal And Replacement Of Undesirable Trees:
      1.   All crippled, deformed, physically damaged, dead or dying trees,
regardless of species, shall be removed and replaced with approved trees.
      2.   All trees infected with non-curable disease that professional
opinion indicates will result in death, deformation or the infection of other
trees shall be immediately removed and replaced with approved trees.
   E.   Protecting Public Trees:
      1.   Protection During Construction: During any type of construction
work, the owner or contractor shall erect a chain- link fence at the edge of
any nearby public tree's dripline to prevent injury to them.
      2.   Attaching Wires To Trees: No person shall attach or connect any
electric or other wire to any public tree nor permit any such wire to come in
contact with a public tree.
      3.   Posting Signs On Trees: No person shall attach any sign, placard, or
poster to any public tree in accordance with section 13.401 of this Code.
      4.   Impeding Water And Air: No person shall place or maintain upon the
ground around a public tree any surfacing or material which will impede free
passage of water and air to the roots without leaving an open space of not less
than two feet (2') in width all around the tree.
      5.   Excavations: No person shall raise the grade around the existing
public trees without the approval of the Director of Public Works. (Ord. O-17-
024, 11-16-2017)
Sec. 6.505. Private Trees And Shrubs.
   A.   It shall be the duty of any person or persons owning or occupying real
property on which there are trees, to prune such trees in such manner that they
will not obstruct or shade street lights, obstruct the passage of pedestrians
on sidewalks, obstruct vision of traffic signs, or obstruct views of any street
or alley intersection. Trimming and pruning shall be carried out in accordance
with the standards set forth in the latest edition of the American National
Standard Institute for Tree Care Operations (ANSI A300).
   B.   It shall be the duty of any person owning or occupying real property on
which there are trees that are diseased or insect infested, to control and
eliminate diseased or infested trees.
      1.   General Standards: Control and elimination of diseased or infested
trees shall be done in a manner that minimizes the risks to other plant, wild
or human life.
      2.   USDA - APHIS: The control and elimination of a specific disease
should be done in accordance with the regulations and requirements set forth by
the United States Department of Agriculture - Animal and Plant Health
Inspection Services (USDA - APHIS) for said specific disease.
      3.   Director's Discretion: If the USDA - APHIS has not published
regulations and requirements for the control and elimination for said disease,
the Director of Public Works in his sole discretion shall identify appropriate
remedies.
      4.   Notification Required: Spraying of private trees for the prevention
and elimination of disease and infestation shall be performed upon notification
and approval by the Director of Public Works.
   C.   The removal of trees on private property shall be in accordance with
section 17.606 of this Code.
   D.   Development of private property shall plant landscaping and trees in
accordance with section 17.606 of this Code. (Ord. O-17-024, 11-16-2017)
Sec. 6.506. Penalty.
Any person who violates, neglects, refuses to comply with, or assists or
participates in any way in the violation of any of the provisions or
requirements of this article shall be subject to enforcement as defined in
chapter 1, article IV of this Code, unless otherwise specified.
A separate offense shall be deemed to have been committed for each tree or
shrub injured, damaged, and/or removed in violation of this article. (Ord. O-
17-024, 11-16-2017)
