1 1. See chapter 12 of this code.
Sec. 7.102. Water And Sewage Facilities Required.
It shall be unlawful for any person to use for any purposes any building or
structure not adequately provided with a potable water supply and with sanitary
sewage disposal facilities or to conduct or operate any business or
establishment to which the public is invited for the purpose of eating,
entertainment or recreation unless there are provided on the premises adequate
separate toilet facilities for the use of male and female patrons. (Ord. O-15-
001, 1-15-2015)
Sec. 7.103. New Private Wells; New Private Septic Systems Prohibited 1 .
After July 21, 1988, no private water well shall be drilled and no private
sanitary septic system shall be constructed or installed; provided, however,
that these prohibitions shall not apply to repairs or maintenance of such wells
and/or septic systems that are existing on the effective date hereof. (Ord. O-
15-001, 1-15-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. See also sections 7.310 and 7.422 of this chapter.
ARTICLE II
WATER AND SEWER ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
7.201. Water And Wastewater Department
7.202. Applications For Service; Deposit
7.203. Changes Of Account
7.204. Delinquencies In Payments Of Bills
7.205. Entry Powers
7.206. Violations
7.207. Penalties
7.208. Civil Damages
Sec. 7.201. Water And Wastewater Department.
   A.   Director Of Water And Wastewater:
      1.   Office Created; Appointment; Term: There is hereby created the
Office of Director of Water and Wastewater, an executive office of the City.
The holder of such office shall be appointed for an indefinite period of time
by the City Manager.
      2.   Duties: The Director shall have the following duties: (Ord. 1460, 7-
21-1988)
         a.   Generally: The Director shall have charge of the operation and
maintenance of the City's waterworks system, sanitary sewer system, storm sewer
system and all appurtenances thereto. He shall:
            (1)   Administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of this
chapter.
            (2)   Make or cause to be made all inspections necessary to enforce
all laws relating to water and the waterworks system as well as those relating
to sewers and the sanitary sewer system and storm sewer system.
            (3)   Read or cause to be read all water meters and shall see that
the City Collector receives the results of such readings so that he can cause
water bills to be sent to consumers.
            (4)   Read or cause to be read all sanitary sewer meters and shall
see that the City Collector receives the results of such readings so that he
can cause bills to be sent to consumers.
            (5)   Be responsible for seeing that all parts of the waterworks
system, sanitary sewer system and storm sewer system are kept in good repair,
free from obstructions and breaks. (Ord. 1885, 5-15-1997)
         b.   Inspections:
            (1)   The Director or his designee shall cause to be made periodic
visual outside and underground inspections of all properties within the City,
with specific attention to downspouts, roof drains and other visible outside
and/or underground connections and shall request the property owner to permit
entry into the premises for the making of additional inspection of the premises
to ascertain if illegal connections are present. Upon completion of the visual
inside, outside and underground inspections, the Director will advise the owner
of any such given property, in writing, of any illegal connections observed.
            (2)   In addition to the visual inside, outside and underground
inspections of the premises, the Director shall cause other lawful tests and
inspections of such building and property to be made as he deems necessary in
order to locate any illegal connections and sources of extraneous flows as may
exist.
            (3)   When corrections are made by such owner, at no additional
expense to said owner, the City will make further inspection of the corrections
to ensure compliance with this Code.
   B.   Employees Of Water And Wastewater Department: All officers or employees
assigned to the Water and Wastewater Department shall perform their duties
subject to the orders and under the supervision of the Director. (Ord. 1460, 7-
21-1988)
Sec. 7.202. Applications For Service; Deposit.
   A.   Application For Service: Applications for receiving service shall be
made in writing to the City Clerk and shall contain an agreement by which the
applicant shall abide by and accept all of the provisions of this article as
conditions governing the use of the City's water supply, waterworks system and/
or sanitary sewer system. The applicant shall indicate whether the occupant of
the premises to be served is an owner or tenant thereof, and the application
shall also contain the address of the title owner of record of the premises to
be served.
   B.   Deposit Requirements:
      1.   A deposit as specified in the master fee schedule shall be made with
each application for receiving service; said sum to be retained by the City to
ensure payment of all service bills.
      2.   When a final water or sewer meter reading is requested or upon
change of any given account, this deposit shall be refunded; provided, the
account has been paid in full.
      3.   In the event of a delinquency in any given account, this deposit
shall be applied toward payment of the delinquency as hereinafter provided.
   C.   Water Impact Fees:
      1.   Imposed: Any properties developed or constructed in the City shall
have imposed water impact fees representing the impact said construction will
have on the water system within the City.
      2.   Payment: Upon application for service, as provided for herein, the
owner or developer of said property shall pay to the City all water impact fees
provided for herein.
      3.   Fee Schedule: Fees shall be assessed as specified in the master fee
schedule.
      4.   Failure To Pay: No certificate of occupancy shall be issued to any
property owner or developer on any property on which the property owner or
developer fails to pay the water impact fees assessed. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-
2018)
Sec. 7.203. Changes Of Account.
Whenever a final water meter and/or sewer meter reading is requested or
whenever the owner of a premises indicates that there is to be a change in
occupancy, following such request, service shall be discontinued until the
account is formally changed upon application for service as provided in this
article. In the event of a change of occupancy of any building location without
such notice to the City, the new occupant shall be given a twenty (20) day
notice (within which to comply with the terms of section 7.821 of this chapter)
before service is terminated by the City. (Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988)
Sec. 7.204. Delinquencies In Payments Of Bills.
   A.   Determination Of Delinquency: In the event the charges for service or
service deposit are not paid within twenty one (21) days after rendition of the
bill for such service or service deposit, such charges shall be deemed and are
hereby declared to be delinquent.
   B.   Notice Of Delinquency: In the event the charges for such service or
service deposit become delinquent as defined hereinabove, the Finance Director
is hereby authorized and directed to cause notification to be given in writing
to the owner or owners of record of the premises and as indicated by the
taxpayer identification number and the occupants thereof that such delinquency
and violation exist.
      1.   Such notice shall state the amount of the charges that are
delinquent and the date on which they became delinquent. The notice shall also
state that the amount of delinquent charges will be increased by any charges
for attorney services, attorney fees, and court costs incurred in attempts to
collect the delinquent amount. Such notice shall additionally state that the
delinquent charges may create a lien on the premises.
      2.   Such notice shall also indicate that if such owner and/or occupant
has a complaint concerning an erroneous billing, within five (5) days from the
date of such notice such owner and/or occupant may contact the City Manager and
present such complaint to him, and that the City Manager may thereafter rectify
any error he may find to exist.
      3.   In the event user charges are not paid within twenty one (21) days
after billing, the account of such user will be deemed delinquent. Notice of
such delinquency shall be sent to such user by the City, providing the user an
additional twenty eight (28) days to become current. In the event said account
remains delinquent after such notice is given, a final notice is given, which
notice also contains a statement that service shall be terminated and
discontinued without further notice after seven (7) days from the date of such
notice thereof unless the delinquency and/or violation is rectified.
Discontinued service shall not be reinstated until all claims are settled.
Discontinued service shall be applicable to those residents whose balance is
one hundred dollars ($100.00) or higher. After receiving notice of delinquency,
the entire balance stated therein must be paid to avoid discontinuation of
service. Further, if the previous balance is not paid on time, a penalty as
specified in the master fee schedule is applied to the previous month’s
balance.
      Such notice shall additionally state that the delinquent charges may
create a lien on the premises.
      In the event service is terminated to a property the property shall be
promptly posted with a notice indicating it is “uninhabitable”. The fee for
such posting is as specified in the master fee schedule, and is payable to the
City at the time of payment for reinstatement of service.
   C.   Reinstatement Of Service; Fee: In the event any service has been
disconnected or terminated, a service charge as specified in the master fee
schedule shall be made for reinstating such service after settlement of the
current as well as the delinquent account, which service charge shall be in an
amount equal to no less than the City's actual costs for such reinstatement
based upon a rolling twelve (12) month period.
   D.   Lien For Water Charges: Whenever a water or sewer bill is deemed
delinquent as set forth in this section, in addition to all of the other
remedies and/or penalties available to the City and/or assessed against a user,
such bill, including charges for attorney services, attorney fees, and costs
incurred in attempts to collect the bill, shall represent and become a lien
upon the real estate upon or for which such water or sewer service is supplied.
The City Clerk shall file notice of such lien in the Office of the Recorder of
Deeds of DuPage County. This notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting
out a description of such real estate sufficient for the identification
thereof, the amount of money due for such water or sewer service, and the date
when such amount became delinquent. A copy of the notice as recorded shall be
sent to the owner or the owner of record of the premises as indicated by the
taxpayer identification number.
(Ord. O-09-004, 2-5-2009; amd. Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018; Ord. O-25-003, 1-16-
2025)
Sec. 7.205. Entry Powers.
It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse employees of the Water and
Wastewater Department access at all times to any premises, for the purpose of
ascertaining the number and type of water connections and the existence of the
building drain. (Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988)
Sec. 7.206. Violations.
   A.   A violation of any of the regulations contained in this article shall
be considered a nuisance. Such nuisance may be abated by an action instigated
by the Director or City Manager in the Circuit Court of DuPage County seeking
to stop the discharge either by a writ of mandamus or injunctive relief. If any
person discharges sewer, industrial wastes or other wastes into any waters of
the sewerage system under the jurisdiction of the City contrary to any statute,
ordinance or order of the City Council, the Director may commence an
appropriate action or proceeding in the Circuit Court for the purposes of
abating the discharge.
   B.   In addition, any person who is apprehended in the act of causing
physical damage to City property in violation of any of the provisions of this
article shall be taken before the Judge or Associate Judge of the Circuit Court
of the County and within the City wherein such offense occurred, and there
charged and prosecuted in the name of the people of the State of Illinois, 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/20-1.
   C.   Whenever the Director determines that sewage, industrial wastes or
other wastewater are being or have been discharged in violation of this article
into any waters of the storm sewer system under the jurisdiction of the City,
the Director, by conference, may endeavor to the fullest extent possible to
eliminate or remedy such violation, which violation is declared hereby to be a
nuisance. (Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988)
Sec. 7.207. Penalties.
Any person who commits a violation of this article by failing to comply with
any provision hereof or with an order of the Director or the City Manager
issued in pursuance of this article, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined
not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each day that such violation exists; and in addition thereto,
such person may be enjoined from continuing such violation. Each day upon which
the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. Any person
violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the City
for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the City by reason of such
violation. (Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988)
Sec. 7.208. Civil Damages.
   A.   The foregoing penalties and prosecutions therefor shall not be held or
construed as constituting a bar, release or waiver by the City to the
prosecution by the City for recovery of any civil damages it may sustain
because of any such violation, and where it shall appear that such violation
has occasioned damage to the appurtenances, machinery, equipment and/or
buildings of the City, a civil suit in the name of the City for damage to or
destruction of all or any part or parts thereof of its waterworks system,
sanitary sewer system and/or storm sewer system may be maintained by it
regardless of prosecution and collection of any other penalty for such
violation. In addition, court costs and attorney fees and other expenses of
litigation are recoverable by the City upon its suit as debts are recoverable
as part of such suit.
   B.   The City may elect to file a civil action in the Circuit Court of
DuPage County to recover the amount of such delinquency as well as its
reasonable attorney fees. A judgment thus obtained shall release any existing
lien for such services for the amount of such judgment and shall operate as a
waiver by the City of the right to obtain such a lien with respect to
delinquency. (Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988)

Sec. 7.301. Joint Waterworks System.
   A.   Purpose: It is necessary and for the best interests of the City that it
acquire and operate jointly with the DuPage Water Commission a common source of
supply of water in order that sufficient water for the use of Wood Dale and its
inhabitants for public and domestic purposes be available at all times and that
it acquire and operate jointly with the other municipalities being members of
the DuPage Water Commission a common source of supply, said method being the
most economical in acquiring a sufficient supply of water. (Ord. 1144, 4-16-
1981)
   B.   Participation In Joint Waterworks System: The City hereby determines
and elects jointly with the following units of local government (or such of
same which shall likewise elect):

   C.   Membership In DuPage Water Commission: As soon after the effective date

of the commission heretofore organized and known as the DuPage Water Commission
with the powers and duties as prescribed in said statute. (Ord. 1144, 4-16-
1981)

Sec. 7.302. Unlawful Water Turn On.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to provide any owner water from the
waterworks system by turning a valve in the buffalo box “on” or otherwise to
tamper with the buffalo box without the prior approval of or the prior issuance
of a permit therefor issued by the Director. If a person turns on, activates or
otherwise causes City water service to operate without authorization, or if a
water customer is receiving City water service that has not been authorized,
the City will promptly terminate water service and post a notice on the
property stating that the property is “uninhabitable.” Water service will not
be re-established until the applicable reinstatement fee and “uninhabitable”
posting fee, as specified in the master fee schedule, is paid, along with any
current and delinquent water services charges and any applicable penalties, as
provided for in Chapter 7 of this Code. Additionally, prior to reinstating
water service, the City has the right to seek and recover payment of any
applicable buffalo box repair or replacement costs and lock box repair or
replacement costs related to the property or water customer receiving the
unauthorized service.
(Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988; amd. Ord. O-25-003, 1-16-2025)
Sec. 7.303. Plumbing Standards.
No water service shall be afforded any premises unless the plumbing therein
complies with this Code 1 , except where service is authorized pursuant to the
issuance of a building permit subject to the provisions of this chapter. (Ord.
1460, 7-21-1988)
 
Notes
1 2. See chapter 12, articles III and IV of this Code.
Sec. 7.304. Water Service Connections.
   A.   General Permit Requirements: No connection to a main shall be made
without a permit issued by the Director. Applications for such permits shall be
made to the City Clerk. Any such permit issued pursuant to the terms of this
Code shall expire within sixty (60) days after issuance; provided, however,
that upon timely application by the permittee within the aforesaid sixty (60)
day period, the City Manager may extend such permit an additional ninety (90)
days.
   B.   Specific Tap-On Fee Connections: The City does not perform water
connections to new development for any resident or business on Irving Park
Road, Wood Dale Road, or Addison Road or for any service that needs to be
upsized due to remodeling. The fee will be waived on these projects. Further,
the City does not perform water connections to industrial or commercial
buildings.
   C.   Residential Connections: For any residential building, no connection
with a main shall be made unless a permit therefor has been issued by and such
connection is accomplished under the direction and supervision of the Director.
No water connection permit shall be issued without prior payment of the fee
provided hereunder:
      1.   A fee as specified in the master fee schedule shall be charged for
each single home or premises that is to be connected to a main.
   D.   Non-Residential Connections: A fee as specified in the master fee
schedule shall be charged for each non-residential structure that is to be
connected to a main.
   E.   Notice Of Connection; Supervision: No connection to a main shall be
made unless there has been twenty four (24) hours' notice to the Director. All
connections to an existing main shall be made under the direction and
supervision of the Director. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
Sec. 7.305. Water Meters.
   A.   Meters Required: All premises receiving service of water must be
equipped with an adequate water meter furnished by the City at the sole cost of
the consumer or owner.
   B.   Meter Costs: Upon their request for installation thereof, each owner
shall pay a fee as specified in the master fee schedule for a water meter
determined by the diameter of the water service line to the premises.
A ten percent (10%) administrative fee has been applied to the meter and
reading device fee. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
   C.   Location: All water meters shall be installed in a location on the
premises of the consumer easily accessible to employees of the Department of
Water and Wastewater.
   D.   Installation Of Meters: The water meter(s) and remote reader(s) are to
be installed by the owner's plumbing contractor. The water supply to the
premises may not be turned on until the water meter(s) and remote reader(s) are
installed. Each water meter shall be provided with two (2) threaded type
shutoff valves (gate type or ball valve) with full size apertures. One valve
shall be installed on the supply side and one valve on the house side of each
meter. The water meter(s) and service pipe shall be of sufficient size to
permit ample and continuous flow of water to provide adequate supply on all
floors at any given time. The Department of Water and Wastewater shall supply
and seal all water meters. In no case will anyone be allowed to remove or
replace any water meter or seals unless authorization is received from the
department.
   E.   Reading Meters: The Director shall read or cause to be read every water
meter used in the City at such times as are necessary that bills may be sent
out at the proper times.
Whenever a water meter is so located that it is not readily accessible to
reading by City officials or in the event any given consumer's water meter
cannot be read or inspected by reason of the failure of the owner or consumer
to allow access thereto for any given continuous period of six (6) months or
more, the Director is authorized hereby to install or cause to be installed
outside meters or "Read-o-Matic" or equal meters, and thereafter, the City
Collector shall bill said owner or consumer and said owner or consumer shall
pay the City for such meter and its installation within the next regular
billing period. (Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988)
   F.   Meter Tests; Fee: Upon request of any consumer, any City water meter
shall be taken out and tested by the City. If, upon testing, the meter is not
found to be accurate within three percent (3%), it shall be repaired by the
City. If such meter is found to be accurate within three percent (3%), a fee as
specified in the master fee schedule shall be charged to the consumer
requesting the test and will be added to their next utility bill. (Ord. O-18-
024, 7-19-2018)
   G.   Access Powers: The City and its employees shall have ready access to
the premises, place or building where water is supplied for the purpose of
examining and testing the consumption, use and flow of water, and it shall be
unlawful for any person or corporation to interfere with, prevent or obstruct
the City or its duly authorized agent in its duties herein. (Ord. 1460, 7-21-
1988)
Sec. 7.306. Water Service Lines.
   A.   Installation Requirements:
      1.   All water service lines from mains to premises served shall be
installed by and at the cost of the owner of the property to be served or the
applicant for the water service. Such installation shall be under the
supervision of the Director and be made after twenty four (24) hours' notice to
him.
      2.   No water service lines shall be installed unless they conform to the
Building and Plumbing Codes 1 , any other applicable rules and regulations of
the City and the following requirements:
         a.   Minimum diameter service water line size to any building shall be
one inch (1").
         b.   All water service line piping shall be "K" grade copper tubing or
ductile iron water main, Class 52, cement lined, push type.
         c.   "K" grade copper tubing shall be flared joint and/or threaded on
all pipes and fittings. The use of soldered fittings shall not be permitted
before the meter.
         d.   Corporation stops shall be tapped at or near the top of the water
main. Double strap service saddles shall be used unless otherwise approved by
the Director.
         e.   The water service line pipe and connections must be inspected and
pressure tested prior to backfilling. (Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988)
         f.   Water service lines shall be laid at a minimum depth of forty
eight inches (48"). (Ord. O-16-001, 2-4-2016)
         g.   It shall be unlawful to excavate for or begin work on the
installation or repair of any water pipe before a written permit for such work
is obtained.
      3.   The location of all water service lines shall conform to the
following requirements:
         a.   The approximate alignment of the water pipe between the buffalo
box and the main shall be perpendicular to the main and the position of the
"off" position of the valve in the buffalo box should be perpendicular to the
alignment of the water service line.
         b.   The water service line shall be located within the boundaries of
the premises served or on an easement recorded for such purpose.
         c.   There shall be maintained a horizontal separation of ten feet
(10') between any water service line pipe and any sanitary sewer service line.
In the event a water service line is laid in the same trench with the sanitary
sewer service line, the water service line shall be located on a ledge (shelf)
not less than eighteen inches (18") above the sanitary sewer service line and
not less than four feet (4') below finished grade level.
   B.   Buffalo Boxes: A Minneapolis buffalo box and valve must be installed on
every water service line and shall be located within the dedicated public
right-of-way or dedicated City easement (as the case may be) between the curb
line or gutter of the street pavement and any public sidewalk. Such buffalo box
shall be located so that it is easily accessible, and the valves located
therein shall be protected from frost. (Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988)
   C.   Inspections Fees: An inspection fee as specified in the master fee
schedule shall be paid to the City Collector at the time the application is
filed. This inspection fee is in addition to the tap-on fee and in addition to
user charges, the provisions of which are detailed in other sections of this
article. An additional fee as specified in the master fee schedule will be
charged for all inspections required other than during the regular forty (40)
hour workweek and for each additional inspection in excess of one inspection.
Excavation for any of the above purposes shall require a separate permit,
pursuant to the Building Code of the City. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
   D.   Repairs: All repairs for water service lines shall be made by and at
the expense of the owners of the premises served. In the case of an emergency,
the City may repair any water service lines and charge the cost of such repair
work to the owner of the premises served.
   E.   Excavations: All excavations for installing or repairing water service
lines shall comply with the provisions of this Code regulating excavation 2 .
(Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 12, articles III and IV of this Code.
2 1. See chapter 6, article XII of this Code.
Sec. 7.307. Water Use Restrictions.
   A.   Unauthorized Use Of Fire Hydrant: Exclusive of firefighting and
Department of Water and Wastewater personnel, it shall be unlawful at any time
for any person to take any water from any fire hydrant without proper
authority.
   B.   Lawn And Garden Sprinkling: It shall be unlawful for any person to use
or any owner to allow the use of any water, whether drawn directly or
indirectly, from the waterworks system for the purpose of watering and/or
sprinkling lawns and/or gardens, except as provided hereinbelow:
      1.   All such watering and/or sprinkling at residential, business and/or
industrial locations with even numbered addresses shall be accomplished only
between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M.
and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on days with even
numbered dates.
      2.   All such watering and/or sprinkling at residential, business and/or
industrial locations with odd numbered addresses shall be accomplished only
between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M.
and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on days with odd
numbered dates.
      3.   Newly sodded areas of lawns or newly planted shrubbery may be
watered by special permit issued by the Director, pursuant to the regulations
contained hereinbelow:
         a.   The applicant for such special permit shall make application in
duplicate on forms provided by the Director, which form shall require the
following information:
            (1)   The name of the applicant;
            (2)   Whether the applicant is an individual, copartnership or
corporation;
            (3)   The residence and/or business address of the applicant;
            (4)   The place (address) where the newly sodded area is located;
            (5)   The consecutive dates (not exceeding 15 days) for which the
permit is being requested.
         b.   Upon completion of the application forms and filing same with the
Director, the applicant shall pay a special permit fee in the amount as
specified in the master fee schedule per lot of record.
         c.   Upon receipt of any such special permit application, the Director
shall forward the application to the City Collector who shall collect payment
of the proper fee and thereafter issue a special permit to sprinkle lawns to
the applicant. Such permit shall allow the permittee unlimited sprinkling
privileges for fifteen (15) consecutive days, commencing with the date of
issuance, the dates of which shall be shown thereon. The permit shall be posted
in clear view at the location for which such special permit was issued. The
permit may be renewed once but shall not thereafter be renewed and may not
thereafter be reapplied for. The fee for such renewal shall be as specified in
the master fee schedule. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
   C.   Filling Swimming Pools: The filling of swimming pools shall be
accomplished in accordance with the regulations contained in this Code.
   D.   Authority To Ban Water Use: Upon recommendation of the Director, the
City Manager shall have the authority to place a complete ban on filling and/or
refilling swimming pools or sprinkling lawns and/or gardens or for the purpose
of washing vehicles at any time the City water supply is in danger because of
overusage, pump failure, well failure or failure of any part of the waterworks
system and/or the City's potable water supply. In such emergency, such ban
shall become effective immediately upon order of the City Manager, as the case
may be.
   E.   Cross Connections 1 : Only potable water shall be accessible to
plumbing fixtures which are located in buildings or which supply water for
drinking, bathing, culinary use or the processing of food, medical or
pharmaceutical products. A potable water supply system shall be designed,
installed and maintained in all buildings in such manner as to prevent
contamination from nonpotable liquids, solids or gases from being introduced
into the waterworks system through cross connections or any other piping
connections to the waterworks system.
   F.   Resale Of Water: Except in the case of an emergency, it shall be
unlawful for any person to resell or distribute water to any premises located
within or without the corporate limits of the City. (Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988)
 
Notes
1 1. See article V of this chapter.
Sec. 7.308. Water Rates.
   A.   Monthly Rates; Additional Charge: All users of water supplied by the
City having a direct or indirect connection with City water mains shall pay a
monthly bill per account consisting of a fixed fee and a variable usage fee as
specified in the master fee schedule.
   B.   Bills Payable: All bills for service shall be rendered as of the first
day of each month succeeding the period for which service is billed and shall
be payable upon receipt and not later than the close of business of the twenty
first day after billing. Bills paid after the due date shall be subject to a
penalty as specified in the master fee schedule. In the event an estimated bill
is rendered, the bill for water usage shall be based on the usage history of
the account during the previous twelve (12) billing periods. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-
19-2018)
   C.   Rate Discount While Filling Swimming Pool:
      1.   A residential user shall be entitled to a reduction of sewer rates
by the amount of water used annually for the first seasonal filling of his
swimming pool if:
         a.   He can prove that a permit for a pool was obtained when the pool
was constructed, if such was required.
         b.   He requests the reduction in writing.
         c.   Such user shall have installed a separate water meter to measure
the water flow of the supply line to his swimming pool and, provided further,
the meter has been read by a representative of the City before and after the
filling of the pool.
         d.   He signs an affidavit indicating that the representations that he
makes at the time of the application for discount are true and accurate.
      2.   Such discount shall never reduce the bill below an amount calculated
by using the water consumption at the location for the same billing period of
the previous year.
      3.   The residential user requesting such a reduction shall present the
required information at the Office of the Finance Director at City Hall. The
reduction shall be allowed following the computation of the number of gallons
used to fill the swimming pool.
      4.   The discount shall be disallowed if the swimming pool is illegally
connected to the City sewerage system. (Ord. 1764, 10-6-1994)
   D.   Application And Provisions For Rate Reduction: Upon written application
from any residents whose household income is not more than the very low income
figures established by the income eligibility rates, published by the United
States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), effective July 1,
1979, and as currently revised, as verified by the resident's previous year's
U.S. Federal Income Tax return, the City Collector shall authorize a rate
reduction as specified in the master fee schedule; provided, however, that such
persons are also:
      1.   Heads of households entitled to and receiving benefits under the
Social Security Act or benefits under other pension plans and are at least
sixty two (62) years of age; or
      2.   Widowers or widows having dependent children; or
      3.   Totally disabled; or
      4.   United States military veterans.
Proof of eligibility shall be submitted annually thereafter to said City
Collector. Said rate reduction shall not result in a credit to any user's
account. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
Sec. 7.309. Prohibited Acts And Conditions.
   A.   Tampering With Waterworks System Or Water Meter: It shall be unlawful
for any person not authorized by the City to tamper with, alter or injure any
part of the City's waterworks system or any water meter. (Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988)
   B.   Obstructing Fire Hydrants: It shall be unlawful for any person under
his direction and control to cover, hide, obscure or bury by the piling of snow
or other debris any fire hydrant.
Any person violating this subsection shall be fined an amount as specified in
the master fee schedule for each offense. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
Sec. 7.310. Private Water Supply 1 .
New private water wells are not permitted within the City. Existing wells shall
be governed by this section.
   A.   Well Site:
      1.   The well site shall have good surface drainage and be higher than
surrounding sources of pollution such as privies, cesspools, septic tanks and
sewers.
      2.   No well shall be located within fifty feet (50') of the centerline
of any public road or utility or drainage easement when an alternate location
is practical.
      3.   Any well located in a basement offset shall be at least five feet
(5') outside the foundation line.
      4.   Each single-family residence shall have its own separate well on the
lot whereon it is located, except where such single-family residence is
connected to and using a public water supply as defined in 415 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 40/1.
      5.   Sealing and abandonment of wells is to be done within thirty (30)
days after a building is connected to the City's water supply system.
   B.   Minimum Distances From Sources Of Pollution:
      1.   Minimum distance from wells or suction lines to sources of pollution
shall be as follows:
 
a. There shall be no sewers or drains of any kind within 10 feet of
   any well
   Extra heavy cast iron sewers with leaded joints encased in sleeves
b. filled with asphalt or other approved jointing material and tested 10 feet
   for leakage
c. Cast iron sewers with leaded joints                                25 feet
   Vitrified clay, concrete, asbestos-cement or bituminous sewers or
d. drains with sealed joints; monolithic concrete or steel septic     50 feet
   tanks, grease traps, catch basins or privy vaults; open sand
   filters
   Subsurface seepage fields, stables, barnyards, manure piles;
e. masonry septic tanks, grease traps or catch basins; streams, ponds 75 feet
   or lakes
f. Privy pits or seepage pits                                         100 feet
g. Cesspools                                                          150 feet
 
   C.   Maintenance Of Private Water Supply: Every water well shall be
maintained in a safe condition by the owner.
   D.   Abandonment Of Use:
      1.   Private wells may not be maintained for any use after a hookup to
the City's water supply system.
      2.   Sealing and abandonment of wells is to be done within thirty (30)
days after a building is connected to the City's water supply system.
      3.   Every abandoned well shall be filled and sealed in accordance with
the recommendations of the State Geological Survey, Urbana, Illinois, in
accordance with the requirements of the DuPage County Health Department and in
accordance with the State of Illinois Department of Mines and Minerals, rule
X1-A, "sealing of abandoned water wells".
      4.   The owner shall supply a copy of a well sealing certificate signed
by a certified well driller to the City certifying that the private well has
been sealed in compliance with the standards adopted by the DuPage County
Health Department. (Ord. 1460, 7-21-1988; amd. 1993 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section 7.103 of this chapter.

Part 7.40. General Provisions
Sec. 7.401. Enactment.
Pursuant to the requirements of the federal clean water act, 33 USC section
1251 et seq., and regulations promulgated thereunder; the (Illinois)
environmental protection act, 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1 et seq.; and
the Illinois municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-1-1 et seq.,
this chapter is hereby passed and approved by the mayor and city council of the
city of Wood Dale, Illinois, and duly published in accordance with law, and
shall be known and may be cited as the SEWER USE AND PRETREATMENT RULES AND
REGULATIONS. (Ord. O-15-001, 1-15-2015)
Sec. 7.402. Purpose And Policy.
This chapter sets forth uniform requirements for users of the POTW for the
city. Specifically, in this regard, it provides for the use of private and
public sewers and drains and private sewage disposal, and authorizes the
installation and continuing of connections into the sewage works of the city
upon certain conditions, including permission thereof; provides for the
installation and maintenance of such connections and enforcement thereof;
regulates the use of municipal and private sewers and drains, individual
wastewater disposal and the installation, connection and disconnection of
building sewers, the discharge of water and waste in the public sewer system
and provides for penalties for violation thereof; and provides for termination
of permits issued by the city pursuant to the provisions hereof.
This chapter enables the city to comply with all applicable state and federal
laws, including the clean water act. Additional objectives of this chapter are:
   A.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW that will
interfere with its operation;
   B.   To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the POTW that will pass
through the POTW, inadequately treated, into receiving waters, or otherwise be
incompatible with the POTW;
   C.   To protect both POTW personnel who may be affected by air, wastewater
and sludge in the course of their employment and the general public;
   D.   To promote reuse and recycling of industrial wastewater and sludge from
the POTW;
   E.   To enable the city to comply with its national pollutant discharge
elimination system permit conditions, sludge use and disposal requirements, and
any other federal or state laws to which the POTW is subject;
   F.   To provide for fees for the equitable distribution of the cost of
operation, maintenance, and improvement of the POTW;
   G.   To provide uniform requirements for food service establishments for the
control of grease discharge to the sanitary sewer system; and
   H.   To regulate private wastewater disposal systems.
This chapter shall apply to all users of the POTW and provides for the
enforcement of general requirements for users. This chapter authorizes the
issuance of wastewater connection and discharge permits; provides for
monitoring, compliance, and enforcement activities; establishes administrative
review procedures; requires user reporting; and provides for the setting of
fees for the equitable distribution of costs resulting from the programs
established herein. (Ord. O-15-001, 1-15-2015)
Sec. 7.403. Administration.
Except as otherwise provided herein, the pretreatment coordinator and/or duly
authorized agent(s) shall administer, implement, and enforce the provisions of
this chapter. Any powers granted to or duties imposed upon the pretreatment
coordinator and/or duly authorized agent(s) may be delegated by the city or
pretreatment coordinator to other city personnel or other duly authorized agent
(s) of the city.
It shall be the duty of employees of the city departments of police and
community development and planning to give vigilant aid to the department of
public works in the enforcement of this chapter and to this end they shall
report all violations thereof, which come to their knowledge, to the director
of public works. (Ord. O-15-001, 1-15-2015)
Sec. 7.404. Jurisdiction.
This chapter shall apply to the city and to persons outside the city who are,
by contract or agreement with the city, users of the city POTW. (Ord. O-15-001,
1-15-2015)
Sec. 7.405. Relationship To Other Articles In This Chapter.
All references to the sections are to sections of articles in this chapter
unless otherwise specified. The definitions and abbreviations in article I of
this chapter shall apply to this article. Local limits referenced in this
article are identified in article VI of this chapter. User charge and surcharge
provisions for wastewater are in article VII of this chapter. Provisions for
fees are identified in each article above while the actual fee can be found in
article VIII of this chapter. Enforcement options for the provisions of the
above articles are found in article IX of this chapter. (Ord. O-15-001, 1-15-
2015)
Part 7.41. Sewer Extension Requirements
Sec. 7.411. Applicability.
The extension of a sanitary sewer by any entity that will serve or in the
future may serve more than one building and that will connect either directly
or indirectly to the sewage works of the city shall be made only after an
application for a city permit has been made in writing on forms prescribed and
furnished by the city and an extension permit is issued by the city. (Ord. O-
15-001, 1-15-2015)
Sec. 7.412. Sewer Extension Requirements.
   A.   Application: Persons desiring such extension of the sewer system shall
file with the city four (4) copies of the following documents:
      1.   Detailed plans and specifications prepared by a professional
engineer registered in the state of Illinois.
      2.   IEPA permit application with such supporting documents required by
the IEPA, completely filled out and ready for city execution.
      3.   Detailed estimate of the cost of the extension.
The person or persons extending the sewer shall pay all costs of plan review to
the city prior to the city signing the IEPA permit application.
   B.   Issuance: The city will issue an extension permit in accordance with
the following:
      1.   It has been demonstrated that the downstream treatment works,
including city sewers and pump stations, have sufficient reserve capacity to
adequately and efficiently handle the additional anticipated waste load.
      2.   A permit has been issued by the Illinois environmental protection
agency. The city permit shall expire on the expiration date of the Illinois
environmental protection agency permit. Those portions of the work for which a
city permit has been issued and the work has been approved by the city shall be
completed within the permit time. Future construction on the project for which
the original permit was issued shall require a new permit that will be issued
in compliance with this code at the time of the application for the new permit.
All fees and charges assessed under the conditions of the city permit are
forfeited by the applicant/owner upon the expiration of the permit.
      3.   The city has received an agreement and bond executed by the
permittee wherein he or she agrees to make and install the improvements in
accordance with plans and specifications identifying a completion date not more
than six (6) months after the date of the agreement, unless the city council
determines, on the basis of the recommendation of the city engineer (CE), that
a longer time is necessary.
The guarantee for completion of the improvements by the permittee shall be in
the principal amount of one hundred ten percent (110%) of the estimated cost as
approved by the CE and secured by either:
         a.   A letter of credit from an escrow account at a federally insured
bank or savings and loan association subject to draw by the city to complete
the improvements if it is not completed within the prescribed time limit.
         b.   A clean, nondeclining, irrevocable letter of credit issued by a
federally insured bank or savings and loan association. The letter shall be
approved by the city and provide that funds may be drawn only by the city.
         c.   A surety bond in a form and from an institution acceptable to the
city administrator.
The bond shall remain in effect for a period of one year after acceptance of
the work by the CE as a guarantee of good faith of the permittee to correct
defects. At the discretion of the city council, the bond may be reduced during
the maintenance period.
      4.   The city has received copies of all permits, insurance and bonds
required for street openings or stream crossings and any other permits required
by an agency having jurisdiction.
      5.   The city has received certificates of insurance protecting the city
from any liability or damage whatsoever from injury, including death, to any
person or property. The amount of the insurance and coinsurance shall be as
recommended by the city insurance carrier used by the city council.
      6.   The city has received payment for the cost of the permit and the
estimated cost of inspection. The cost of inspection shall include resident
supervision if deemed necessary by the CE. The estimated cost of inspection,
approved by the CE, shall be deposited with the city treasurer prior to the
start of work and additional funds added during the work if required. The
permittee, however, shall pay only the actual costs of such services based on
standard engineering fees. At the completion of the work any unused portion of
the amount deposited shall be returned. No interest shall be paid on deposited
funds.
   C.   Construction Requirements:
      1.   The rules, regulations, chapters and policies listed hereafter and
issued by the authorities indicated are incorporated herein by reference and
shall govern the work so far as they apply to said work.
      2.   The city's rules, regulations, resolutions, policies, directives and
instructions that may be adopted or issued from time to time by the city,
including, but not limited to:
         a.   "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Main Construction In
Illinois", latest edition.
         b.   The Illinois environmental protection agency's rules,
regulations, technical releases and requirements.
         c.   "The Illinois Recommended Standards For Sewage Works", IEPA,
latest edition.
         d.   The state of Illinois plumbing code (latest edition).
         e.   "Federal Manual Of Practice No. 9", Water Pollution Control
Federation, latest edition.
      3.   The permittee agrees that they shall provide adequate inspection
during the entire construction period which, at the option of the city, may
require a full time resident engineer. The city reserves the right to review
the construction.
      4.   Changes in the work to be done or materials to be used from those
shown on the plans or set forth in the specifications, as submitted to the
city, shall be approved in writing by the CE prior to the changed work being
done or the changed materials being installed.
      5.   The contractor or the contractor's representative constructing the
sewer extension shall notify the city two (2) city business days prior to
commencing construction. When the construction of the sewer extension is
interrupted for a period of seven (7) calendar days or more, the city shall be
notified two (2) city business days prior to continuing construction of the
sewer extension.
      6.   At the time a sewer extension is connected to an existing sewer, the
connection shall be made at an existing manhole or in a manhole constructed
over the existing sewer. If an existing manhole is the point of connection and
a suitable stub is not provided for the extension, the existing manhole shall
be core drilled and a suitable connection stub installed. The sewer extension
shall be plugged with a watertight concrete plug by the contractor at the time
the connection to the existing sewer is made. The plug shall be maintained in
place at all times until the sewer extension is approved in writing by the CE.
If the plug is not maintained in place, the city shall install a concrete plug
and charge a fee to the contractor for each time a plug is installed by the
city. The fee for a plug is established annually by the department of public
works and is published in article VIII of this chapter. Mechanical plugs are
also an acceptable means of plugging the sewer to maintain it out of service.
The charge for installation of a plug in the sewer is published in article VIII
of this chapter, and will also include the cost of materials.
      7.   Upon completion of construction, the contractor shall notify the CE
requesting final review of the work. The contractor shall televise the
completed extension in the presence of a city staff who will take immediate
possession of the videotape prior to leaving the site. The city shall review
the work for conformance with the city's requirements and adherence to the
approved plans and specifications for which the city's sewer extension permit
was issued. If deficiencies are found in the work, the city shall furnish the
contractor with a listing of such deficiencies. When the contractor believes
that the deficiencies have been corrected, the contractor shall request a re-
review of the work. Should the re-review of the work show that the deficiencies
as set forth have not been corrected, the contractor shall make the necessary
corrections, and subsequent to that, shall notify the city and request another
review. The city shall charge a fee for each additional review and/or
inspection after the first inspection following the issuance of the list of
deficiencies. The fee for each additional review and/or inspection is published
as part of article VIII of this chapter.
      8.   All sanitary sewer mains shall be constructed in the center of the
street or roadway unless approved by the department of community development
and planning and public works or within public rights of way or within
easements dedicated for public utilities. No sanitary sewer mains shall be
installed in the rear or side yard of any property unless first approved by the
CE.
      9.   Minimum sanitary sewer main size shall be eight inch (8") diameter
for public sewer mains for sewer mains serving more than one building.
      10.   Manholes shall be precast reinforced concrete sections meeting ASTM
C-478 and ASTM C-443 standards. Manholes for sanitary sewers twenty four inches
(24") or less in diameter shall have a minimum inside diameter of forty eight
inches (48"). Manholes for sanitary sewers greater than twenty four inches
(24") in diameter shall have a minimum inside diameter of sixty inches (60")
and be spaced at a maximum of three hundred twenty five feet (325').
Additionally, manholes shall be installed under the following conditions:
termination of existing and future lines, changes in direction (horizontal or
vertical), changes in pipe shape or pipe size, or junctions with other sewers.
Drop manholes shall be provided for manholes with any pipe having a difference
in invert elevation more than twenty four inches (24") above the invert of the
sewer leaving the manholes. All drop manholes shall be of the external type. No
internal drop manhole connections will be allowed.
   D.   Project Completion: No connection permits shall be issued or building
permits released until such time that final approval of the improvement has
been made in writing by the CE. Final approval is contingent upon the
following:
      1.   All punch list work has been completed;
      2.   As built plans prepared by a registered Illinois professional
engineer are furnished to and are approved by the city. No grandfather clause
for existing uses is granted or intended;
      3.   The sewer has been televised by the contractor or by the permittee
in the presence of city personnel per the requirements identified in section
7.413 of this article; and
      4.   A video record of the television inspection has been provided to the
city. In addition to a video record, air exfiltration testing as outlined in
division III, section 31-1.11, of the "Standard Specifications For Water And
Sewer Main Construction In Illinois", will be completed prior to acceptance.
      5.   All additional charges levied by the city have been paid.
   E.   Connections To Extension: Also, no connection shall be made to the
sanitary sewer until sewer connection permits have been issued by the city
under part
7.42 of this article.
   F.   Performance Bond Release: The performance bond will not be released
until the guarantee period has expired and the following documents are filed
with the city clerk and approved by the city council:
      1.   As built drawings: One reproducible set and two (2) sets of prints;
      2.   Video record of television inspection;
      3.   Release of all permits;
      4.   Copies of all tests required by the city engineer;
      5.   Bill of sale for all constructed public improvements; and
      6.   Such other documents as may be reasonably requested by the city.
(Ord. O-15-001, 1-15-2015)
Sec. 7.413. New Trunk Lines.
In addition to all other requirements of all the ordinances of the city
pertaining to the installation and construction of sanitary sewers, the
following tests and criteria are hereby established to be complied with prior
to any acceptance of any new trunk line construction in the city after February
6, 1975. (Said tests and criteria pertain to any trunk line installed to
service or extend the present sanitary sewer system.)
   A.   All construction must have been installed in accordance with approved
plans and specifications as prescribed by the city and all workmanship must
have been performed in a satisfactory manner.
   B.   Infiltration shall not exceed two hundred (200) gallons per mile, per
one inch (1") in diameter of pipe, per twenty four (24) hour day. Infiltration
tests shall be performed under the supervision of the CE.
   C.   Completed installations must be televised by closed circuit television,
such televising to be performed by a reputable approved company proficient in
providing said service at a time to be established by the CE.
All costs and expenses relating to said closed circuit televising shall be
borne at the expense of the owner, developer or contractor, and said televising
tests shall be conducted in the presence of the CE or a duly authorized
representative appointed by him. Findings of the closed circuit television
tests shall be approved or rejected by the CE or his authorized representative.
In the event the CE does not approve the results of the closed circuit
televising of the trunk lines, then ownership of said trunk lines shall not be
accepted by the city and no such trunk line shall be connected to an
interceptor and/or a treatment works.
Nothing hereinabove shall preclude the contractor from utilizing city work
crews and city equipment to satisfy the regulations of this section, provided
that the contractor shall reimburse the city for its out of pocket, labor and
equipment costs in undertaking such televising. (Ord. O-15-001, 1-15-2015)
Part 7.42. Sewer Connection Procedures
Sec. 7.421. Use Of Public Sewers Required.
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to place or deposit, or allow to be
placed or deposited, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other
objectionable waste in any unsanitary manner on public or private property
within the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the
city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of said city, without the expressed
approval from the director of public works (DPW) that all slug load and federal
effluent limitations have been met and that there are no reasonable alternative
methods of disposal.
   C.   Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or
maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility
intended or used for the private disposal of sewage.
   D.   The owner of any house, building or property used for human occupancy,
employment, recreation or other purpose that requires the installation of
sanitary facilities situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley
or right of way, in which there is now located or may in the future be located
any public sanitary sewer of the city, is hereby required at his expense to
install suitable facilities therein, including toilets and/or urinals, lavatory
sinks and kitchen sinks, and to connect such facilities directly with the
proper public sanitary sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article,
within ninety (90) calendar days after the adoption of and publication of this
article, or upon installation or extension of such public sanitary sewer and
after date of official notice to connect, provided that said public sanitary
sewer is within two hundred feet (200'), or sixty one meters (61m), of the
property line. If such public sanitary sewer benefits other properties, the
city shall enact a recapture article and make best efforts to collect and
return to the owner amounts received from the benefited properties. All public
sanitary sewer extensions shall be made in accordance with part
7.41 of this article.
      1.   Failure to install such facilities and to connect same to the public
sanitary sewer within ninety (90) calendar days after the adoption of and
publication of this article, or upon installation or extension of such public
sanitary sewer and after the date of official notice to connect, shall be
deemed, held and construed as a violation of this provision, punishable as
provided in article IX of this chapter.
      2.   Application for a permit to make a connection to the public sanitary
sewer shall be made by the owner within ninety (90) calendar days of the
adoption of and publication of this article, or upon installation or extension
of such public sanitary sewer and after date of official notice to connect, as
the case may be as provided by section
7.423 of this article.
      3.   In the event of failure upon the part of the owner to make the
described connection within ninety (90) calendar days of the adoption of and
publication of this article, or upon installation or extension of such public
sanitary sewer and after date of official notice to connect, if it shall appear
that such delay is not wilful upon the part of the owner, an official notice in
writing by the city shall be given to the owner to make such connection, served
personally or by certified mail. If the owner fails, neglects and refuses to
make the connection within thirty (30) days of the date of this notice, he
shall be held and deemed to be in violation of this provision, and punishable
as provided in article IX of this chapter.
   E.   It shall be unlawful to discharge or cause to be discharged to any
facility served by the city, without having first complied with the terms of
this article. At minimum, all nonresidential users are subject to the
prohibited discharge standards in section
7.442 of this article, change notification in section
7.486 of this article and hazardous waste notification in section
7.489 of this article, if applicable. Spill prevention/slug control planning
may also be necessary for some nonresidential users as identified in section
7.455 of this article.
   F.   No user(s) shall make connection of roof downspouts, stormwater sump
pumps, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface
runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain that is connected
directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.
   G.   Inspection required upon transfer of property. Upon transfer of title
to, or transfer or assignment of beneficial interest in, real property located
in the city, inspection of such property shall be required to verify compliance
with part
7.41 of this article. It shall be unlawful for any person to occupy said
property subsequent to said transfer or assignment until the inspection
required herein shall be performed. If after inspection by the building
official or any of his authorized agents the property is determined to be in
compliance with part
7.41 of this article, the city clerk shall issue, without fee, a certificate to
the owner of said property.
   H.   The city of Wood Dale, and specifically the public works department,
shall not be held responsible for damages to personal property caused by the
construction or repair to the city sewers by water or sewage seepage or for any
other reason. (Ord. O-15-001, 1-15-2015)
Sec. 7.422. Private Sewage Disposal.
No person shall construct a wastewater treatment facility within the corporate
limits of the city or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city for the
purpose of treating wastewater and discharging same to a watercourse unless the
following provisions are met:
   A.   Inadequate Capacity: For the purpose of treating nonresidential source
wastes, the city engineer (CE) determines that the wastewater treatment
facilities have inadequate capacity, and issues a permit for the construction
and operation of a wastewater treatment facility. No city permit shall become
effective until:
      1.   The CE has approved the plans and specifications in writing,
      2.   Approval has been obtained from the DuPage County department of
health, as appropriate,
      3.   An IEPA permit issued to construct the facility has been received,
      4.   An IEPA NPDES permit to operate the facility has been issued and
received,
      5.   The installation is completed to the satisfaction of the CE, and
      6.   The final inspection has been completed.
Persons operating a wastewater treatment facility shall file copies of all
operating reports sent to the USEPA and IEPA with the CE and such other reports
as the CE deems necessary.
   B.   Public Sanitary Sewer Not Available: Where a public sanitary sewer is
not available under the provisions of section
7.421 of this article, and the wastewater source to be treated is domestic in
nature, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal
system employing subsurface absorption facilities.
No person shall construct a private wastewater treatment facility with
subsurface disposal without previous approval from the CE. If approval is given
the person must adhere to the following limitations:
      1.   Permit Requirements:
         a.   Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal
system the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the CE. The
application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city which
the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications and other
information as deemed necessary by the city. A permit and inspection fee as
published in article VIII of this chapter, or reimbursement of costs shall be
paid to the city at the time the application is filed. The permit shall not be
issued until applicable state and county permits are on file.
         b.   The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private sewage
disposal system shall comply with all regulations and provisions of the state
of Illinois private sewage disposal licensing act and code, with the state of
Illinois environmental protection agency and the DuPage County health
department, as appropriate latest revision. No permit shall be issued for any
private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities
where the area of the lot is less than forty thousand (40,000) square feet. No
septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet.
         c.   A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become
effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the city.
The city shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of construction and,
in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the city when the work
is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered.
The inspection shall be made within two (2) city business days of the receipt
of written notice by the city, except that no inspections will be made at any
time other than regular city working hours.
   C.   Gravity And Conventional Sewer Systems Impractical: Where development
is possible but gravity sewers and conventional sewer systems are not
practical.
Accordingly, it is the policy of the city to approve grinder pump systems on a
discretionary case by case basis. In order to implement a grinder pump system,
a developer or individual homeowner must prove to the city that a grinder pump
system is the only viable option other than a conventional sanitary sewer
system. A permit and inspection fee as published in article VIII of this
chapter shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. A
permit for a private wastewater treatment facility employing a grinder pump
system shall not be issued until the design and installation is completed to
the satisfaction of the city.
      1.   Installation: The city shall be allowed to inspect the work at any
stage of the construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall
notify the building official when the grinder pump system is ready for final
inspection, and before any underground portions are covered.
      2.   Operation And Maintenance: The building official shall be entitled
to inspect the grinder pump system if the building official has any reason to
believe that the grinder pump system is not operating properly or pursuant to a
routine inspection protocol used by the building and code enforcement division
of the city. Should the grinder pump system fall into disrepair or otherwise
need maintenance as determined by the city, and the owner refuses to repair,
replace or otherwise fix the grinder pump system to the specifications of the
city, the city may do so at its own expense and obtain reimbursement from the
individual owner. In that regard, and as a condition of obtaining a city permit
for a grinder pump system, the individual owner shall enter into a contractual
agreement indemnifying the city for any costs the city may incur and holding
the city harmless with regard to maintaining the grinder pump system, and
further allow the city reasonable access to the grinder pump system for
inspection purposes.
   D.   Other Provisions:
      1.   The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal
facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, and at no expense to the city.
      2.   As provided in subsection B of this section, at such time as a
public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage
disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sanitary sewer
within ninety (90) calendar days in compliance with this chapter. Any septic
tanks, cesspools and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be
cleaned of sludge within ninety (90) calendar days and filled with suitable
material such as clean bank run gravel or dirt compacted and thereafter
maintained in a safe condition.
      3.   No statement contained in this section shall be construed to
interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the DuPage
County health department as appropriate. (Ord. O-15-001, 1-15-2015)
Sec. 7.423. Building Sewer And Connections.
   A.   Permit Requirements: No person shall construct a new wastewater source
or alter, repair or reconstruct an existing source and connect same to the
wastewater facilities of the city without first making application for the
privilege of making said connection to the city.
      1.   No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with, or
open into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof
without first obtaining a written permit from the building and code enforcement
division of the city, with sign off by the wastewater operations supervisor,
wastewater division (WWOS) and receipt of an IEPA permit when required under 35
IAC 309.
      2.   No addition to or alteration of any building sewer shall be made or
caused to be made by any person without a permit from the building official and
then only through a duly licensed sewer contractor. No permit shall authorize
anything not explicitly stated in the application.
      3.   No person(s) shall make connection of roof downspouts, stormwater
sump pump, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of
surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain that is
connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. Any violation of
this section after article adoption shall subject the violator to fines as
designated per article VIII of this chapter. Each successive day (24 hour
period) shall be considered a separate violation.
      4.   All disposal by any person into the sanitary sewer system is
unlawful, except those discharges in compliance with federal standards
promulgated pursuant to the federal act, the Illinois environmental protection
act and regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, and this code.
      5.   There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits consisting
of one residential wastewater class and one nonresidential wastewater class as
designated below:
         a.   Residential, and
         b.   Nonresidential, which includes institutional, or commercial and
industrial users, and other nonresidential sources of waste.
For either class, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special
form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any
plans, specifications, or other information considered pertinent in the
judgment of the building official and the WWOS. A permit and inspection fee as
defined in article VIII of this chapter shall be paid to the city at the time
the application is filed.
      6.   Persons desiring to construct a new waste source and connect it to
the wastewater facilities of the city shall state the quantity, quality and
rate of discharge into the public sewer or treatment works. A nonresidential
user, as a condition of permit authorization, must provide information
describing its wastewater constituents, characteristics, and type of activity
per section
7.431 of this article. In the case of any fraudulent representation upon the
part of the user, the permit fees will be forfeited and the use of the sewer
stopped.
      7.   A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sanitary sewer
connection shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the downstream
sewage facilities, including sewers, pump stations, and wastewater treatment
works, have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently handle
the additional anticipated waste load based on the population equivalent.
      8.   A user will also secure a building permit if the waste source is for
new equipment to be installed in an existing building with an existing sewer
connection.
      9.   Each excavation for any of the purposes set out in this subsection
shall require a separate permit, pursuant to the building code.
Any person who makes any excavation or does any work without first securing the
permit required by this subsection, upon conviction thereof, shall be guilty of
a misdemeanor and, in addition to any other penalty imposed by this article,
shall be liable for the penalties set forth in this code.
      10.   All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection
of the building sewer shall be borne by the applicant. The person installing
the building sewer for the owner shall be a duly licensed plumber or sewer
contractor and shall indemnify the city from loss or damage that may be
directly or indirectly occasioned by said installation. Before a building sewer
permit is issued, the plumber or sewer contractor shall file with the city
clerk an indemnity bond in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00),
with corporate surety licensed to do business in the state of Illinois, on bond
forms supplied by the city. In addition thereto, the plumber or sewer
contractor shall file with the city clerk a certificate of insurance covering
public liability insurance in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars to
three hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00 - $300,000.00) for bodily injury
and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) covering property damage.
      11.   The building sewer connection permit will be issued for a period of
twenty four (24) months consistent with the IEPA permits.
      12.   Any permit issued in this section may be revoked by article IX of
this chapter.
   B.   Building Sewer Connections (Lateral Line Connections):
      1.   A separate and independent building sewer or lateral line shall be
provided for every building, except that where one building stands at the rear
of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be
constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or
driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the
rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer, but may be done
only with the explicit approval of the building official. In no case shall any
owner be permitted to maintain, without the consent of the building official,
any connection of a building drain to a building sewer located across or under
the property of another.
      2.   An existing building sewer may be used in connection with new
buildings only when it is found, on examination and test by the building
official or WWOS or his designee, to meet all requirements of this chapter. All
costs for this examination shall be borne by the applicant.
      3.   The size, slope, alignment and construction materials of a building
sewer and the methods to be used in excavating, placement of pipe, jointing,
testing, and backfilling of the trench shall all conform to the requirements of
the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of
the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the
materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the
American Society Of Testing Materials, "Water Pollution Control Federation
Manual Of Practice No. 9", and "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer
Main Construction In Illinois", shall apply.
      4.   No building sewer shall be laid parallel to or within three feet
(3') of any bearing wall. No building sewers shall be installed in any place
where they may be subject to freezing temperatures unless adequate provisions
are made to protect them from frost. Changes in direction shall be made only
with properly curbed pipe and fittings, or a manhole, as determined by the
WWOS.
      5.   In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit
gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building
drain shall be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the
building sewer. Where possible, all building sanitary services shall be
"overhead" installations. Buildings having basements will have a pump or
ejector provided to pump the wastewater to the sanitary sewer service for
gravity transport to the sewer main.
      6.   The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be
at an existing stub and conform to the requirements of the building and
plumbing codes, or other applicable rules and regulations of the city, or the
procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the American Society Of
Testing Materials, "Water Pollution Control Federation Manual Of Practice No.
9", and "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Main Construction In
Illinois". All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight.
If no stub is available, then a wye or tee shall be installed on the public
sewer by the user, at his expense, subject to inspection and approval by the
city.
   C.   Building Sewer Construction Requirements: Construction of a building
sewer may not be started until fees are paid consistent with section
7.424 of this article and a written permit is issued by the city after issuance
and receipt of an IEPA permit for the project when applicable. It shall be
unlawful to extend any trunk line to be so connected in order to serve
additional buildings without payment to the city of an additional sewer
connection fee for each such additional building or unit within said building.
The following conditions are also required:
      1.   The applicant shall secure an excavation permit from the building
official when appropriate in conformance with the provisions of the building
code.
      2.   All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately
guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard.
Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course
of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. Failure to
properly barricade will be cause for the job site to be shut down and a fee as
provided in article VIII of this chapter must be paid before any further work
can commence.
      3.   The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the
building official two (2) city business days prior to the start of any
underground piping installation and when the building sewer is ready for
inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made
under the supervision of a qualified duly authorized agent of the city during
regular city working hours.
      4.   Minimum building sanitary sewer service size shall be six inches
