Notes:
   1.   Temporary window signs in accordance with section
13.502 of this chapter count toward the maximum sign area provisions for window
signs.
   2.    Integrated shopping centers comprising at least 200,000 contiguous
square feet of land with at least 1,000 linear feet of frontage on Irving Park
Road, a maximum of 5 additional monument signs spaced a minimum of 200 feet
apart are permitted. The maximum sign area of each additional sign is 144
square feet. The maximum height is 20 feet. The additional signs are only
permitted within 10 feet of the lot line adjacent to Irving Park Road. Pole
signs are prohibited.
   B.   Additional Regulations For Signs In Nonresidential Districts:
      1.   Freestanding Signs:
         a.   Commercial directional signs may identify the occupant of the
property provided that the directional message is the predominant copy and a
permit is obtained.
         b.   Monument signs for properties occupied by multiple tenants can
display panels for each tenant provided that the overall monument sign size
does not exceed the maximum allowed.
      2.   Wall Signs:
         a.   When a business that is licensed by the city to operate does not
have building frontage (e.g., bank located inside a grocery store), the
business will be allowed to install a wall sign on the building frontage, in a
location approved by the property owner, up to a maximum of thirty six (36)
square feet in area.
      3.   Projecting Signs:
         a.   Where the city has approved the encroachment of a projecting sign
into the public right of way, the requirements of section
13.704 of this chapter apply.
         b.   No projecting sign may project more than five feet (5') from a
building wall.
      4.   Marquee Signs:
         a.   Where the city has approved the encroachment of a marquee sign
into the public right of way, the requirements of section
13.704 of this chapter apply.
         b.   Individual, freestanding letters may project no more than six
inches (6") beyond the sign face.
      5.   Awning And Canopy Signs:
         a.   Where the city has approved the encroachment of an awning or
canopy sign into the public right of way, the requirements of section
13.704 of this chapter apply.
         b.   Individual, freestanding letters may project no more than six
inches (6") beyond the sign face of a canopy sign.
         c.   No awning sign shall project vertically above or horizontally
beyond the physical dimensions of such awning, wherein any sign located on an
awning must be affixed flat to the surface of the awning.
         d.   The framework for awnings and canopies must comply with the city
building code and section
13.305 of this chapter.
      6.   Under Canopy Signs: The width of an under canopy sign shall not
exceed three-fourths (3/4) of the building overhang projection.
      7.   Window Signs: Signs located within twelve inches (12") of the inside
of a window shall be subject to these provisions.
      8.   Electronic Message Centers:
         a.   An electronic reader board shall only be operated in nonflashing
mode, with electronic changeable copy displaying only on premises messages.
         b.   The scrolling or changing of a static message onto the sign from
one direction only per display shall be permitted, provided that a single
message or segment of a message shall have a minimum display time of at least
two (2) seconds and it may not take longer than thirty (30) seconds to display
the entire message.
      9.   Shopping Center Monument Signs: Shopping center monument signs may
advertise the name and location of the shopping center, as well as additional
tenant names, provided that they are only on sites that are ten (10) acres or
more in size.
      10.   Community Landmark Sign:
         a.   A community landmark sign shall be privately owned and shall
provide availability and display time for municipal, civic, and emergency
messaging and may display on-premises and off-premises advertising. One
advertising slot shall be provided on any digital or other face of a community
landmark sign for the purpose of communicating local community information,
without any cost or charge to the City.
         b.   A community landmark sign may have up to two (2) display faces,
placed either back to back or in a V-shaped configuration. Each display face
shall be no more than fourteen feet (14') high and forty-eight feet (48') long
for a maximum square footage of six hundred seventy-two (672) square feet per
display face.
         c.   The operation of a community landmark sign display face shall be
allowable for a continuous twenty-four (24) hours. Architectural, hardscape and
landscape lighting features of the community landmark sign may also operate for
a continuous twenty-four (24) hour period.
         d.   All message or copy change of the community landmark sign display
face shall be instantaneous. Scrolling, fading, animated, flashing or moving
messages or copy is prohibited. No display face shall change message or copy
more than once every ten (10) seconds. In instances where portions of the sign
display face malfunctions, the operator shall repair the faulty LED module(s)
within twenty four (24) hours or turn off the display face entirely until the
necessary repairs can be made.
         e.   A community landmark sign display face may not message or
advertise adult or sexually-oriented businesses or materials, hate speech, or
use any form of profane language or promotion of any message that would be
obscene in nature.
         f.   A community landmark sign shall incorporate ambient light sensors
that measure the levels of surrounding light and automatically reduce the
intensity of illumination during periods of darkness or increase the intensity
of illumination during periods of brightness. No community landmark sign
display face shall exceed a maximum illumination intensity of five hundred
(500) nits during night time hours (dusk until dawn) and seven thousand five
hundred (7,500) nits during day time hours (dawn until dusk) when the display
face is in direct sunlight. A community landmark sign display face shall not
spill light or glare exceeding 0.3 foot candles of light above the ambient
light level. The lighting measurements described above shall be reviewed and
confirmed by the City Engineer.
         g.   The architecture of a community landmark sign shall incorporate
visual art or architecture elements in addition to its messaging function
thereby creating a unique or distinctive architectural design. A community
landmark sign design shall incorporate one or more of the following
architectural elements: natural or reproduced stone, stucco, wood, brick,
ornamental iron or decorative steel. A community landmark sign shall
incorporate landscaping at the base of the sign and require the operator (the
entity, person, or individual who owns the Illinois Department of
Transportation outdoor advertising sign permit) to permanently maintain the
landscaping. The owner or operator of the community landmark sign shall
continuously maintain the structure and surrounding associated area. The
municipality may require a community landmark sign to display the name of the
municipality or local identifiable community area as part of the structure.
         h.   A community landmark sign shall not be considered a principal use
or structure on a lot and shall be allowed on lots that already have principal
uses or structures.
         i.   Prior to permit application submittal, the community landmark
sign design shall be reviewed by the Streetscape and Economic Enhancement
Committee, followed by City Council. The permit application shall be submitted,
reviewed, and approved under the municipality's standard building permit
process and shall not require additional subdivision and land development
approval. Revisions to a proposed community landmark sign design shall not be
considered a substantial amendment requiring a formal re-submission of a
community landmark sign permit application. Based upon comments received from
the municipality, the applicant shall be permitted to revise the community
landmark sign design as many times as may be necessary to obtain design
approval.
         j.   No community landmark sign shall be allowed without all required
State permits or approvals.
      11.   Cannabis dispensaries (Medical and Recreational):
         a.   Signage for the dispensary business shall not include any
pictures or images of cannabis or the smoking of the product.
         b.   No outdoor, window, or on-site media display of merchandise and/
or products related to a dispensing facility allowed.
         c.   No exterior signage that includes the words "marijuana,"
"cannabis," or any related word or symbol.
         d.   Signage shall be posted at or near all entrances indicating the
restriction that no one under 21 years of age may enter the business.
Cardholders granted medical access under the Medical Cannabis Act over eighteen
(18) years of age may access medical cannabis dispensing area only. (Ord. O-16-
013, 5-5-2016; amd. Ord. O-21-028, 10-21-2021; Ord. O-24-002, 2-15-2024)
ARTICLE VII
PERMITS
SECTION:
13.700. Requirement
13.701. Applications
13.702. Sign Permit Fee
13.703. Suspension, Denial, And Revocation
13.704. Financial Guarantees
13.705. Electrical Work
Sec. 13.700. Requirement.
Except as provided in section
13.402 of this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any person to construct,
erect, relocate, or structurally alter any sign without first obtaining a sign
permit from the City and making payment of the required fee. Alteration of the
sign face on an existing sign that is not an "abandoned sign" as defined by
section
13.202 of this chapter also requires a sign permit. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
Sec. 13.701. Applications.
An application for a sign permit shall be made on forms provided by the
Community Development Director. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
Sec. 13.702. Sign Permit Fee.
   A.   The Development Administrator shall issue a sign permit for any sign
for which a complete and accurate sign permit application and nonrefundable
permit fee have been filed and he/she has determined that the sign is in
compliance with this and all other applicable City ordinances.
   B.   All permits required by this chapter are subject to the sign permit and
separate electrical permit fees specified in the master fee schedule.
   C.   In addition, all permits required by this chapter are subject to the
applicable administration permit fees specified in the master fee schedule.
(Ord. O-18-026, 7-19-2018)
Sec. 13.703. Suspension, Denial, And Revocation.
   A.   A sign permit shall become void if the authorized sign has not been
completely installed within six (6) months of the date the permit was issued.
In this case, a new sign permit shall be required.
   B.   The Community Development Director shall give verbal or written notice
to the applicant of denial of a sign permit application together with the
reasons for the denial.
   C.   The Community Development Director may revoke any permit where there
has been a violation of the provisions of this chapter or a misrepresentation
of fact on the permit application. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
Sec. 13.704. Financial Guarantees.
Every applicant for a sign permit to construct or erect a sign over or within
the public right-of-way, where permitted, shall enter into an encroachment
license with the applicable jurisdiction, subject to insurance requirements.
(Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
Sec. 13.705. Electrical Work.
Only individuals who are licensed and bonded to conduct electrical work, with
the exception of the owner of the sign or his/her designee, may perform
electrical work, including maintenance, upon a sign. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
ARTICLE VIII
VARIATIONS
SECTION:
13.800. Public Hearing Required
13.801. Application
13.802. Procedure
Sec. 13.800. Public Hearing Required.
All requests for variations from requirements of this chapter are reviewed by
the community development commission, upon which the recommendation of the
community development commission is forwarded to the city council for final
approval. No such variation shall be granted until a public hearing has been
held in accordance with this article. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
Sec. 13.801. Application.
   A.   The petitioner shall file an application for a variation on forms
provided by the community development director.
   B.   The application for a variation shall contain the following information
as well as any additional information requested by the community development
commission:
      1.   The particular requirements of this chapter which prevent the
proposed use or construction of such sign;
      2.   The characteristics of the subject property which prevent compliance
with the requirements of this chapter;
      3.   The minimum requirements which would be necessary to permit the
proposed use or construction of such sign;
      4.   The practical difficulty or particular hardship which would result
if the aforesaid particular requirements of this chapter were applied to the
subject property and/or the proposed sign;
      5.   The details of the proposed sign, including applicable dimensions
and location on a plat of survey, as applicable.
      6.   A legal description of the subject property;
      7.   The commonly known location (address) of the subject property;
      8.   The present zoning classification of the subject property.
   C.   At the time of filing, the application for a variation shall be
accompanied by:
      1.   Proof of ownership, proof of authority on behalf of the owner or
current contract to purchase or lease the subject property; and
      2.   Payment of the required public hearing fee. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-
2016)
Sec. 13.802. Procedure.
   A.   Authorization: The community development commission may recommend and
the city council may authorize such variations from the terms of this chapter
as are hereinafter set forth in harmony with their purpose and intent as will
not be contrary to the public interest. Variations may be authorized only when
the community development commission or city council has made findings of fact,
based upon the standards set out in subsection D of this section that owing to
special conditions a literal enforcement of the provisions of this chapter
will, in an individual case, result in practical difficulties or particular
hardship for the owner, lessee or occupant of land or a structure.
   B.   Public Hearing Notification Requirements:
      1.   Required Public Notices: Prior to holding a public hearing, the
following notices shall be required:
         a.   Publication In Newspaper: This required notice must be published
at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city.
         b.   Mailed Notices To Adjacent Property Owners: Where applicable, the
city will provide or have the applicant provide mailed notices to property
owners, as shown on the record of the local real estate tax collector, within
three hundred feet (300') of the subject property, as measured from property
line to property line.
         c.   Posted Notice: Where applicable, the city will provide or have
the applicant provide a posted notice on the subject property.
      2.   Content Of The Notices: All forms of notice must contain at least
the following information:
         a.   An address or legal description of the property that is the
subject of the hearing (excluding posted notices on the subject property);
         b.   A summary of the nature of the application; and
         c.   The time and place of the hearing.
      3.   Timing Of The Notices: All notices must be provided at least fifteen
(15) days before and no more than thirty (30) days before the public hearing.
      4.   Satisfaction Of Notice Requirements: If attempts were made in good
faith to provide the required notices but the owner of the property on which
the notice is served cannot be found at the owner's last known address, or
mailed notice is returned because the owner cannot be found at the owner's last
known address, then the requirement for written notice of that owner will be
deemed satisfied.
   C.   Hearing: Any party in interest may appear and be heard at the hearing
and held pursuant to any such application and such appearance may be made in
person, by agent (if a corporation) or by attorney.
   D.   Standards: The regulations of this chapter shall not be varied unless
the community development commission and city council make findings of fact
based upon the evidence as presented that:
      1.   The property in question cannot yield a reasonable return if a sign
may be permitted only under the conditions allowed by the regulations of the
zoning district in which it is located;
      2.   The plight of the owner is due to unique circumstances, and the
proposed request will not merely serve as a convenience to the petitioner but
will alleviate some demonstrable and unusual hardship which will result if the
strict letter of the regulations of this chapter were carried out and which
particular hardship or practical difficulty is not generally applicable to
other property within the same zoning district;
      3.   The alleged hardship has not been created by any person presently
having a proprietary interest in the subject property;
      4.   The proposed request will not be materially detrimental to the
public welfare or injurious to other property or improvements in the
neighborhood;
      5.   The proposed request will not alter the essential character of the
neighborhood; and
      6.   The proposed request is in harmony with the spirit and intent of
this chapter.
   E.   Variation Conditions And Restrictions: The community development
commission or the city council may impose such conditions and restrictions upon
the subject property, the location, the construction, design and use of the
sign proposed under such request as may be necessary or appropriate to comply
with the foregoing standards and to protect adjacent property and property
values.
   F.   Findings Of Fact: No variations shall be recommended or granted unless
said variation is granted by means of a conclusion or statement of relief
granted, supported by findings of fact, which statement and findings shall be
transmitted to the applicant not less than thirty five (35) days from the date
for the decision thereon.
      1.   The findings of fact adopted by the community development commission
shall specify the reason or reasons for making the variation, and shall refer
to any exhibits containing plans and specifications for the proposed variation
which have been made a part of the application or which were introduced at the
public hearing as evidence. These forms and exhibits shall remain part of the
permanent record of the community development commission.
      2.   The terms of relief granted shall be specifically set forth in
conclusions or statements separate from the findings of fact.
   G.   Decisions For Variations: The community development commission shall
consider the variation request and shall recommend whether the variation should
be granted. The community development commission shall transmit its findings of
fact and recommendation to the city council within the time limitations
established in the unified development ordinance for public hearings. However,
the community development commission upon its own motion, or the applicant upon
his own motion, may each extend the period of time provided for in the unified
development ordinance for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days per
extension.
   H.   Action By The City Council: After receipt of the community development
commission recommendation, the city council shall approve, approve with
modifications, or disapprove the variation request.
   I.   Notice Of Decision: All final orders, requirements, and decisions of
the city council shall be in the form of an ordinance. A copy of the ordinance
approving the variation shall be transmitted to the applicant within five (5)
business days of the city council's final action. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
ARTICLE IX
AMENDMENTS TO THIS CHAPTER
SECTION:
13.901. General Requirements For Amendments
13.902. Additional Standards And Criteria For Amending This Chapter
Sec. 13.901. General Requirements For Amendments.
   A.   Public Hearing Required: The regulations imposed by this chapter may be
amended from time to time, but no such amendments shall be made until a public
hearing has been held, and a report and recommendation has been made thereon by
the community development commission.
   B.   Public Hearing Notification Requirement: A hearing shall be held on an
application for a text amendment subject to the notification requirements of
subsection
13.802B of this chapter.
   C.   Report Of Public Hearing: Following a public hearing, the community
development commission shall transmit within thirty (30) days to the city
council a report thereon containing its findings of fact and recommendation(s)
for action to be taken by the city council. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
Sec. 13.902. Additional Standards And Criteria For Amending This Chapter.
   A.   Initiation Of Amendments: Amendments to the text of this chapter may be
proposed by the city council, by the community development commission, by any
person having proprietary interest in property in the city, or by any
interested citizen of the city.
   B.   Application For Amending This Chapter:
      1.   Where an amendment to text of this chapter is proposed by someone
other than the community development director, community development commission
or city council, an application requesting the amendment shall be filed with
the community development director. The application shall be in a form
determined by the community development director and shall include the section
of this chapter to be amended and the proposed text.
      2.   Upon receiving an application requesting an amendment, or upon an
instruction from the city council or community development commission that it
will consider a proposed amendment, the community development director shall
review the proposed amendment to:
         a.   Evaluate conformity with the comprehensive plan and the unified
development ordinance; and
         b.   Determine whether the proposed text amendment corrects an error
or inconsistency, meets the challenge of a changing condition or is necessary
to implement established policy.
      3.   Prior to the scheduled public hearing, the community development
director shall deliver to the community development commission a written report
incorporating or summarizing the comments of the community development
director, planning consultant, or city departments, and other agencies.
   C.   Action By The Community Development Commission:
      1.   The community development commission shall hold a public hearing on
the proposed amendment.
      2.   In considering the amendment, the community development commission
shall review the proposed amendment, the report of the community development
director, and any oral and written comments received by the community
development commission before or at the public hearing or otherwise made part
of the record of the community development commission on the application. Based
on this information, the community development commission shall submit, within
a reasonable time, a report and recommendation to the city council on whether
or not the proposed amendment should be adopted.
   D.   Action By The City Council: After receiving the recommendations and
report of the community development commission, the city council shall, within
thirty (30) days, review the recommendations and report and may accept the
findings and recommendations of the community development commission in whole
or part or may reject them in whole or in part, or the city council may refer
the matter back to the community development commission for further
consideration. However, in the event the community development commission
recommends against an amendment of this chapter, then it may be approved only
upon the favorable two-thirds (2/3) vote of all of the members of the city
council. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
ARTICLE X
NONCONFORMING SIGNS
SECTION:
13.1001. Purpose And Intent
13.1002. Maintenance And Minor Repairs
13.1003. Damaged
13.1004. Alterations
13.1005. Abandonment
13.1006. Relocation
13.1007. Amortization
Sec. 13.1001. Purpose And Intent.
It is the intent of the city to require removal over time of signs that are
nonconforming upon adoption of this chapter. Any sign lawfully existing prior
to the enactment of this chapter, but which could not be erected in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter, shall be deemed to be a nonconforming sign
and may continue to be in existence under the following conditions. (Ord. O-16-
013, 5-5-2016)
Sec. 13.1002. Maintenance And Minor Repairs.
Maintenance and minor repairs shall be permitted, provided that the cost within
any twelve (12) month period does not exceed fifty percent (50%) of its
estimated replacement value, as determined by the community development
director. When a nonconforming wall sign is removed, the wall on which it was
displayed shall be restored to its original surface at the time the
nonconformities are eliminated. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
Sec. 13.1003. Damaged.
If a nonconforming sign is damaged in such a manner that the estimated expense
of repairs exceeds fifty percent (50%) of its estimated replacement value, the
sign shall not be allowed to remain and must be removed. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-
2016)
Sec. 13.1004. Alterations.
The only alteration to a nonconforming sign that shall be permitted is a change
in the sign face, the words or symbols used or the message displayed, only to
advertise an activity, business, or use conducted or a product sold on the
premises where said sign is located, provided that the sign is not abandoned as
described in section
13.1005 of this article. Any other alteration or change will be to bring the
nonconforming sign into conformance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord.
O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
Sec. 13.1005. Abandonment.
All nonconforming abandoned signs shall be removed and/or brought into full
conformance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
Sec. 13.1006. Relocation.
A nonconforming sign may not be relocated except when such relocation brings
the sign into compliance with this chapter. Nonconforming signs which are
relocated in violation of this section must be removed. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-
2016)
Sec. 13.1007. Amortization.
It is the intent of the city to require removal of certain legal nonconforming
signs within a reasonable time period that would allow sign owners to recoup
their investment, but ultimately reduce sign clutter that can be a traffic
hazard and negatively impacts the appearance of the city.
   A.   Applicability: All zoning districts are subject to the amortization
provisions of this section. The pole signs subject to this section are those
that do not meet the requirements for monument signs of this chapter, including
requirements for sign height, area, location, and/or base design.
   B.   Nonconforming Pole Signs: Nonconforming pole signs must be brought into
compliance upon their replacement, or when altered or damaged beyond fifty
percent (50%) of the original sign value. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
ARTICLE XI
ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
13.1101. Dangerous Or Unlawful Signs
13.1102. Appeals
13.1103. Violations
Sec. 13.1101. Dangerous Or Unlawful Signs:
In the case of any sign which is determined by the Community Development
Director to be unsafe or which has been constructed or maintained in violation
of the provisions of this chapter, written notice shall be given to the
permittee or such person having ownership and/or control of the sign. If the
permittee or person having ownership and/or control of the sign fails to remove
or alter the sign so as to comply with the standards set forth herein within
twenty four (24) hours after receipt of the notice, such sign or structure may
be removed by the Community Development Director at the expense of the
permittee or person having ownership and/or control of the sign. The Community
Development Director may cause any sign which in his/her judgment constitutes
an immediate peril to persons or property to be removed summarily, without
notice. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-2016)
Sec. 13.1102. Appeals.
In the event a permittee or person having ownership or control of any sign
disagrees with the judgment and/or interpretation of the Community Development
Director or disagrees with the content of the notice, such person may appeal
receipt of such notice in the manner set forth in the unified development
ordinance. Such appeal shall stay the removal of the sign until final
determination by the City of the issues raised on appeal. (Ord. O-16-013, 5-5-
2016)
Sec. 13.1103. Violations.
Any person or property found in violation of any provision of this chapter
shall be subject to enforcement as defined in chapter 1, article IV of this
Code. (Ord. O-18-026, 7-19-2018)
CHAPTER 14
POLICE REGULATIONS
ARTICLE I
REGULAR POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
14.101. Department Created; Members
14.102. Chief Of Police
14.103. Deputy Chiefs And Other Department Members
14.104. Auxiliary Police
14.105. Compensation, Medical Benefits, And Longevity Pay
14.106. Fees
Sec. 14.101. Department Created; Members.
There is established hereby a department of police which shall be under the
jurisdiction and control of the city manager. Said department shall include
such sworn members in number and rank as may be provided for from time to time.
In addition, the department shall include such clerks, radio men, auxiliary
police and other employees as the city council may provide by adoption of the
annual budget.
   A.   Oath: The chief of police and all members of the department shall also
execute the prescribed oath of office before entering upon their respective
duties.
   B.   Witness Fees: No member of the regular police department shall receive
any witness fee for such services in any action or suit to which the city is a
party, and all fees due for such service shall, if paid, be turned over to the
city treasurer. (Ord. 1409, 6-18-1987)
Sec. 14.102. Chief Of Police.
   A.   Appointment: The director of the department of police shall be the
chief of police who shall be appointed by the city manager for an indefinite
period of time 1 . In the event the office of chief of police is held by a
sworn member of the regular police department of the city, in addition to
holding the office of chief of police, such chief shall retain his then
existing rank as such sworn member as established by appointment by the fire
and police commissioners of the city 2 .
   B.   Powers And Duties: As director of the department of police, the chief
of police shall have the following duties, functions and responsibilities:
      1.   To see to the enforcement of all ordinances of the city and statutes
of the state effective within the city;
      2.   To be the keeper of the city jail 3  and have custody of all
prisoners incarcerated therein;
      3.   To keep such records and make such reports concerning the activities
of his department as may be required by statute, ordinance and/or the city
manager;
      4.   To be responsible for the performance of the department of police
and of all its functions;
      5.   To be the custodian of all lost, abandoned or stolen property in the
city;
      6.   To serve writs, summonses and other processes;
      7.   To make such rules and regulations for the guidance of the members
of the police department as he shall see fit. Upon posting, such rules shall
become effective; and
      8.   To perform such other duties as may be required of him from time to
time by the city manager. (Ord. 1409, 6-18-1987)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection 2.504B of this code.
2 2. See section 3.604 of this code.
3 1. See section 1.405 of this code.
Sec. 14.103. Deputy Chiefs And Other Department Members.
   A.   In accordance with the statutes of the state of Illinois, made and
provided, all sworn members of the regular police department of the city other
than the chief of police and the deputy chiefs of police, shall be appointed by
the board of fire and police commissioners.
   B.   The exempt rank of deputy chief of police is created hereby. The chief
of police is authorized hereby to appoint from the rank of sergeant a maximum
number of two (2) deputy chiefs of police, who shall serve at the discretion of
the chief of police for an indefinite period of time.
      1.   Each such appointee shall have at least five (5) years of full time
service as a sworn police officer in the city of Wood Dale police department;
and
      2.   In addition to holding the exempt rank of deputy chief of police,
each such deputy chief of police shall retain his then existing rank of
sergeant as established by his appointment by the board of fire and police
commissioners of the city. (Ord. 2099, 2-7-2002)
Sec. 14.104. Auxiliary Police.
The mayor of the city is authorized hereby to appoint, with the advice and
consent of the city council, auxiliary policemen in such number as the
corporate authorities deem necessary from time to time. Initially, such number
may be no more than fifteen (15). Such auxiliary policemen shall not supplement
sworn members of the regular police department in the performance of their
assigned and normal duties, except as otherwise provided herein.
   A.   Qualifications: Prior to their appointment:
      1.   The backgrounds of all auxiliary policemen shall be checked and
their fingers printed by the chief of police for any possible criminal record.
No person shall be appointed as an auxiliary policeman if he has been convicted
of a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude.
      2.   Auxiliary policemen shall have passed physical and psychological
tests to a degree satisfactory to the city and shall have received a course of
training in the use of weapons and other police procedures.
   B.   Powers And Duties: Once appointed pursuant to this section, such
members shall have only the following powers and duties:
      1.   To aid or direct traffic in the city;
      2.   To aid in control of natural or manmade disasters;
      3.   To aid in case of civil disorder;
      4.   To act as conservators of the peace as set forth in the Illinois
Compiled Statutes 1 ; and
      5.   To perform normal and regular police duties when assigned by the
chief of police on occasions when it is impracticable for members of the sworn
regular police department to perform normal and regular police duties.
Such auxiliary policemen shall at all times, during the performance of their
duties, be subject to the direction and control of the chief of police. (Ord.
1409, 6-18-1987)
   C.   Uniforms And Weapons: Identification symbols worn by such auxiliary
policemen shall be different and distinct from those used by the sworn regular
police department of the city, shall be supplied by the city, and shall be
selected and chosen by the city manager. In addition, auxiliary police members
shall not carry firearms unless they have received proper training and then
only with the permission of the chief of police of the city and then only when
in uniform and in the performance of their duties. (Ord. 1409, 6-18-1987; amd.
1993 Code)
   D.   Compensation: Auxiliary policemen shall receive such compensation for
services performed as may be established in the annual budget of the city.
(Ord. 1409, 6-18-1987)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/3-9-4; see section 2.104 of this code.
Sec. 14.105. Compensation, Medical Benefits, And Longevity Pay.
   A.   Compensation For Injury In The Line Of Duty: The city will provide
salary compensation to any full time sworn member of the police department or
the chief of police who was injured in the line of duty in accordance with the
provisions of the public employee disability act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes
345/0.01 et seq.
   B.   Assumption Of Liability For Medical Expenses: In case of an accident
resulting in an injury to or death of any full time sworn member of the police
department, including the chief of police while in the employ of the city while
in the performance of his duties, the city manager may secure and provide
proper medical care and hospital treatment for any such full time sworn member
of the police department, including the chief of police, and to that end may
incur expense in connection therewith to be paid from funds budgeted or
appropriated therefor by the city council or from proceeds of insurance funds.
   C.   Investigation Of Facts: It shall be the duty of the city manager to
make a complete investigation of all facts surrounding any accident resulting
in an injury to or death of any full time sworn member of the police department
or the chief of police in the employ of the city while in the performance of
his duties, to obtain the statements of all material witnesses and to present a
report thereof. Such report shall also show the date and hour of any such
accident, the place of occurrence of same, the names and addresses of
witnesses, the apparent nature and extent of the injury and whether the injury
or death was caused under circumstances creating a legal liability for damages
on the part of some person other than the city.
   D.   Payment Of Expenses: All bills showing the items of expense incurred
for any medical care and hospital treatment referred to in subsection B of this
section, shall be presented to the city manager, who shall make a determination
as to the reasonableness of the charges made for the services so rendered and
recommend payment to cover the items of expense.
   E.   Reimbursement By Third Person: If the city manager is of the opinion
that any accident referred to in this section created a legal liability for
damages on the part of some person other than the city, it shall be the duty of
the city manager to demand from such person reimbursement to the city for the
amount expended by the city for the medical care and hospital treatment of any
such full time sworn member of the police department or the chief of police. In
default of payment of such amount so expended, the city manager may cause
proceedings to be filed to recover for the city the amount so expended. (Ord.
1848, 5-16-1996)
   F.    Longevity Pay: Any full time sworn supervisor members of the police
department with the rank of Sergeant or above who complete twenty-five (25) or
more years of continuous employment as a police officer with the city,
including the Chief of Police, shall be entitled to receive longevity pay in
accordance with and subject to the following:
      1.   For every sworn supervisor with the rank of Sergeant or above and
more than 15 years of service, the City shall budget and appropriate sufficient
monies, on an annual basis, an annual amount according to the following scale
that will be restricted for payment of longevity upon the retirement of the
supervisor who completes twenty-five (25) or more years of employment with the
City of Wood Dale. The employee will not receive the annual longevity payments
that are provided to all other City employees who have 15 years of service or
more.
 
Years 15-19 $800 per year
Years 20-24 $1,000 per year
Years 25+   $1,500 per year
 
      2.   In order to be eligible for said longevity pay, the employee shall
tender an irrevocable letter of resignation with an effective date certain of
said resignation, substantially in the form of exhibit A attached to this
ordinance and incorporated herein by reference.
      3.   The amount of longevity pay shall be an additional amount based upon
the employee's annual wages equal to the applicable percentage of the amount of
such annual wages as set forth below:
 
30 or more years of service 12 percent
25 or more years of service 8 percent
 
      4.   If the sworn supervisor leaves prior to achieving twenty-five (25)
years of employment with the City of Wood Dale, they shall not be entitled to
any longevity payments from the designated amounts set forth in Section I or 3
above.
      5.   Such longevity pay shall be payable prior to the supervisor's
retirement, on the last compensable period of time covered by the pay period
which includes the employee's last day of employment in connection with his or
her voluntary resignation in good standing from the City. Such longevity pay
shall be annualized for pension purposes.
      6.   Such longevity pay shall be excluded from the calculation of payment
of all earned and unused vacation or any other compensable leave as of such
employee's date of retirement. (Ord. O-04-038, 10-7-2004; amd. Ord. O-19-008,
5-2-2019)
Sec. 14.106. Fees.
The Police Department shall charge fees for documents as specified in the
master fee schedule. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
ARTICLE II
ALARM SYSTEMS
SECTION:
14.201. Definitions
14.202. Automatic Protection Devices
14.203. False Alarms
Sec. 14.201. Definitions.
AUTOMATIC PROTECTION DEVICE: Any electrically operated instrument composed of
sensory apparatus and related hardware which automatically sends over primary
trunk lines, by direct connection or radio signal or otherwise, prerecorded
voice alarm upon receipt of a stimulus from the sensory apparatus that has
detected a physical force or condition inherently characteristic of a fire or
unauthorized intrusion.
FALSE ALARM: Shall include the activation of an alarm system through mechanical
failure, malfunction, improper installation, or negligence of the alarm user or
alarm business requiring, requesting, or resulting in a response on the part of
the Police Department when in fact there has been no hazard requiring urgent
attention, but shall not include alarm activation caused by or through power
outages, severe thunderstorms, tornadoes, earthquakes, or similar conditions
beyond the control of the alarm user or alarm business. (Ord. O-16-005, 3-3-
2016)
Sec. 14.202. Automatic Protection Devices.
   A.   Automatic Protection Devices Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any
person to use, cause or be permitted to use, or engage in the business of
providing any automatic protection device or devices within the City.
   B.   Disconnection Of Existing Devices: Within ninety (90) days after the
effective date hereof, all automatic protection devices located within the City
which are hooked up to or keyed to a primary trunk line of the Wood Dale Police
Department shall be disconnected therefrom, which disconnection shall be
accomplished by the owner, lessee or user thereof.
   C.   Penalties:
      1.   At the effective date hereof, any alarm equipment supplier who
installs an automatic protection device within the corporate limits of the City
in violation of subsection A of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor
and upon conviction, shall be fined as specified in the master fee schedule.
      2.   Any person who shall use, cause or permit to be used automatic
protection devices in violation of the terms of subsection A of this section
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction, shall be fined as
specified in the master fee schedule. Each day that an automatic protection
device exists in violation of the terms of subsection A of this section shall
be deemed a separate and distinct violation of this section. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-
19-2018)
Sec. 14.203. False Alarms.
   A.   Three False Alarms In A Calendar Year: Upon the receipt by the Police
Department of three (3) false alarms in any given calendar year for a retail,
commercial, or industrial business, the Police Department shall notify the
owner of the occurrence of these false alarms and the provisions of this Code
that will be enforced if additional false alarms are received during the
calendar year. The notification will be completed on a letter produced by the
Police Department and delivered to the alarm owner via U.S. mail or hand
delivery.
   B.   More Than Three False Alarms In A Calendar Year: Upon the receipt of
more than three (3) false alarms in any given calendar year of an alarm system
from a retail, commercial, or industrial business, the owner shall be charged a
service fee for false alarms emanating from the alarm system that result in a
response by the Police Department, during the calendar year starting January 1
through December 31, as specified in the master fee schedule. (Ord. O-18-024,
7-19-2018)
   C.   Restricted Response Of Police Department Personnel: In the event that a
false alarm is received from a location twelve (12) or more times in a calendar
year, or in the event of nonpayment of the fees for previous responses for
false alarms within sixty (60) days, the Chief of Police may order the
restricted response of Police Department personnel. This restricted response
would not apply to panic, duress or holdup alarms.
   D.   Appeals:
      1.   Upon receipt of a notice alleging violations of this Code regarding
false alarms, the owner of the alarm may request a review of the allegations by
contacting the Chief of Police in writing.
      2.   The request for review should include the reasons that the owner
does not feel that the service charges are justified, and any extenuating
circumstances that should be considered.
      3.   The request for review must occur within fourteen (14) days of the
mailing of the notice of violation.
      4.   The review will be completed by the Chief of Police or his designee
within fourteen (14) days and the alarm owner will be notified of the findings
of the review.
      5.   If the alarm owner is not satisfied with the results of the review
by the Chief of Police or his designee, the owner can seek administrative
review in accordance with chapter 18 of this Code. (Ord. O-16-005, 3-3-2016)
ARTICLE III
CIVIL EMERGENCIES
SECTION:
14.301. Definitions
14.301.1. Interim Emergency Successor
14.302. Declaration Of Emergency
14.303. Curfew
14.304. Additional Powers Of Mayor
14.305. Immunity
14.306. Utilization Of City Personnel, Equipment, Supplies And Facilities
14.307. National Incident Management System
Sec. 14.301. Definitions.
As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings indicated
below:
CIVIL EMERGENCY: A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual
force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power
to execute same by three (3) or more persons acting together without authority
of law, or any natural disaster or manmade calamity including flood,
conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion resulting in the death
or injury of persons or the destruction of property to such an extent that
extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety and
welfare.
CURFEW: A prohibition against any person or persons walking, running,
loitering, standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public
property or vacant premises except officials of any governmental unit and
persons officially designated to duty with reference to a civil emergency.
MAYOR: The incumbent mayor, his or her interim emergency successor, or the
emergency successor to the incumbent mayor appointed by the city council as
provided for in section 14.301.1 of this article.
UNAVAILABLE: "Unavailable" as defined in section 3 of the emergency interim
executive succession act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 275/3. (1976 Code §8-27;
amd. Ord. O-03-038, 12-18-2003)
Sec. 14.301.1. Interim Emergency Successor.
   A.   Interim Emergency Successor To Incumbent Mayor: In accordance with the
emergency interim executive succession act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 275/
1 et seq., the following officers in the order indicated are hereby designated
interim emergency successors to the incumbent mayor or the officer immediately
proceeding in order, as applicable, if the incumbent mayor or officer
immediately proceeding is unavailable: 1) the city manager; 2) the police
chief; and 3) the director of city services. Any officer acting as interim
emergency successor to the incumbent mayor in accordance with this section
shall continue to so act until the incumbent mayor is able to resume the
exercise of the powers and discharge the duties of office, or until appointment
of an emergency successor to the incumbent mayor by the city council as
provided in subsection B of this section.
   B.   Successor To Incumbent Mayor: If the incumbent mayor is still
unavailable after any interim emergency successor assumes authority hereunder,
the city council, as soon as practicable, shall convene and appoint an
emergency successor to the incumbent mayor to exercise the duties and
responsibilities of the mayor under this article. Upon the appointment of said
emergency successor, all authority of the interim emergency successor hereunder
shall cease. Any person appointed emergency successor to the incumbent mayor by
the city council shall continue to exercise the duties and responsibilities of
the mayor according to the provisions of this article for so long as the
incumbent mayor shall be unavailable, unless and until the city council shall
appoint another person as emergency successor.
   C.   Interim Emergency Successors To City Clerk, Chief Of Police, And
Emergency Management Staff: Within thirty (30) days of the adoption of this
section, the city clerk, chief of police, and each member of the city's
emergency management staff shall designate in writing, by title or position, an
interim emergency successor and file such with the city clerk, with a copy to
the head of the city's emergency management staff. In the event of a
proclamation of a civil emergency and the unavailability of the city clerk,
chief of police, or particular emergency management staff member, his or her
interim emergency successor shall exercise all duties and responsibilities of
his or her office or position for so long as the proclamation shall be in
effect, until the city clerk, chief of police or emergency management staff
member ceases to be unavailable or until a person to succeed the interim
emergency successor is appointed by the city council. (Ord. O-03-038, 12-18-
2003)
Sec. 14.302. Declaration Of Emergency.
   A.   Proclamation By The Mayor: When a "civil emergency" as defined herein
exists, the mayor shall declare its existence by means of a written
proclamation. The mayor shall not exercise any powers granted him under this
article unless the proclamation shall contain a statement finding that a "civil
emergency" as defined herein exists, set forth facts to substantiate such
finding, describe the nature of the emergency, expressly declare that a civil
emergency exists, and be signed, under oath, by the mayor. Such proclamation
shall be filed as soon as practicable with the city clerk. Only the "mayor", as
defined herein, may proclaim a civil emergency involving the powers of this
article. No other city official or official from another jurisdiction operating
within the city under a mutual agreement may proclaim a civil emergency within
the city. (Ord. O-03-038, 12-18-2003)
   B.   Notice Of Proclamation: Upon the issuance of the proclamation herein
authorized, the chief of police shall notify the news media situated within the
city and shall cause three (3) copies of the proclamation declaring the
existence of the emergency to be posted at the municipal building, the post
office and the fire hall. (1976 Code §8-30)
   C.   Termination Of Proclamation: Unless sooner terminated by a proclamation
of the mayor, the mayor's emergency proclamation shall be in effect until
ratified, amended, or terminated by the city council and, in any event, shall
not remain in effect in excess of seven (7) days after issuance nor be renewed
or reproclaimed beyond such period without consent of the city council. (Ord.
O-03-038, 12-18-2003)
Sec. 14.303. Curfew.
After proclamation of a civil emergency by the mayor, he may order a general
curfew applicable to such geographical areas as he deems advisable and
applicable during such hours of the day or night as he deems necessary in the
interest of the public safety and welfare. (1976 Code §8-31)
Sec. 14.304. Additional Powers Of Mayor.
While proclamation is in effect, subject to any direction, instruction,
restriction, or prohibition by the city council, the mayor may, in the interest
of public safety and welfare: (Ord. O-03-038, 12-18-2003)
   A.   Liquor Establishments Closed 1 : Order the closing of all retail
alcoholic liquor stores including taverns and private clubs or portions thereof
wherein the consumption of intoxicating liquor and beer is permitted.
   B.   Liquor Sales Stopped 2 : Order the discontinuance of the sale of
alcoholic liquor by any wholesaler or retailer.
   C.   Gasoline Sales Stopped: Order the discontinuance of selling,
distributing or giving away of any gasoline or other liquid flammable or
combustible products in any container other than a gasoline tank properly
affixed to a motor vehicle.
   D.   Firearms Sales Stopped: Order the discontinuance of selling,
distributing, dispensing or giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any
character whatsoever. (1976 Code §8-32)
   E.   Suspend Provisions Of City Ordinances: Except for the provisions of
this article, the mayor may suspend the provisions of any ordinance or
resolution prescribing procedures for the conduct of city business, or the
orders, rules and regulations of any city department or agency, if compliance
with the provisions thereof would prevent, hinder, or delay any action needed
to address a civil emergency.
   F.   Additional Orders: Issue such other orders as are immediately necessary
for the protection of life and property. (Ord. O-03-038, 12-18-2003)
 
Notes
1 1. Liquor control regulations are in chapter 5 of this code.
2 2. Liquor control regulations are in chapter 5 of this code.
Sec. 14.305. Immunity.
Neither the city of Wood Dale, nor, except in cases of wilful misconduct, the
mayor, the city manager, or the officers, employees, volunteers, or
representatives engaged in any emergency management response or recovery
activities, while complying with or attempting to comply with this article is
liable for the death of or any injury to persons or damage to property, as a
result of such activity. This section does not, however, affect the right of
any person to receive benefits to which he would otherwise be entitled under
this article under the workers' compensation act or the workers' occupational
disease act, or under any pension law, and this section does not affect the
right of any such person to receive any benefits or compensation under any act
of congress. (Ord. O-03-038, 12-18-2003)
Sec. 14.306. Utilization Of City Personnel, Equipment, Supplies And Facilities.
In carrying out the provisions of this article while a civil emergency
proclamation is in effect, the mayor and emergency management staff may utilize
to the fullest all personnel, equipment, supplies, and facilities of the city
in their preparations for civil emergency mitigation. All officers and
personnel of the various city departments shall assist with such mitigation as
the mayor and emergency management staff may direct. (Ord. O-03-038, 12-18-
2003)
Sec. 14.307. National Incident Management System.
   A.   To the fullest extent permitted under law, the city council adopts and
hereby declares the national incident management system ("NIMS"), provided for
by the homeland security presidential directive, issued by the president of the
United States on February 28, 2003, to be the public policy of the city of Wood
Dale in relation to preparation for, preventing, responding to, recovering
from, and mitigating critical incidents and continued threat of such incidents.
   B.   The interpretation and implementation of the city's emergency
procedures, as provided for in this article and elsewhere in this code, shall,
to the fullest extent permitted under law, adhere to and be consonant with all
federal standards and guidelines now or hereafter promulgated by the department
of homeland security for determining whether a local entity has adopted the
NIMS.
   C.   The chief of police, or his designee, shall periodically recommend such
revisions or additions to this article as may be deemed required by the NIMS.
(Ord. O-04-036, 9-16-2004)
ARTICLE IV
ANIMALS AND ANIMAL CONTROL
SECTION:
14.401. Rules And Definitions
14.402. Certain Animals Restricted
14.403. Animal Care
14.404. Prohibited Acts And Conditions
14.405. Diseased Animals
14.406. Killing Dangerous Animals
14.407. Impoundment And Redemption Procedures
14.408. Registration Required
14.409. Running At Large
14.410. Rabies Control
14.411. Removal Of Excrement
14.412. Intergovernmental Cooperation
14.413. Penalty
Sec. 14.401. Rules And Definitions.
   A.   Rules Of Word Construction: The language set forth in the text of this
article shall be interpreted in accordance with the following rules of
construction:
      1.   The singular number includes the plural number and the plural the
singular.
      2.   The word "shall" is mandatory; the word "may" is permissive.
      3.   The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter.
   B.   Definitions: Whenever the following words and phrases are used in this
article, they shall have the meanings as described herein:
   ANIMAL: A dog, cat or other living creature, the keeping of which is not
otherwise prohibited under the terms of this article.
   BITE: Any cutting, wounding, piercing or tearing with the teeth, including
contact of saliva with any break or any abrasion of the skin.
   CAT: Any animal which is classified as Felis domestica.
   DANGEROUS DOG: Any dog, including, but not limited to, any vicious dog, upon
any public or private property, which dog when either unmuzzled, unleashed or
unattended by its owner or a member of its owner's family, in a vicious or
terrorizing manner, approaches any other animal or person in an apparent
attitude of attack.
   DOG: Any animal which is classified as Canis familiaris.
   ENCLOSURE: A fence or structure, forming or causing an enclosure suitable to
confine a vicious dog. Such enclosure shall be securely locked and designed in
such a way so as to prevent the entry therein of children or animals, and to
prevent the vicious dog from escaping therefrom. Any such enclosure must be
adequately lighted and kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
   FERAL CAT: Any cat that is undomesticated or untamed or has returned to an
undomesticated or untamed state and is living in the wild.
   IMPOUNDED: Take into custody of the city.
   OWNER: Any person, firm, partnership, trustee, association or corporation.
   RUN LINE: A system of tying a dog in place with either a rope or chain
having a tensile strength of at least three hundred (300) pounds.
   RUNNING AT LARGE: A dog that is off the premises of its owner and not under
the control of the owner (or a person acting for the owner) by means of a
leash, cord, chain or like device, not more than eight feet (8') in length,
capable of physically restraining the movement of such dog.
   VICIOUS DOG: Except that no dog shall be deemed to be a vicious dog
hereunder if it bites, attacks or menaces a trespasser on the property of its
owner, or harms or menaces anyone who has tormented or abused it or is a
professionally trained dog for law enforcement or guard duties, "vicious dog"
means:
      1.   Any dog that when unprovoked inflicts bites or attacks or has
attacked or bitten a person or animal either on public or private property; or
      2.   Any dog with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack
without provocation, to cause injury to, or to otherwise endanger the safety of
persons or animals; or
      3.   Any dog which, because of its physical nature or vicious propensity,
is capable of inflicting serious physical harm or death to persons or animals
and which would constitute a danger to life or property if it were not kept in
the manner required by this article; or
      4.   Any dog owned or kept primarily or in part for the purpose of
dogfighting, or any dog trained for dogfighting; or
      5.   Any dog that has been found to be a dangerous dog upon any other
occasion; or
      6.   Any dog which attacks a person or domestic animal without
provocation. (1993 Code; amd. Ord. O-07-028, 9-6-2007)
Sec. 14.402. Certain Animals Restricted.
   A.   It shall be unlawful and a public nuisance to keep, maintain or have
any bats, pigeons, wild birds, roosters, chickens, rodents, skunks, raccoons,
rabbits, goats, cattle, horses, swine, pigs or any such other animals not
otherwise considered to be a pet, except as otherwise permitted in the Code,
within the city limits. This shall not apply to a reasonable number of house
pets.
   B.   It shall be unlawful and a nuisance to keep any live swine or pigs.
(1976 Code §§ 5-9, 5-10; amd. Ord. O-20-014, 6-18-2020)
Sec. 14.403. Animal Care.
Every person owning, harboring, keeping or caring for an animal, fowl or
reptile shall provide for it:
   A.   A sufficient quantity of good quality, wholesome food and water.
   B.   Adequate shelter and protection from the weather.
   C.   Veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering.
   D.   Humane care and treatment. (1976 Code §5-1)
Sec. 14.404. Prohibited Acts And Conditions.
It shall be unlawful:
   A.   Cruelty To Animals:
      1.   To beat, cruelly treat, torment, overload, overwork or otherwise
abuse any animal, fowl or reptile; or
      2.   To abandon any animal, fowl or reptile where it may become a public
charge or may suffer injury, hunger or exposure. (1976 Code §5-2)
   B.   Running At Large: For any animal, fowl or reptile to run at large.
(1976 Code §5-3)
   C.   Grazing Or Feeding In Streets: To picket or tie any animal in the
street for the purpose of grazing or feeding. (1976 Code §5-4)
   D.   Noisy Animals: To harbor or keep any animal which disturbs the peace
with loud noises. (1976 Code §5-6)
   E.   Killing Animals: For any person to engage in killing any animal other
than as prescribed by law 1 . (1976 Code §5-5)
   F.   Dogs At Public Events: No person shall bring to, or keep or maintain,
any dog at any public event being held in the City including, but not limited
to, the Wood Dale Summerfest. This provision shall not prohibit the presence of
dogs assisting the handicapped or any dog being used by law enforcement or
public safety officials within the course of their official duties. Any person
violating the provision of this subsection shall be deemed to be guilty of an
offense and shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars
($50.00). (Ord. 1673, 9-17-1992)
   G.   Feeding, Harboring, And Maintenance Of Feral Cats: If any person within
the City of Wood Dale undertakes to feed, harbor or maintain a feral cat within
the City limits of Wood Dale, that person shall be deemed responsible for the
feral cat and shall be required to comply with all applicable portions of this
Code, the DuPage County Code and State law concerning the care of cats.
Further, such person shall be required to provide any veterinary care necessary
to treat or prevent any injury to the feral cat, and shall spay or neuter the
feral cat within seven (7) days from the date the person is deemed responsible
for the feral cat. (Ord. O-07-028, 9-6-2007)
 
Notes
1 1. 510 ILCS 50/5, 75/3; ch. 520.
Sec. 14.405. Diseased Animals.
   A.   Running At Large Prohibited: No animal afflicted with a contagious
disease or an infectious disease shall be allowed to run at large or to be
exposed in any public place whereby the health of man or beast may be affected.
   B.   Quarantine: No diseased animal shall be shipped or removed from the
premises of its owner except under the supervision of the Chief of Police.
   C.   Disposal Of Diseased Animals; Premises: It is hereby made the duty of
the Chief of Police to dispose of any diseased animal and treat the affected
premises so as to prevent the communication or spread of contagion or infection
except in cases where the State Department of Agriculture is empowered to act.
(1976 Code §5-8)
Sec. 14.406. Killing Dangerous Animals.
The members of the Police Department or any other person is authorized to kill
any dangerous animal when necessary for the protection of any person or
property. (1976 Code §5-6)
Sec. 14.407. Impoundment And Redemption Procedures.
   A.   Animal Impoundment: Any dog or other animal found in the City in
violation of any of the other provisions of this article shall be kept in the
enclosure established as the City pound until redeemed or otherwise disposed of
as directed from time to time by the City Council. Animals held in the pound
shall be held at least ten (10) days for redemption.
   B.   Care And Treatment Of Animals: Impounded animals shall be humanely
treated and fed; the pound shall be under the charge of the Chief of Police,
who shall be responsible for the care and custody of the same.
   C.   Redemption Of Impounded Animals: Any person seeking to redeem an
impounded animal shall pay a recording fee as specified in the master fee
schedule per day that the animal is impounded. This shall be in addition to any
fees that are due to the facility where the animal is impounded, which shall be
paid to the City prior to release of the animal. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
   D.   Unredeemed Animals: Unredeemed animals shall be disposed of as provided
by the Mayor and Council. (Ord. O-14-036, 11-20-2014)
Sec. 14.408. Registration Required.
Whenever a resolution called for in section
14.412 of this article has been adopted by the City Council, it shall be the
duty of every person owning, keeping or harboring any dog to register the same
with the City Clerk within thirty (30) days after acquiring same. (Ord. 1167,
8-20-1981)
Sec. 14.409. Running At Large.
   A.   Dogs At Large Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person owning or
having in charge, care, control or custody any dog, except a seeing eye dog
actually being used by a blind person, to cause, allow or permit such dog,
whether licensed or unlicensed, on or upon any public street, alley or other
public place or in or upon any unenclosed lot or premises within the City
unless such dog be kept securely confined by a rope, chain or other leash not
over eight feet (8') in length, securely and continuously held by a competent
person, or to neglect by wilful act or omission to exercise due care or control
any such dog so as to commit any nuisance on any property other than any
improved private property belonging to the owner or person having charge, care,
control or custody of such dog. (1976 Code §5-27)
   B.   Interpretation:
      1.   For the purpose of this article, a dog shall be considered not to be
at large when it is muzzled or under the control of a person by means of a
leash, cord or rope of not more than eight feet (8') in length which is of
sufficient strength to control said dog. (1976 Code §5-11)
      2.   Any dog confined within any vehicle shall be deemed to be on the
enclosed premises of the operator thereof, and any dog securely tied or chained
so as to be confined within any unenclosed lot or premises shall be deemed to
be on an enclosed lot or premises.
   C.   Definition: For the purposes of this section, "nuisance" shall be
deemed to mean any trespass by such dog, or any act by such dog threatening or
actually bringing harm or damage to any person upon public or private property,
or any act by such dog endangering the repose or health of persons by biting or
by frequent barking, howling or yelping. (1976 Code §5-27)
Sec. 14.410. Rabies Control.
   A.   Rabies Inoculation Required: It shall be the duty of the owner or
person in custody of any dog four (4) months or more of age to have it
inoculated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian at least once each year.
No registration for a dog shall be issued unless the applicant exhibits a
certificate by a veterinarian showing compliance with this subsection within
one year prior to its issuance. (1976 Code §5-25; amd. 1993 Code)
   B.   Dog Bites; Procedures:
      1.   Whenever any dog bites a person, the owner of said dog shall
immediately notify the Chief of Police who shall order the dog to be held on
the owner's premises or shall have it impounded for a period of ten (10) days.
      2.   The dog shall be examined immediately after it has bitten anyone and
again at the end of the ten (10) day period. If, at the end of this ten (10)
day period, a veterinarian is convinced that the dog is free from rabies, he
shall order the dog released from quarantine or the pound. (1976 Code §5-26)
Sec. 14.411. Removal Of Excrement.
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit a dog to be on any
property, public or private, not owned or possessed by such person unless such
person has in his immediate possession a device for the removal of excrement
and a depository for the transmission of excrement to a receptacle located upon
property owned or possessed by such person. It shall be unlawful for any person
in control of, causing or permitting any dog to be on any property, public or
private, not owned or possessed by such person to fail to remove excrement left
by such dog to a proper receptacle located on property owned or possessed by
such person. (1976 Code §5-28)
Sec. 14.412. Intergovernmental Cooperation.
Pursuant to the authority vested in units of local government by section 10 of
article VII of the Constitution of the State of Illinois of 1970, the City
shall undertake to collect the registration fees and other proper charges
agreed by and between it and the County under the terms of any
intergovernmental cooperation agreement to administer and enforce the Animal
Control Act of the State of Illinois 1 , which contract shall be authorized
upon passage of a suitable resolution by the City and execution by the
authorized officials of the County. (Ord. 1167, 8-20-1981)

Sec. 14.413. Penalty.
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be deemed to be guilty
of an offense and shall be punished by a fine as specified in the master fee
schedule. If any violation shall be of a continuing nature, each day of
violation shall be deemed a separate offense and subject to the progressive
penalties contained therein. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)

Sec. 14.501. Injuring Public Property.
It shall be unlawful for anyone to injure, deface or interfere with any
property belonging to the city without proper authority from the council. (1976
Code §17-3)
Sec. 14.502. Advertisements On Public Property.
No person shall post, stick, stamp, tack, paint or otherwise fix, or cause the
same to be done by any person, any notice, placard, bill, card, poster,
advertisement or other device calculated to attract the attention of the public
to or upon any sidewalk, crosswalk, curb or curbstone, flagstone or any other
portion or part of any public way, lamppost, electric light, telegraph,
telephone, hydrant, shade tree 1  or upon the piers, columns, trusses, girders,
railings, gates or other parts of any public bridge or viaduct, or upon any
pole box or fixture of the fire alarm or police telegraph system, except such
as may be required by law. (1976 Code §25-16)
