18.113. Penalties, Court Fees, And Judgment Collection Procedure
18.114. Federal Government Contracts; Maintenance Of Property; Penalties
Sec. 18.101. Establishment of Administrative Adjudication System.
   The City of Wood Dale, pursuant to article 1, division 2.1 of the Illinois
Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-2.1-1 et seq., hereby establishes a system of
administrative adjudication, subject to the limitations of this chapter, that
provides due process of law, including notice and an opportunity for a hearing
for all affected persons. In the event a conflict between this chapter and
article 1, division 2.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code exists, then the
Illinois Municipal Code shall prevail. The stated purpose of this chapter is to
provide a method for fairly and efficiently enforcing the Municipal Code of the
City of Wood Dale of 1993, as amended from time to time, through citations or
notices of violation issued by any city department for any city code
violations, including, but not limited to, the building code; unified
development code; all offenses under chapter 4, commercial occupancy and
activity regulations; chapter 6, public health and safety; and chapter 15,
traffic code, as may be allowed by law through an administrative adjudication
of the city’s municipal ordinances; including and establishing a schedule of
fines and penalties and authority for collection of unpaid fines and penalties.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.102. Definitions.
As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the following
definitions shall have the meanings ascribed:
ADJUDICATORY HEARINGS: Any administrative hearing called by the code hearing
unit pursuant to this chapter.
AUTOMATED TRAFFIC REGULATIONS: A traffic regulation as set forth in the
Illinois vehicle code, as amended from time to time, section 11-208.6,
governing an automated traffic law enforcement system or 11-1201.1, governing
an automated railroad crossing enforcement system.
CITY: The city of Wood Dale, DuPage County, Illinois.
CODE OR CITY CODE: The Wood Dale municipal code, as amended from time to time.
CODE ENFORCEMENT ADMINISTRATOR: A person responsible for managing the
administrative process for handling city code violations, ensuring compliance
with the city code, and facilitating adjudicatory hearings for violations that
are subject to administrative adjudication.
GENERAL REGULATIONS: Any regulation set forth in this code and city ordinances
other than automated traffic regulations, real property use regulations,
standing, parking and compliance regulations or liquor control.
HEARING OFFICER: An individual, other than a city law enforcement officer, or
city code enforcement inspector, appointed by the city manager to preside over
and conduct hearings in the City’s system of administrative adjudication.
ORDINANCE OR CITY ORDINANCE: Any regulation approved and adopted by the Wood
Dale city council that is in effect but that has not been codified in this
code.
NON-EMERGENCY SITUATION: Any situation that does not reasonably constitute a
threat to the public interest, safety, or welfare.
STANDING, PARKING AND COMPLIANCE REGULATIONS: Any standing, parking and
compliance regulation set forth in chapter 15 of this code, or city ordinances
that is in conformity with the definition of “compliance” set forth in the
Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3(a). (Ord. O-
10-021, 11-4-2010)
VIOLATION NOTICE: A formal written allegation or charge of a city code or
ordinance violation, also known as a “notice of violation,” or “complaint”,
filed with the code hearing unit by an individual authorized by this code to
issue a city code or ordinance violation notice.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.103. Composition of Administrative Adjudication System.
The administrative adjudication system of the city shall be comprised of a code
hearing unit.
   A.   Code hearing unit.
      1.   There is hereby created a code hearing unit within the city that is
responsible for conducting adjudicatory hearings, exercising the powers
conferred in this chapter and in the manner set out in this chapter.
      2.   The code hearing unit shall have jurisdiction to adjudicate all
alleged violations of the city code, except for: (i) proceedings not within the
statutory authority of the city; (ii) any offense under the Illinois Vehicle
Code or a similar offense that is a traffic regulation governing the movement
of vehicles; and (iii) any reportable offense under Section 6-204 of the
Illinois Vehicle Code.
      3.   Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter, the administrative
adjudication of impounded vehicles shall be governed by the specific procedures
established in chapter 15, article XVIII of the City Code.
      4.   The code hearing unit shall consist of one or more hearing officers,
as that term is defined herein, and any one or more of the following: a code
enforcement administrator, as that term is defined herein, hearing room
personnel, and such other agents, employees or officials assigned to assist
either the hearing officer of the code enforcement administrator. All members
of the code hearing unit shall be appointed by the city manager and shall have
the powers, authority, and limitations as set forth in this chapter.
      6.   This chapter shall not affect the validity of systems of
administrative adjudication authorized by state law and adopted by the city.
For a violation of any city ordinance, fines and penalties shall be as
established from time to time by the corporate authorities.
   B.   Hearing officer powers and duties.
      1.   The hearing officer shall have all the powers granted to hearing
officers under state law set forth in section 1-2.1-4 of the Illinois Municipal
Code, as amended, the provisions of which are incorporated herein by this
reference, including the powers to:
      2.   Preside at an adjudicatory hearing called to determine whether or
not a code or ordinance violation exists; and
      3.   Hear testimony and accept evidence from all interested parties
relevant to the existence of a code or ordinance violation; and
      4.   Issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant
testimony at the adjudicatory hearing or produce relevant documents, upon the
request of the parties or their representatives; and
      5.   Preserve and authenticate the transcript and record of the
adjudicatory hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the
adjudicatory hearing; and
      6.   Issue and sign a written finding, decision, and order that states
whether a code or ordinance violation exists; specifies the penalty or fines
imposed; and/or specifies the action with which the person found liable must
comply, along with a timeline for compliance, if appropriate; and
      7.   Impose penalties consistent with applicable provisions of the city
code and assess costs upon finding a party liable for the charged violation,
except, however, that in no event shall the hearing officer have authority to
(i) impose a penalty of incarceration, or (ii) impose a fine in excess of
$50,000 for each violation of the city code or each count stated in the
violation notice, or at the option of the city, such other amount not to exceed
the maximum amount established by the Mandatory Arbitration System as
prescribed by the Rules of the Illinois Supreme Court from time to time for the
judicial circuit in which the city is located. Any such fine imposed under this
chapter shall be exclusive of costs of enforcement or costs imposed to secure
compliance with the city’s code or ordinances and shall not be applicable to
cases to enforce the collection of any tax imposed and collected by the city.
   C.   Hearing officer qualifications. All hearing officers shall be appointed
by the city manager and prior to conducting proceedings under this chapter, a
hearing officer shall successfully complete a formal training program that
includes the following:
      1.   Instruction on the rules of procedure of the hearing that they will
conduct;
      2.   Orientation to each subject area of this code or city ordinance
violations that they will administer;
      3.   Observations of administrative hearings; and
      4.   Participation in hypothetical cases, including rules on evidence and
issuing final orders.
      In addition, every hearing officer must be an attorney licensed to
practice law in the state of Illinois for at least three (3) years, and be in
good standing with the attorney registration and disciplinary commission of the
supreme court of Illinois. A hearing officer is not required to be a resident
of the city.
   D.   The code enforcement administrator, who shall be the community
development director, or their designee, is hereby authorized, empowered, and
directed to:
      1.   Promulgate rules and regulations reasonably required to operate and
maintain the administrative adjudication system.
      2.   Adopt, distribute, and process all notices or documents required
under this Chapter, or as may reasonably be required to carry out the purpose
of this Chapter.
      3.   Collect payments made as a result of fines and/or penalties assessed
after a final determination and transmit such payments to the city’s finance
department.
      4.   Refer to the city’s attorney the collection of unpaid fines and
penalties assessed after a final determination, and enforcement of any
unremediated violations of the city code.
      5.   Certify copies of findings, decisions, and orders adjudicated
pursuant to this Chapter, and any factual reports verifying the findings,
decisions, and orders that are issued in accordance with this Chapter or the
laws of the State of Illinois.
      6 .   Manage the operations of the administrative adjudication system,
including, but not limited to:
         a.   Inputting information for violation notices and notices to
appear;
         b.   Establishing notices of violations and hearing dates;
         c.   Issuing and serving notices of hearing dates, notices of default,
such other notices as may be necessary to implement the administrative
adjudication system, and final notices;
         d.   Keeping an accurate record of appearances and failures to appear
at the administrative hearings;
         e.   Keeping a record of please entered, judgments entered, penalties
imposed, if any, and penalties paid or completed;
         f.   Collecting unpaid fines and penalties, and pursuing post-judgment
remedies available by law;
         g.   Issuing payment receipts;
         h.   Pursuing such other duties as directed by the community
development director, or their designee; and
         i.   Performing such other duties as are necessitated to achieve
functionality and efficiency in the operation of the administrative
adjudication system.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.104. Hearing Procedures Not Exclusive.
   The city is not precluded from using other methods to enforce the provisions
of this code and city ordinances such as instituting an action in a court of
law.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.105. Code Enforcement Procedure.
   A.   Initiation of Adjudicatory Proceedings: Adjudicatory proceedings in the
city’s administrative adjudication system are initiated when any individual
authorized to issue a city code or ordinance violation notice files such a
notice with the code hearing unit. Authorized individuals include, but are not
limited to, full-time police officers, community service officers, code
enforcement officers, code inspectors, and persons retained by the city who
identify a code violation.
   B.   Violation Notice Requirements:
      1.   A violation of the city code or a city ordinance shall be noted on a
multiple copy violation notice or a computer generated violation notice that
shall including the following:
         a.   The name and address of the party alleged to have violated the
city code or ordinance, if known;
         b.   The name and address of the person to whom the violation notice
is given if that person is not the alleged violator/respondent;
         c.   The date of the alleged violation;
         d.   For violations of Chapters 14 or 15 of the city code, the time of
the alleged violation;
         e.   The section(s) of the city code or ordinance alleged to have been
violated;
         f.   A brief description of the type and nature of the alleged city
code or ordinance violation;
         g.   In the case of a violation pertaining to real property, the
address of the property where the violation is observed;
         h.   Vehicle make and state registration number, if applicable;
         i.   The names of any witnesses to the violation;
         j.   The names, signature (which can include a conformed, electronic,
or authorized stamp signature), city department, position, and identification
number, if applicable, of the person issuing the violation notice;
         k.   The date, time, and location of the adjudication hearing for the
alleged city code or ordinance violation; and
         l.   The legal authority and jurisdiction under which the hearing is
to be held and the penalties for failure to appear.
   C.   Verification: The correctness of the facts contained in any violation
notice shall be verified by the person issuing the notice by:
      1.    Signing his/her name to the violation notice at the time of
issuance; or
      2.    In the case of a notice being produced by a computer, signing a
single certificate, to be kept by the code enforcement administrator attesting
to the correctness of all notices produced by the computer while under their
control.
   D.   Scheduling Adjudicatory Proceedings: Adjudicatory hearings shall be
scheduled with reasonable promptness, provided that for adjudicatory hearings
scheduled in all non-emergency situations, if requested by the alleged
violator, the alleged violator shall have at least 15 days after service of
process to prepare for an adjudicatory hearing. If service is provided by mail,
the 15-day period shall begin to run on the day that the violation notice and
notice to appear is deposited in the mail.
   E.   Docketing and Notice: The docketing and service of violation notices
shall be made in the following manner:
      1.   Alleged violators shall be served with process in a manner
reasonably calculated to give them actual notice. For purposes of this chapter,
“a manner reasonably calculated to give actual notice” shall mean, as
appropriate, service by first-class mail at an alleged violator’s address;
personal service of process upon an alleged violator or their employer or
agent; affixing the original or facsimile of the notice to an unlawfully
standing or parked vehicle, unstickered vehicle, vehicle violating any
compliance regulation; or, posting a notice upon the property where the
violation is found where the alleged violator is the owner, tenant, or
administrator of the property.
      2.   The original or a copy of the violation notice shall be retained by
the code enforcement administrator, with a docket number stamped on all copies
and a hearing date noted;
      3.   The notice shall be kept as a record in the ordinary course of
business by the code enforcement administrator and shall be a part of the
hearing record;
      4.   One copy of the violation notice shall be returned to the person
issuing the notice so that he or she may prepare evidence for presentation at
the hearing on the date indicated;
      5.   One copy of the violation notice shall be served to the alleged
violator along with a summons commanding the alleged violator to appear at the
hearing;
      6.   In the case of a violation pertaining to real property, if the name
of the property owner cannot be ascertained or if service on the owner cannot
be made by mail, service may be made on the owner by posting or nailing a copy
of the violation notice form on the front door of the structure where then
violation is found, not less than fifteen (15) days before the hearing is
scheduled.
      7.   In the case of a building code or unified development code
violation, if the city has an ordinance or code provision requiring property
owners, meaning the legal or beneficial owner(s) of the structure, to register
with it, service may be made on the owner by mailing the violation notice and
notice to appear to the property owner’s address registered with the city. If
the name of the property owner cannot be ascertained or if service on the owner
cannot be made by mail, service may be made on the owner by posting or affixing
a copy of the violation notice and notice to appear on the front door of the
structure where the violation is found, not less than fifteen (15) days before
the hearing is scheduled.
      8.   In the case of violation notice alleging a parking, standing, or
stopping violation of a motor vehicle, the violation notice may be served by
leaving a copy of the violation notice on the windshield of the motor vehicle
or by handing the notice to the operator of the vehicle, if present.
      9.   If the city requires the party to respond to the violation notice
within a specified amount of time, the city shall file a reply with the code
hearing unit within the same amount of time afforded to the party responding to
the complaint.
      10.   Any violation notice issued, signed and served in accordance
herewith shall be prima facie correct and shall be prima facie evidence of the
correctness of the facts shown on the notice and shall be admissible in a
subsequent administrative or legal hearing.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.106. Eviction; Rights Of The Occupants.
   No action for eviction, abatement of a nuisance, forcible entry and detainer
or other similar proceeding shall be threatened or instituted against an
occupant of a dwelling solely because such occupant agrees to testify or
testifies at a code or ordinance violation hearing.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.107. Subpoenas.
   Parties may request the hearing officer to issue subpoenas to direct the
attendance and testimony of relevant witnesses, as well as the product of
relevant documents. All costs associated with a subpoena shall be prepaid by
the requesting party and shall include the cost of serving the subpoena and
witness fees equal to the fee that would be provided a subpoenaed witness in a
civil case if the Code of Illinois Procedure was applicable.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.108. Representation at Hearings.
   The case for the city may be presented by an attorney designated by the city
manager or by any other city employee. The case for the alleged violator may be
presented by the alleged violator, their attorney, or any other agent or
representative of the alleged violator. When the alleged violator is a
corporation, limited liability company or partnership, the alleged violator
must be represented by an attorney. An attorney or agent appearing at an
adjudication hearing on behalf of the alleged violator shall present the
administrative hearing officer with a signed appearance form stating, on oath
or affirmation, that he or she has been authorized by the alleged violator to
represent the alleged violator at the hearing.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.109. Adjudicatory Hearings.
   An adjudicatory hearing shall be held to adjudicate an alleged city code or
ordinance violation on its merits, or to contest the validity of a violation
notice in accordance with the following procedures:
   A.   Hearing Time and Date; Limited Continuances: Hearings for all “must
appear” or “required to appear” violations and contested allegations will be
held at the date, time, and place specified in the violation notice and notice
to appear. No continuances shall be authorized by the hearing officer in
proceedings under this chapter, except in cases where a continuance is
absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the alleged violator, or if both
the city and the alleged violator agree to a continuance. A lack of preparation
or a scheduling conflict are not valid reasons for a continuance.
   B.   Strict Rules of Evidence Inapplicable: At the hearing, the hearing
officer shall preside, administer oaths and affirmation, hear testimony and
accept any evidence relevant to the existence or nonexistence of a city code or
ordinance violation. The formal and technical rules of evidence shall not be
applied in an adjudicatory hearing under this chapter, subject to the condition
that hearsay shall be admissible if it is of a type commonly relied upon by
reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs.
   C.   Burden of Proof: The burden shall be on the city to prove by a
preponderance of the evidence that the alleged violation occurred.
   D.   Record: A record of all adjudicatory hearings shall be kept by tape
recording or other appropriate means.
   E.   Defenses to Building and Life Safety Code Violations: In the case of a
building and life safety code violations only, it shall be a defense to a
charge of such violation(s) under this section if the owner, their attorney, or
any other agent or representative proves to the hearing officer’s satisfaction
that:
      1.   The violation did not exist;
      2.   The code violation has been caused by the current property occupants
and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the property owners to maintain the
structure free of such violation(s), the current occupants continue to cause
the code violation(s);
      3.   The occupant or resident of the structure has refused entry to the
owner or its agent for purposes of correcting the code violation.
      4.   In the case where the hearing officer finds the defense set forth in
subparagraph 2 or 3 above, such finding shall authorize the issuance of notices
of violation against the occupants of the property who upon a finding of a
violation shall become liable for any penalties, compliance or action order
that can be entered by the hearing officer.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.110. Findings, Decision and Order.
   A.   At the conclusion of the adjudicatory hearing, the hearing officer
shall make a determination (the “Final Administrative Decision”), based on the
evidence presented at the adjudicatory hearing, of whether or not a code or
ordinance violation exists. The Final Administrative Decision shall be in
writing and shall be designated as findings, decision, and order. The findings,
decision, and order shall include: a) the hearing officer’s findings of fact;
b) a decision of whether or not a code or ordinance violation exists based upon
the findings of fact; and c) an order that states the fine, penalty and/or
compliance action required, or dismisses the case if a violation is not proved.
   B.   A monetary sanction for a violation under this article shall not exceed
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) or the amount provided for in section 1-
2-1 of the Illinois municipal code as amended from time to time, per code
violation or count stated in a violation notice.
   C.   In addition to, and not in lieu of, any penalty or other remedy
provided in this code, the hearing officer or the circuit court, whatever the
case may be, may enter an order enjoining any ongoing or repeated violation of
this code or otherwise mandating compliance with this code upon due notice of
such violation.
   D.   If, on the date set for hearing, the alleged violator or their attorney
fails to appear, the hearing officer may enter a default judgment of liability
and impose a penalty in accordance this chapter, upon determining that a
factual basis exists that a code violation occurred.
   E.   Upon finding the alleged violator in default, the code enforcement
administrator or his or her designee shall send or cause to be sent notices by
first class mail, postage prepaid to the violator who receives the notice of a
code or ordinance violation. Service of the notice sent in accordance herewith
shall be complete as of the date of the deposit of the first-class mail in the
United States mail.
   F.   A violator against whom a default judgment has been entered may file a
motion to vacate the default judgment with the code enforcement administrator
or hearing officer and request a new hearing. Such motion shall be filed within
21 days after the issuance of the default order. A motion to vacate shall set
forth the reasons the violator failed to appear on the original hearing date
along with the basis for a defense to the code violation. The hearing officer
shall hear and rule on the motion. The hearing officer may set aside the
default judgment if sufficient evidence is presented demonstrating that the
petitioner’s failure to appear at the hearing was for good cause or that the
city did not provide proper service of process. If any judgment is set aside
pursuant to this subsection, the hearing officer shall have authority to enter
an order extinguishing any lien which has been recorded for any debt due and
owing the city as a result of the vacated default judgment.
   G.   A default judgment constitutes a final determination for purposes of
judicial review and is subject to review under the Illinois Administrative
Review Law, 735 ILCS 5/3-101.
   H.   A copy of the Final Administrative Decision shall be served on the
violator within five (5) days after it is issued. The Final Administrative
Decision shall be served in a manner allowed in section 18.105 of this code,
unless the parties agree to an alternative form of service.
   I.   Payment of any penalty or fine and the disposition of fine money shall
be in the same manner as set forth in this code and city ordinances.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.111.     Order and Sanction Attached to Property.
   In the case of a Chapter 12, Building Code violation, the order to correct
the violation and the sanctions imposed by the city as the result of a finding
of a building code violation under this Chapter shall attach to the property as
well as to the property owner so that a finding of a building code violation
against one owner cannot be avoided by conveying or transferring the property
to another owner. Any subsequent transferee or owner of the property takes
subject to the findings, decision, and order of a hearing officer under this
Chapter.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.112. Review Under Administrative Review Law.
   The Final Administrative Decision of the hearing officer shall constitute a
final determination and shall be subject to review in the circuit court of the
18th judicial circuit. The provisions of the Administrative Review Law, as
amended, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto, shall apply to and govern
every action for judicial review of a Final Administrative Decision of a
hearing officer under this Chapter.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.113. Penalties, Court Fees, and Judgment Collection Procedure.
   A.   Where a finding of a violation is made, the following penalties, and
any other applicable penalties provided for elsewhere in the city code, or a
combination thereof may be imposed:
      1.   A penalty not to exceed $750.00 per code violation or count stated
in the violation notice, for each day the violation exists, with a maximum
cumulative daily penalty not to exceed $50,000.00 per code violation or count
stated in the violation notice. The maximum monetary penalty imposed under the
city code shall be exclusive of costs of enforcement or costs incurred by the
city to secure compliance with the city code. This penalty limit does not apply
to cases to enforce the collection of any tax imposed and collected by the
city.
      2.   Remediation;
      3.   Community service;
      4.   Restitution.
   B.   The city shall impose a non-refundable court fee of fifty dollars
($50.00) on any person found liable for a violation of the city code through
the administrative adjudication process. This fee shall be assessed in addition
to any fines, penalties, or other costs imposed under the findings, decision,
and order of the administrative hearing officer.
   C.    Any fine, other sanction or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other
sanction or costs imposed, remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of or the
failure to exhaust judicial review procedures under the Illinois Administrative
Review Law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.) shall be a debt due and owing to the city
and may be collected in accordance with applicable law.
   D.   After expiration of the period in which judicial review under the
Illinois Administrative Review Law may be sought for a Final Administrative
Decision of a code or ordinance violation, unless stayed by a court of
competent jurisdiction, the findings, decision, and order of the hearing
officer may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of
competent jurisdiction.
   E.   In any case in which a defendant has failed to comply with a judgment
ordering a defendant to correct a code violation or imposing any fine or other
sanction as a result of a code violation, any expenses incurred by the city to
enforce the judgment, including, but not limited to, attorney’s fees, courts
costs, and costs related to property demolition or foreclosure, after they are
fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction or a hearing officer, shall be a
debt due and owing the city and may be collected in accordance with applicable
law. Prior to any expenses being fixed by a hearing officer pursuant to this
subsection, the city shall provide notice to the defendant that state that the
defendant shall appear at hearing before the hearing officer to determine
whether the defendant has failed to comply with the judgment. The notice shall
set the date for such hearing, which shall not be less than seven days from the
date that notice is served. If notice is served by mail, the seven (7) day
period shall begin to run on the date that the notice was deposited in the
mail.
   F.   Upon being recorded in the manner required by Article XII of the Code
of Civil Procedure, 735 ILCS 5/12-101 et seq., or the Uniform Commercial Code,
810 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq., a lien shall be imposed on the real estate or
personal estate, or both, of the defendant in the amount of any debt due and
owing the city under this chapter. The lien may be enforced in the same manner
as a judgment lien pursuant to a judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.114. Federal Government Contracts; Maintenance Of Property; Penalties.
   A.   A person who contracts with the federal government or any of its
agencies, including, without limitation, the department of housing and urban
development, to care for vacant residential real estate shall be responsible
for maintaining the property to prevent and correct municipal health and safety
code or ordinance violations.
   B.   A person who intentionally violates this section is guilty of a
business offense and shall be fined not less than five hundred one dollars
($501.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )

Sec. 18.201. Definitions.
As used in this article, unless the context requires otherwise, the following
definitions shall have the meanings ascribed:
AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM: A device within the City of Wood Dale
with one (1) or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction with a red
light signal to produce recorded images of motor vehicles entering an
intersection against a steady or flashing red signal indication in violation of
section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/11-306, or similar
violation of the City of Wood Dale Municipal Code.
DISREGARDING A TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICE: Failure to stop and remain stopped
before an intersection that is controlled by a red signal as provided for in
section 11-306 of the Illinois Vehicle Code.
NO TURN ON RED: Where the motor vehicle comes to a complete stop and does not
enter the intersection as defined by section 1-132 of the Code, during the
cycle of the red signal indication unless one (1) or more pedestrians are
present, even if the motor vehicle stops at a point past a stop line or
crosswalk where a driver is required to stop, as specified in subsection (c) of
Section 11-306 of the Code or this Ordinance.
RECORDED IMAGES: Images produced by the automated traffic law enforcement
system, which consist of either two (2) or more photographs; two (2) or more
microphotographs; two (2) or more electronic images; or, a video recording
showing the motor vehicle and, on at least one (1) image or portion of the
recording, clearly identifying the registration plate or digital registration
plate number of the motor vehicle.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.202. Violations.
   It shall be a violation of this article for a vehicle to disregard a traffic
control device or turn on red in violation of section 11-306 of the Illinois
Vehicle Code.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.203. Establishment.
The city hereby adopts the provision of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3, as amended from time to time, governing the
exclusive procedure for the administrative adjudication of all city code and
ordinance violations involving automated traffic law regulations.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.204. Hearing Procedures Not Exclusive.
   The city is not precluded from using other methods to enforce the provisions
of this code and city ordinances such as instituting an action in a court of
law.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.205. Traffic Compliance Administrator.
   The city chief of police shall designate a traffic compliance administrator
who is authorized to adopt, distribute and process automated traffic law
violation notices and other notices required by this article, collect money
paid as fines and penalties for violation of automated traffic law violations,
and operate an administrative adjudication system.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.206. First Notice Of Violation.
An automated traffic law violation notice shall contain the following
information:
   A.   The date, time, and place of violation of an automated traffic law
regulation; and
   B.   The particular regulation violated; and
   C.   Any requirement to complete a traffic education program; and
   D.   The amount of the civil penalty imposed, and the requirements of any
traffic education program imposed and the date by which the civil penalty
should be paid, and the traffic education program should be completed; and
   E.   The fine and any penalty that may be assessed for late payment or
failure to complete a required traffic education program, or both; and
   F.   The vehicle make, where available and readily discernible and state
registration number; and
   G.   The identification number of the person issuing the notice; and
   H.   A statement that the person may elect to proceed by:
      1.   Paying the fine, completing a required traffic education program, or
both; or
      2.   Challenging the charge by mail in the case of nonresidents, or by an
administrative hearing; and
   I.   A statement that the completion of any required traffic education
program, the payment of any indicated fine, and the payment of any applicable
penalty for late payment or failure to complete a required traffic education
program, or both, shall operate as a final disposition of the violation; and
   J.   Information as to the availability of a hearing in which the violation
may be contested on its merits; and
   K.   Information about the time and manner in which a hearing may be had;
and
   L.   A warning that failure to pay the civil penalty, to complete a required
traffic education program, or to contest liability in a timely manner is an
admission of liability and may result in a suspension of the driving privileges
of the registered owner of the vehicle; and
   M.   A statement that recorded images are evidence of a violation of an
automated traffic regulation; and
   N.   A website address, accessible through the internet, where the person
may view the recorded images of the violation.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.207. Recorded Images.
   A.   Recorded images made by an automatic traffic law enforcement system are
confidential and shall be made available only to the alleged violator and
governmental and law enforcement agencies for purposes of adjudicating a
violation, for statistical purposes, or for other governmental purposes. Any
recorded image evidencing an automated traffic law violation, however, may be
admissible in any proceeding resulting from the issuance of the citation.
   B.   The city shall make the recorded images of an automated traffic law
violation accessible to the alleged violator by providing the alleged violator
with a website address, accessible through the internet.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.208. Service Of First Notice Of Violation.
   The notice shall be delivered to the registered owner of the vehicle, by
mail, within thirty (30) days after the secretary of state notifies the city of
the identity of the owner of the vehicle, but in no event later than ninety
(90) days after the violation.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.209. Certification Of The First Violation Notice.
   A notice of violation associated with an automated traffic law violation
shall require a determination made by a technician employed or contracted by
the city that, based on inspection of recorded images, the motor vehicle was
being operated in violation of section 11-208.6, 11-208.9 or 11-1201.1 of the
Illinois Vehicle Code as incorporated in this code and city ordinances. If the
technician determines that the vehicle entered the intersection as part of a
funeral procession or in order to yield the right of way to an emergency
vehicle, a citation shall not be issued. All determinations by a technician
that a motor vehicle was being operated in violation of the automated traffic
law must be reviewed and approved by a law enforcement officer or retired law
enforcement officer of the city. The original or a facsimile of the violation
notice or, in the case of a notice produced by a computerized device, a printed
record generated by the device showing the facts entered on the notice, shall
be retained by the traffic compliance administrator, and shall be a record kept
in the ordinary course of business.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.210. Hearing Fee Prohibited.
   No additional fee shall be charged to the alleged violator for exercising
his or her right to an administrative hearing.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.211. Prima Facie Evidence.
   An automated traffic law violation notice issued, signed and served in
accordance with this article, a copy of the notice, or the computer generated
record shall be prima facie correct and shall be prima facie evidence of the
correctness of the facts shown on the notice. The notice, copy, or computer
generated record shall be admissible in any subsequent administrative or legal
proceedings.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.212. Nonresidents.
   Where the registered owner or lessee of the cited vehicle is not a resident
of the city but seeks to contest the merits of the alleged violation, such
person may contest the charges using the same available defenses as stated
above, but rather than attend the administrative hearing, they may submit any
and all documentary evidence to the traffic compliance administrator no later
than the hearing date, together with a written statement reflecting that they
are nonresidents of the City of Wood Dale. The traffic compliance administrator
shall forward all timely-submitted materials to the hearing officer for review
and determination.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.213. Hearing.
   The registered owner of the vehicle cited in the automated traffic law
violation notice may request a hearing by the respond-by date on the notice of
violation to challenge the evidence or set forth an applicable defense. A
lessee of a vehicle cited in the violation notice likewise shall be provided an
opportunity for a hearing of the same kind afforded the registered owner. The
notice of violation shall constitute evidence of the facts contained in the
notice and is admissible in any proceeding alleging an automated traffic law
violation. The notices of violation shall be prima facie evidence of a
violation, subject to rebuttal on the basis of the defenses established in
section
18.412. The registered owner’s failure to appear will result in a finding of
liability. In the event of a failure to appear, a “Findings, Decision, and
Order” letter will be sent to the registered owner. The owner’s failure to pay
the amount by the date specified will result in a final determination. The
hearings shall be recorded, and the person conducting the hearing on behalf of
the traffic compliance administrator shall be empowered to administer oaths and
to secure by subpoena both the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the
production of relevant books and papers. Persons appearing at a hearing under
this article may be represented by counsel at their expense.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.214. Limited Affirmative Defenses For Automated Traffic Law Violations.
   The hearing officer shall only consider in defense of a violation:
   A.   The motor vehicle or registration plates of the motor vehicle were
stolen before the violation occurred and not under the control of or in the
possession of the owner at the time of the violation. To demonstrate that the
motor vehicle or the registration plates were stolen before the violation
occurred and were not under the control or possession of the owner at the time
of the violation, the owner must submit proof that a report concerning the
stolen motor vehicle or registration plates was filed with a law enforcement
agency in a timely manner.
   B.   The driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection when the
light was red either: 1) in order to yield the right of way to an emergency
vehicle or 2) as part of a funeral procession for an automated red light
violation.
   C.   The driver of the motor vehicle received a uniform traffic citation
from a police officer at the time of the violation for the same offense.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.215. Final Determinations Of Violation Liability.
   A final determination of violation liability shall occur following failure
to complete the required traffic education program or to pay the fine or
penalty, or both, after a hearing officer’s determination of violation
liability and the exhaustion of or failure to exhaust any administrative review
procedures provided by city code. Where a person fails to appear at a hearing
to contest the alleged violation in the time and manner specified in a prior
mailed notice, the hearing officer’s determination of violation liability shall
become final: a) upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that
determination, or b) upon expiration of the period for filing the petition
without a filing having been made.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.216. Notice of Determination of Liability.
   A determination of automated traffic law violation liability shall occur
following failure to pay the fine or penalty, or to contest the alleged
violation within twenty-one (21) days of the notice of violation. Where a
person fails to appear at a hearing to contest the alleged violation in the
time and manner specified in a prior mailed notice, the hearing officer will
enter a findings, decision and order determination of automated traffic law
violation liability which shall become final: (a) upon denial of a timely
petition to set aside that determination, or (b) upon expiration of the period
for filing such a petition without a filing having been made. If a person
appears at a hearing and is found liable or contests the violation by mail and
is found liable, the hearing officer will enter findings, decision and order,
which is a final determination of automated traffic law violation liability
that is a final, appealable order.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.217. Notice Of Final Determination Of Automated Traffic Law Violation.
   A notice shall be sent following a final determination of automated traffic
law violation liability and the conclusion of review procedures taken under
this article. The notice shall state that the incomplete traffic education
program or the unpaid fine or penalty, or both, is a debt due and owing the
municipality. The notice shall contain warnings that failure to complete any
required traffic education program or to pay any fine or penalty due and owing
the city, or both, within the time specified may result in the city’s filing of
a petition in the circuit court of the 18th judicial circuit to have the
incomplete traffic education program or unpaid fine or penalty, or both,
rendered a judgment as provided by this article.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.218. Petition To Set Aside.
   A petition to set aside a determination of automated traffic law violation
liability may be filed by a person owing an unpaid fine or penalty. A petition
to set aside a determination of liability may also be filed by a person
required to complete a traffic education program. The petition shall be filed
with and ruled upon by the traffic compliance administrator. The grounds for
the petition are limited to: a) the person not having been the owner or lessee
of the cited vehicle on the date the violation notice was issued, b) the person
having already completed the required traffic education program or paid the
fine or penalty, or both, for the violation in question, and c) excusable
failure to appear at or request a new date for a hearing. Any such petition
shall be filed no more than twenty one (21) days after a final determination of
violation liability. After the determination of an automated traffic law
violation liability has been set aside upon a showing of just cause, the
registered owner shall be provided with a hearing on the merits for that
violation. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.219. Fines And Penalties.
   A violation of an automated red light regulation shall be subject to a fine
of not more or less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). A violation of an
automated railroad crossing regulation shall be subject to a fine of not more
or less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first violation and
not more or less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a second or subsequent
violation. Upon a final determination of violation of an automated traffic law
regulation, the registered owner of the vehicle shall have thirty (30) days to
satisfy any applicable fine. In the event the registered owner of the vehicle
fails to timely and fully satisfy the applicable fine, the registered owner of
the vehicle shall be assessed an additional one hundred dollars ($100.00). In
addition to or in lieu of a fine, the registered owner of the vehicle may be
ordered to complete a required traffic education program. In the event the
registered owner of the vehicle fails to timely complete a required traffic
education program, the registered owner of the vehicle shall be assessed an
additional one hundred dollars ($100.00). A low income individual required to
complete a traffic education program who provided proof of eligibility for the
Federal Earned Income tax credit under section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code
of the Illinois Earned Income Tax credit under section 212 of the Illinois
Income Tax Act is not required to pay any fee for participating in a traffic
education program. A registered owner who is a holder of a valid commercial
driver’s license is not required to complete a traffic education program. For
purposes of the required traffic education program only, a registered owner may
submit an affidavit to the hearing officer swearing that at the time of the
alleged violation, the vehicle was in the custody and control of another
person. The affidavit must identify the person in custody and control of the
vehicle, including the person’s name and current address. The person in custody
and control of the vehicle at the time of the violation is required to complete
the required traffic education program. If the person in custody and control of
the vehicle at the time of the violation completes the required traffic
education program, the registered owner of the vehicle is not required to
complete a traffic education program.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.220. Court Fee Assessment.
   The city shall impose a non-refundable court fee of fifty dollars ($50.00)
on any person found liable for a violation of an automated traffic law through
the administrative adjudication process. This fee shall be assessed in addition
to any fines, penalties, or other costs imposed under the findings, decision,
and order of the administrative hearing officer.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.221. Non-Liability.
   Notwithstanding any other provision of law to the contrary, a person shall
not be liable for violations, fees, fines, or penalties for an automated
traffic law violation during the period in which the motor vehicle was stole or
hijacked, as indicated in a report to the appropriate law enforcement agency
filed in a timely manner.
(Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.222. Administrative Review Law.
   Judicial review of final determinations of automated traffic law violations
and final administrative decisions issued after hearings regarding vehicle
immobilization and impoundment made under this article shall be subject to the
provisions of the administrative review law.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.223. Final Disposition.
   Any fine, penalty, incomplete traffic education program, or part of any fine
or any penalty remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to
exhaust, administrative remedies created under this article and the conclusion
of any judicial review procedures shall be a debt due and owing the city and,
as such, may be collected in accordance with applicable law. Completion of any
required traffic education program and payment in full of any fine or penalty
resulting from an automated traffic law violation shall constitute a final
disposition of that violation.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.224. Judgment.
   After the expiration of the period within which judicial review may be
sought for a final determination of an automated traffic law violation, the
city may commence a proceeding in the circuit court of the 18th judicial
circuit for purposes of obtaining a judgment on the final determination of
violation. Nothing in this article shall prevent the city from consolidating
multiple final determinations of automated traffic law violations against a
person in a proceeding. Upon commencement of the action, the city shall file a
certified copy or record of the final determination of automated traffic law
violation, which shall be accompanied by a certification that recites facts
sufficient to show that the final determination of violation was issued in
accordance with this article and the Illinois vehicle code. Service of the
summons and a copy of the petition may be by any method provided by section
2-203 of the code of civil procedure or by certified mail, return receipt
requested, provided that the total amount of fines and penalties for final
determinations of automated traffic law violations does not exceed two thousand
five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). If the court is satisfied that the final
determination of an automated traffic law violation was entered in accordance
with the requirements of this article and the Illinois Vehicle Code, and that
the registered owner or the lessee, as the case may be, had an opportunity for
an administrative hearing and for judicial review as provided in this article,
the court shall render judgment in favor of the city and against the registered
owner or the lessee for the amount indicated in the final determination of
automated traffic law violation, plus costs. The judgment shall have the same
effect and may be enforced in the same manner as other judgments for the
recovery of money.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
Sec. 18.225. Vehicle Immobilization.
   The city is authorized to immobilize any eligible vehicle upon the public
way by presence of a restraint in a manner to prevent operation of the vehicle
to enforce the provisions of this article.
   A.   A vehicle shall be eligible for immobilization when the registered
owner of the vehicle has accumulated any combination of three (3) or more
incomplete traffic education programs or unpaid final determinations of
parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic law violations.
   B.   At least twenty one (21) days prior to immobilization, the city shall
send to the registered owner of an eligible vehicle a notice of impending
vehicle immobilization and shall provide the registered owner a right to a
hearing to challenge the validity of the notice by disproving liability for the
incomplete traffic education programs or unpaid final determinations of
parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic law violation liability, or
both, listed on the notice.
   C.   The registered owner shall have the right to a prompt hearing after a
vehicle has been immobilized or subsequently towed without the completion of
the required traffic education program or payment of the outstanding fines and
penalties on parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic law
violations, or both, for which final determinations have been issued. An order
issued after the hearing is a final administrative decision within the meaning
of section
3-101 of the code of civil procedure.
   D.   The city shall send a post-immobilization and post-towing notice
advising the registered owner of the vehicle of the right to a hearing to
challenge the validity of the impoundment.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010; amd. Ord. O-24-041, - - )
ARTICLE III
DIVISION OF REAL PROPERTY ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION
SECTION:
18.301. Establishment
18.302. Hearing Procedures Not Exclusive
18.303. Instituting Adjudication Proceedings
18.304. Subpoenas; Defaults
18.305. Continuances; Representation At Hearings
18.306. Hearing; Evidence
18.307. Eviction; Rights Of The Occupants
18.308. Defenses To Code Or Ordinance Violations
18.309. Findings, Decision, Order
18.310. Administrative Review
18.311. Judgment On Findings, Decision, Order
18.312. Sanctions Applicable To Owner; Property
18.313. Civil Liability For Rentals In Excess Of Number Permitted By Ordinance;
Definitions
18.314. Federal Government Contracts; Maintenance Of Property; Penalties
18.315. Application For Grants
Sec. 18.301. Establishment.
The city hereby adopts the provisions of the Illinois municipal code, 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., as amended from time to time,
governing the exclusive procedure for the administrative adjudication of all
real property use regulations set forth in this code and city ordinances. (Ord.
O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.302. Hearing Procedures Not Exclusive.
The city is not precluded from using other methods to enforce the provisions of
this code and city ordinances such as instituting an action in a court of law.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.303. Instituting Adjudication Proceedings.
When a building inspector finds a code or ordinance violation while inspecting
a structure, he shall note the violation on a multiple copy violation notice
and report form, indicating the name and address of the structure owner, the
type and nature of the violation, the date and time the violation was observed,
the names of witnesses to the violation, and the address of the structure where
the violation is observed.
The violation report form shall be forwarded by the building inspector to the
division of real property administrative adjudication where a docket number
shall be stamped on all copies of the report, and a hearing date noted in the
blank spaces provided for that purpose on the form. The hearing date shall not
be less than thirty (30) nor more than forty (40) days after the violation is
reported by the building inspector.
One copy of the violation report form shall be maintained in the files of the
division of real property administrative adjudication and shall be part of the
record of hearing, one copy of the report form shall be returned to the
building inspector so that he may prepare evidence of the code or ordinance
violation for presentation at the hearing on the date indicated, and one copy
of the report form shall be served by first class mail on the owner of the
structure, along with a summons commanding the owner to appear at the hearing.
If the name of the owner of the structure cannot be ascertained or if service
on the owner cannot be made by mail, service may be made on the owner by
posting or nailing a copy of the violation report form on the front door of the
structure where the violation is found, not less than twenty (20) days before
the hearing is scheduled. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.304. Subpoenas; Defaults.
At any time prior to the hearing date the hearing officer assigned to hear the
case may, at the request of the building inspector or the attorney for the
city, or the owner or his attorney, issue subpoenas directing witnesses to
appear and give testimony at the hearing. If on the date set for hearing the
owner or his attorney fails to appear, the hearing officer may find the owner
in default and shall proceed with the hearing and accept evidence relevant to
the existence of a city code or ordinance violation. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.305. Continuances; Representation At Hearings.
No continuances shall be authorized by the hearing officer in proceedings under
this article except in cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to
protect the rights of the owner. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a
continuance. Any continuance authorized by a hearing officer under this article
shall not exceed twenty five (25) days. The case for the city may be presented
by an attorney designated by the city. The case for the structure's owner may
be presented by the owner, his attorney, or any other agent or representative.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.306. Hearing; Evidence.
At the hearing, a hearing officer shall preside and shall hear testimony and
accept any evidence relevant to the existence or nonexistence of a code or
ordinance violation in the structure indicated. The strict rules of evidence
applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply to hearings authorized by
this article. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.307. Eviction; Rights Of The Occupants.
No action for eviction, abatement of a nuisance, forcible entry and detainer or
other similar proceeding shall be threatened or instituted against an occupant
of a dwelling solely because such occupant agrees to testify or testifies at a
code or ordinance violation hearing. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.308. Defenses To Code Or Ordinance Violations.
It shall be a defense to a code or ordinance violation charged under this
article if the owner, his attorney, or any other agent or representative proves
to the hearing officer's satisfaction that:
   A.   The code or ordinance violation alleged in the notice does not in fact
exist, or at the time of the hearing the violation has been remedied or
removed;
   B.   The code or ordinance violation has been caused by the current property
occupants and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the owner to maintain the
dwelling free of such violations, the current occupants continue to cause the
violations;
   C.   An occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to the owner
or his agent to all or a part of the dwelling for the purpose of correcting the
code or ordinance violation. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.309. Findings, Decision, Order.
At the conclusion of the hearing the hearing officer shall make a determination
on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing whether or not a code or
ordinance violation exists. The determination shall be in writing and shall be
designated as findings, decision and order. The findings, decision and order
shall include the hearing officer's findings of fact, a decision whether or not
a code or ordinance violation exists based upon the findings of fact, and an
order, ordering the owner to correct the violation or dismissing the case, in
the event a violation is not proved. If a code or ordinance violation is
proved, the order may also impose the sanctions that are provided in the code
or ordinance for the violation proved. A copy of the findings, decision, and
order shall be served on the owner within five (5) days after they are issued;
service shall be in the same manner as the report form and summons are served
pursuant to this article. Payment of any penalty or fine and the disposition of
fine money shall be in the same manner as set forth in this code or city
ordinance. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.310. Administrative Review.
The findings, decision and order of the hearing officer shall be subject to
review in the circuit court of the 18th judicial circuit, and the provisions of
the administrative review law, and all amendments and modifications thereto,
and the rules adopted pursuant thereto are adopted and shall apply to and
govern every action for the judicial review of the final findings, decision and
order of a hearing officer under this article. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.311. Judgment On Findings, Decision, Order.
   A.   Any fine, other sanction or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other
sanction or costs imposed remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the
failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures under the administrative review
law shall be a debt due and owing the city and, as such, may be collected in
accordance with applicable law.
   B.   After expiration of the period within which judicial review under the
administrative review law may be sought for a final determination of the code
or ordinance violation, the city may commence a proceeding in the circuit court
of the 18th judicial circuit for purposes of obtaining a judgment on the
findings, decision and order. Nothing in this article shall prevent the city
from consolidating multiple findings, decisions and orders against a person in
such a proceeding. Upon commencement of the action, the city shall file a
certified copy of the findings, decision and order, which shall be accompanied
by a certification that recites facts sufficient to show that the findings,
decision and order was issued in accordance with this article and the Illinois
municipal code. Service of the summons and a copy of the petition may be by any
method provided by section 2-203 of the code of civil procedure or by certified
mail, return receipt requested, provided that the total amount of fines, other
sanctions and costs imposed by the findings, decision and order does not exceed
two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). If the court is satisfied that
the findings, decision and order were entered in accordance with the
requirements of this article and the Illinois municipal code, and that the
property owner had an opportunity for a hearing under this article and for
judicial review as provided in this article: 1) the court shall render judgment
in favor of the municipality and against the property owner for the amount
indicated in the findings, decision and order, plus costs. Such judgment shall
have the same effect and may be enforced in the same manner as other judgments
for the recovery of money; and 2) the court may also issue such other orders
and injunctions as are requested by the city to enforce the order of the
hearing officer to correct a code or ordinance violation. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-
2010)
Sec. 18.312. Sanctions Applicable To Owner; Property.
The order to correct a code or ordinance violation and the sanctions imposed by
the city as the result of a finding of a code or ordinance violation under this
article shall attach to the property as well as to the owner of the property,
so that a finding of a code or ordinance violation against one owner cannot be
avoided by conveying or transferring the property to another owner. Any
subsequent transferee or owner of property takes subject to the findings,
decision and order of a hearing officer under this article. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-
4-2010)
Sec. 18.313. Civil Liability For Rentals In Excess Of Number Permitted By
Ordinance; Definitions.
   A.   The owner of a building located in the city who, directly or
indirectly, has collected, or caused to be collected, rentals from an occupant
of that building during a period in which the number of apartments or family
units in that building exceeded the number permitted for that building by this
code and city ordinances, is liable to any such occupant in an amount equal to
not more than three (3) times the amount of any rentals paid by any such
occupant, or in his behalf, after January 1, 1970, together with court costs
and reasonable attorney fees. If the occupant is a recipient of public aid
under article III, IV, or VI of "the Illinois public aid code", approved April
11, 1967, as amended, in whose behalf vendor payment of the rental was made by
the Illinois department of public aid, the department of human services (acting
as successor to the department of public aid under the department of human
services act), or a local governmental unit, as the case may be, the liability
as herein provided is to the Illinois department of public aid, the department
of human services (acting as successor to the department of public aid under
the department of human services act), or the local governmental unit making
the vendor payment of the rental.
   B.   For the purposes of this article:
    FAMILY UNIT: A room or group of rooms used or intended to be used as a
housekeeping unit for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. The fact that any
such family unit is used or intended to be used with cooking or eating
accommodations in common with another family unit in any such building does not
affect liability hereunder.
   OWNER: The legal or beneficial owner of a building.
   C.   No liability accrues under this article until thirty (30) days after
the owner of record of a building has been notified in writing that such owner
is in violation of any such municipal ordinance. Such notice shall be
personally served upon such owner of record or sent by registered mail to the
last known address of such owner. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.314. Federal Government Contracts; Maintenance Of Property; Penalties.
   A.   A person who contracts with the federal government or any of its
agencies, including, without limitation, the department of housing and urban
development, to care for vacant residential real estate shall be responsible
for maintaining the property to prevent and correct municipal health and safety
code or ordinance violations.
   B.   A person who intentionally violates this section is guilty of a
business offense and shall be fined not less than five hundred one dollars
($501.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. O-10-021,
11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.315. Application For Grants.
The city may make application to the department of commerce and economic
opportunity for grants to help defray the cost of establishing and maintaining
a code hearing department as provided in this article. The application for
grants shall be in the manner and form prescribed by the department of commerce
and economic opportunity. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
ARTICLE IV
DIVISION OF VEHICLE ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION
SECTION:
18.401. Establishment
18.402. Hearing Procedures Not Exclusive
18.403. Traffic Compliance Administrator
18.404. First Notice Of Violation; Required Information For All Vehicle
Regulations
18.405. First Notice Of Violation; Additional Required Information For
Automated Traffic Law Regulations
18.406. Recorded Images
18.407. Service Of First Notice Of Violation; Parking, Standing, Compliance
18.408. Service Of First Notice Of Violation; Automated Traffic Law
18.409. Certification Of The First Violation Notice; All Vehicle Regulations
18.410. Hearing Fee Prohibited
18.411. Prima Facie Evidence
18.412. Second Notice Of Violation; All Vehicle Regulations
18.413. Hearing
18.414. Limited Affirmative Defenses For Automated Traffic Law Violations
18.415. Final Determinations Of Violation Liability
18.416. Notice Of Final Determination Of Parking, Standing, Compliance Or
Automated Traffic Law Violation
18.417. Petition To Set Aside
18.418. Fines And Penalties
18.419. Administrative Review Law
18.420. Final Disposition
18.421. Judgment
18.422. Suspension Of Driver's License
18.423. Notice Of Impending Driver's License Suspension
18.424. Certified Report Requesting Suspension Of Driver's License
18.425. Certified Report; Hearing
18.426. Certified Report; Error
18.427. Vehicle Immobilization
Sec. 18.401. Establishment.
The city hereby adopts the provision of the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-208.3, as amended from time to time, governing the
exclusive procedure for the administrative adjudication of all city code and
ordinance violations involving parking, standing and compliance regulations and
automated traffic law regulations. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.402. Hearing Procedures Not Exclusive.
The city is not precluded from using other methods to enforce the provisions of
this code and city ordinances such as instituting an action in a court of law.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.403. Traffic Compliance Administrator.
The city chief of police shall designate a traffic compliance administrator who
is authorized to adopt, distribute and process parking, compliance, and
automated traffic law violation notices and other notices required by this
article, collect money paid as fines and penalties for violation of parking and
compliance ordinances and automated traffic law violations, and operate an
administrative adjudication system. The traffic compliance administrator also
may make a certified report to the secretary of state under section 6-306.5 of
the Illinois vehicle code. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.404. First Notice Of Violation; Required Information For All Vehicle
Regulations.
A parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic law violation notice that
shall specify the date, time, and place of violation of a parking, standing,
compliance, or automated traffic law regulation; the particular regulation
violated; any requirement to complete a traffic education program; the fine and
any penalty that may be assessed for late payment or failure to complete a
required traffic education program, or both; the vehicle make and state
registration number; and the identification number of the person issuing the
notice. With regard to automated traffic law violations, vehicle make shall be
specified on the automated traffic law violation notice if the make is
available and readily discernible. The violation notice shall state that the
completion of any required traffic education program, the payment of any
indicated fine, and the payment of any applicable penalty for late payment or
failure to complete a required traffic education program, or both, shall
operate as a final disposition of the violation. The notice also shall contain
information as to the availability of a hearing in which the violation may be
contested on its merits. The violation notice shall specify the time and manner
in which a hearing may be had. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.405. First Notice Of Violation; Additional Required Information For
Automated Traffic Law Regulations.
The first violation notice shall include:
   A.   The name and address of the registered owner of the vehicle; and
   B.   The registration number of the motor vehicle involved in the violation;
and
   C.   The violation charged; and
   D.   The location where the violation occurred; and
   E.   The date and time of the violation; and
   F.   A copy of the recorded images; and
   G.   The amount of the civil penalty imposed and the requirements of any
traffic education program imposed and the date by which the civil penalty
should be paid and the traffic education program should be completed; and
   H.   A statement that recorded images are evidence of a violation of an
automated traffic regulation; and
   I.   A warning that failure to pay the civil penalty, to complete a required
traffic education program, or to contest liability in a timely manner is an
admission of liability and may result in a suspension of the driving privileges
of the registered owner of the vehicle; and
   J.   A statement that the person may elect to proceed by:
      1.   Paying the fine, completing a required traffic education program, or
both; or
      2.   Challenging the charge by mail in the case of nonresidents, or by an
administrative hearing; and
   K.   A website address, accessible through the internet, where the person
may view the recorded images of the violation. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.406. Recorded Images.
   A.   "Recorded images" means images recorded by an automated traffic law
enforcement system on:
      1.   Two (2) or more photographs;
      2.   Two (2) or more microphotographs;
      3.   Two (2) or more electronic images; or
      4.   A video recording showing the motor vehicle and, on at least one
image or portion of the recording, clearly identifying the registration plate
number of the motor vehicle.
   B.   The city shall make the recorded images of an automated traffic law
violation accessible to the alleged violator by providing the alleged violator
with a website address, accessible through the internet. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-
2010)
Sec. 18.407. Service Of First Notice Of Violation; Parking, Standing,
Compliance.
Service of the first violation notice shall be made by affixing the original or
a facsimile of the notice to an unlawfully parked vehicle or by handing the
notice to the operator of a vehicle if he or she is present and by sending such
notice, by mail, to the address of the registered owner of the cited vehicle as
recorded with the secretary of state within thirty (30) days after the
secretary of state notifies the city of the identity of the owner of the
vehicle, but in no event later than ninety (90) days after the violation. (Ord.
O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.408. Service Of First Notice Of Violation; Automated Traffic Law.
The notice shall be delivered to the registered owner of the vehicle, by mail,
within thirty (30) days after the secretary of state notifies the city of the
identity of the owner of the vehicle, but in no event later than ninety (90)
days after the violation. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.409. Certification Of The First Violation Notice; All Vehicle
Regulations.
A person authorized by ordinance to issue and serve parking, standing, and
compliance violation notices shall certify as to the correctness of the facts
entered on the violation notice by signing his or her name to the notice at the
time of service or in the case of a notice produced by a computerized device,
by signing a single certificate to be kept by the traffic compliance
administrator attesting to the correctness of all notices produced by the
device while it was under his or her control. In the case of an automated
traffic law violation, a technician employed or contracted by the city shall
determine that, based on inspection of recorded images, the motor vehicle was
being operated in violation of section 11-208.6 or 11-1201.1 of the Illinois
vehicle code as incorporated in this code and city ordinances. If the
technician determines that the vehicle entered the intersection as part of a
funeral procession or in order to yield the right of way to an emergency
vehicle, a citation shall not be issued. All determinations by a technician
that a motor vehicle was being operated in violation of the automated traffic
law must be reviewed and approved by a law enforcement officer or retired law
enforcement officer of the city. The original or a facsimile of the violation
notice or, in the case of a notice produced by a computerized device, a printed
record generated by the device showing the facts entered on the notice, shall
be retained by the traffic compliance administrator, and shall be a record kept
in the ordinary course of business. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.410. Hearing Fee Prohibited.
No additional fee shall be charged to the alleged violator for exercising his
or her right to an administrative hearing. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.411. Prima Facie Evidence.
A parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic law violation notice
issued, signed and served in accordance with this article, a copy of the
notice, or the computer generated record shall be prima facie correct and shall
be prima facie evidence of the correctness of the facts shown on the notice.
The notice, copy, or computer generated record shall be admissible in any
subsequent administrative or legal proceedings. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.412. Second Notice Of Violation; All Vehicle Regulations.
This notice shall specify the date and location of the violation cited in the
parking, standing, or compliance violation notice, the particular regulation
violated, the vehicle make and state registration number, any requirement to
complete a traffic education program, the fine and any penalty that may be
assessed for late payment or failure to complete a traffic education program,
or both, the availability of a hearing in which the violation may be contested
on its merits, and the time and manner in which the hearing may be had. This
notice shall also state that failure to complete a required traffic education
program, to pay the indicated fine and any applicable penalty, or to appear at
a hearing on the merits in the time and manner specified, will result in a
final determination of violation liability for the cited violation in the
amount of the fine or penalty indicated, and that, upon the occurrence of a
final determination of violation liability for the failure, and the exhaustion
of, or failure to exhaust, available administrative or judicial procedures for
review, any incomplete traffic education program or any unpaid fine or penalty,
or both, will constitute a debt due and owing the city. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-
2010)
Sec. 18.413. Hearing.
The registered owner of the vehicle cited in the parking, standing, compliance,
or automated traffic law violation notice shall have an opportunity for a
hearing in which the owner may contest the merits of the alleged violation, and
during which formal or technical rules of evidence shall not apply; provided,
however, that a lessee of a vehicle cited in the violation notice likewise
shall be provided an opportunity for a hearing of the same kind afforded the
registered owner. The hearings shall be recorded, and the person conducting the
hearing on behalf of the traffic compliance administrator shall be empowered to
administer oaths and to secure by subpoena both the attendance and testimony of
witnesses and the production of relevant books and papers. Persons appearing at
a hearing under this article may be represented by counsel at their expense.
