The ordinance may also provide for internal administrative review following the
decision of the hearing officer. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.414. Limited Affirmative Defenses For Automated Traffic Law Violations.
The hearing officer shall only consider in defense of a violation:
   A.   The motor vehicle or registration plates of the motor vehicle were
stolen before the violation occurred and not under the control of or in the
possession of the owner at the time of the violation. To demonstrate that the
motor vehicle or the registration plates were stolen before the violation
occurred and were not under the control or possession of the owner at the time
of the violation, the owner must submit proof that a report concerning the
stolen motor vehicle or registration plates was filed with a law enforcement
agency in a timely manner.
   B.   The driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection when the
light was red either: 1) in order to yield the right of way to an emergency
vehicle or 2) as part of a funeral procession for an automated red light
violation.
   C.   The driver of the motor vehicle received a uniform traffic citation
from a police officer at the time of the violation for the same offense. (Ord.
O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.415. Final Determinations Of Violation Liability.
A final determination of violation liability shall occur following failure to
complete the required traffic education program or to pay the fine or penalty,
or both, after a hearing officer's determination of violation liability and the
exhaustion of or failure to exhaust any administrative review procedures
provided by ordinance. Where a person fails to appear at a hearing to contest
the alleged violation in the time and manner specified in a prior mailed
notice, the hearing officer's determination of violation liability shall become
final: a) upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that determination, or
b) upon expiration of the period for filing the petition without a filing
having been made. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.416. Notice Of Final Determination Of Parking, Standing, Compliance Or
Automated Traffic Law Violation.
This notice shall be sent following a final determination of parking, standing,
compliance, or automated traffic law violation liability and the conclusion of
review procedures taken under this article. The notice shall state that the
incomplete traffic education program or the unpaid fine or penalty, or both, is
a debt due and owing the municipality. The notice shall contain warnings that
failure to complete any required traffic education program or to pay any fine
or penalty due and owing the city, or both, within the time specified may
result in the city's filing of a petition in the circuit court of the 18th
judicial circuit to have the incomplete traffic education program or unpaid
fine or penalty, or both, rendered a judgment as provided by this article, or
may result in suspension of the person's driver's license for failure to
complete a traffic education program or to pay fines or penalties, or both, for
ten (10) or more parking, standing or compliance violations under section 6-
306.5 of the Illinois vehicle code or five (5) or more automated traffic law
violations under section 11-208.6 of the Illinois vehicle code. (Ord. O-10-021,
11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.417. Petition To Set Aside.
A petition to set aside a determination of parking, standing, compliance, or
automated traffic law violation liability that may be filed by a person owing
an unpaid fine or penalty. A petition to set aside a determination of liability
may also be filed by a person required to complete a traffic education program.
The petition shall be filed with and ruled upon by the traffic compliance
administrator. The grounds for the petition may be limited to: a) the person
not having been the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle on the date the
violation notice was issued, b) the person having already completed the
required traffic education program or paid the fine or penalty, or both, for
the violation in question, and c) excusable failure to appear at or request a
new date for a hearing. Any such petition shall be filed no more than twenty
one (21) days after a final determination of violation liability. After the
determination of parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic law
violation liability has been set aside upon a showing of just cause, the
registered owner shall be provided with a hearing on the merits for that
violation. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.418. Fines And Penalties.
A violation of a parking, standing and compliance regulation shall be subject
to the applicable fines and penalties set forth in chapter 15 of this code,
provided that in no event shall a civil fine for such violations exceed five
hundred dollars ($500.00). A violation of an automated red light regulation
shall be subject to a fine of not more or less than one hundred dollars
($100.00). A violation of an automated railroad crossing regulation shall be
subject to a fine of not more or less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
for the first violation and not more or less than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for a second or subsequent violation. Upon a final determination of
violation of any vehicle regulation, the registered owner of the vehicle shall
have thirty (30) days to satisfy any applicable fine. In the event the
registered owner of the vehicle fails to timely and fully satisfy the
applicable fine, the registered owner of the vehicle shall be assessed an
additional one hundred dollars ($100.00). In addition to or in lieu of a fine,
the registered owner of the vehicle may be ordered to complete a required
traffic education program. In the event the registered owner of the vehicle
fails to timely complete a required traffic education program, the registered
owner of the vehicle shall be assessed an additional one hundred dollars
($100.00). A registered owner who is a holder of a valid commercial driver's
license is not required to complete a traffic education program. For purposes
of the required traffic education program only, a registered owner may submit
an affidavit to the hearing officer swearing that at the time of the alleged
violation, the vehicle was in the custody and control of another person. The
affidavit must identify the person in custody and control of the vehicle,
including the person's name and current address. The person in custody and
control of the vehicle at the time of the violation is required to complete the
required traffic education program. If the person in custody and control of the
vehicle at the time of the violation completes the required traffic education
program, the registered owner of the vehicle is not required to complete a
traffic education program. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.419. Administrative Review Law.
Judicial review of final determinations of parking, standing, compliance, or
automated traffic law violations and final administrative decisions issued
after hearings regarding vehicle immobilization and impoundment made under this
article shall be subject to the provisions of the administrative review law.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.420. Final Disposition.
Any fine, penalty, incomplete traffic education program, or part of any fine or
any penalty remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to
exhaust, administrative remedies created under this article and the conclusion
of any judicial review procedures shall be a debt due and owing the city and,
as such, may be collected in accordance with applicable law. Completion of any
required traffic education program and payment in full of any fine or penalty
resulting from a standing, parking, compliance, or automated traffic law
violation shall constitute a final disposition of that violation. (Ord. O-10-
021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.421. Judgment.
After the expiration of the period within which judicial review may be sought
for a final determination of parking, standing, compliance, or automated
traffic law violation, the city may commence a proceeding in the circuit court
of the 18th judicial circuit for purposes of obtaining a judgment on the final
determination of violation. Nothing in this article shall prevent the city from
consolidating multiple final determinations of parking, standing, compliance,
or automated traffic law violations against a person in a proceeding. Upon
commencement of the action, the city shall file a certified copy or record of
the final determination of parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic
law violation, which shall be accompanied by a certification that recites facts
sufficient to show that the final determination of violation was issued in
accordance with this article and the Illinois vehicle code. Service of the
summons and a copy of the petition may be by any method provided by section 2-
203 of the code of civil procedure or by certified mail, return receipt
requested, provided that the total amount of fines and penalties for final
determinations of parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic law
violations does not exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). If
the court is satisfied that the final determination of parking, standing,
compliance, or automated traffic law violation was entered in accordance with
the requirements of this article and the Illinois vehicle code, and that the
registered owner or the lessee, as the case may be, had an opportunity for an
administrative hearing and for judicial review as provided in this article, the
court shall render judgment in favor of the city and against the registered
owner or the lessee for the amount indicated in the final determination of
parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic law violation, plus costs.
The judgment shall have the same effect and may be enforced in the same manner
as other judgments for the recovery of money. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.422. Suspension Of Driver's License.
The city is authorized to request the suspension of a violator's driver's
license upon ten (10) or more unpaid parking, standing or compliance violations
or upon five (5) or more unpaid automated traffic law violations pursuant to
the Illinois vehicle code, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5, upon
notice and opportunity for an administrative hearing. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-
2010)
Sec. 18.423. Notice Of Impending Driver's License Suspension.
This notice shall be sent to the person liable for failure to complete a
required traffic education program or to pay any fine or penalty that remains
due and owing, or both, on ten (10) or more parking, standing or compliance
violations or five (5) or more unpaid automated traffic law violations. The
notice shall state that failure to complete a required traffic education
program or to pay the fine or penalty owing, or both, within forty five (45)
days of the notice's date will result in the city notifying the secretary of
state that the person is eligible for initiation of suspension proceedings
under section 6-306.5 of the Illinois vehicle code. The notice shall also state
that the person may obtain a photostatic copy of an original ticket imposing a
fine or penalty by sending a self-addressed, stamped envelope to the
municipality along with a request for the photostatic copy. The notice of
impending driver's license suspension shall be sent by first class United
States mail, postage prepaid, to the address recorded with the secretary of
state or, if any notice to that address is returned as undeliverable, to the
last known address recorded in a United States post office approved database.
(Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.424. Certified Report Requesting Suspension Of Driver's License.
If a violator has failed to pay any fine or penalty that remains due and owing,
or both, on ten (10) or more parking, standing or compliance violations or five
(5) or more unpaid automated traffic law violations upon forty five (45) days'
notice, the city shall deliver to the secretary of state a certified report
requesting the suspension of a violator's driver's license. The report shall
contain the following:
   A.   The name, last known address as recorded with the secretary of state,
as provided by the lessor of the cited vehicle at the time of lease, or as
recorded in a United States post office approved database if any notice sent
under section 11-208.3 of the Illinois vehicle code is returned as
undeliverable, and driver's license number of the person who failed to pay the
fine or penalty and the registration number of any vehicle known to be
registered to such person in this state; and
   B.   The name and address of the city; and
   C.   A statement that the city sent a notice of impending driver's license
suspension, to the person named in the report at the address recorded with the
secretary of state or at the last address known to the lessor of the cited
vehicle at the time of lease or, if any notice sent under this article is
returned as undeliverable, at the last known address recorded in a United
States post office approved database; the date on which such notice was sent;
and the address to which such notice was sent; and
   D.   A statement that the city has sent a copy of the certified report to
the violator; and
   E.   A statement that the city provides by ordinance a procedure for the
violator to challenge the accuracy of the certified report. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-
4-2010)
Sec. 18.425. Certified Report; Hearing.
Upon the timely request of a registered owner within ten (10) days of his or
her receipt of the certified report requesting a driver's license suspension,
the city shall provide the registered owner a hearing on his or her challenge
to the accuracy of the certified report. The grounds for such a challenge,
shall be limited to: a) the person not having been the owner or lessee of the
vehicle or vehicles receiving ten (10) or more standing, parking, or compliance
violation notices or five (5) or more automated traffic law violations on the
date or dates such notices were issued; and b) the person having already paid
the fine or penalty for the ten (10) or more standing, parking, or compliance
violations or five (5) or more automated traffic law violations indicated on
the certified report. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.426. Certified Report; Error.
The city shall notify the secretary of state, in a form prescribed by the
secretary, whenever a person named in the certified report has paid the
previously reported fine or penalty or whenever the municipality determines
that the original report was in error. A certified copy of such notification
shall also be given upon request and at no additional charge to the person
named therein. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
Sec. 18.427. Vehicle Immobilization.
The city is authorized to immobilize any eligible vehicle upon the public way
by presence of a restraint in a manner to prevent operation of the vehicle to
enforce the provisions of this article.
   A.   A vehicle shall be eligible for immobilization when the registered
owner of the vehicle has accumulated any combination of three (3) or more
incomplete traffic education programs or unpaid final determinations of
parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic law violations.
   B.   At least twenty one (21) days prior to immobilization, the city shall
send to the registered owner of an eligible vehicle a notice of impending
vehicle immobilization and shall provide the registered owner a right to a
hearing to challenge the validity of the notice by disproving liability for the
incomplete traffic education programs or unpaid final determinations of
parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic law violation liability, or
both, listed on the notice.
   C.   The registered owner shall have the right to a prompt hearing after a
vehicle has been immobilized or subsequently towed without the completion of
the required traffic education program or payment of the outstanding fines and
penalties on parking, standing, compliance, or automated traffic law
violations, or both, for which final determinations have been issued. An order
issued after the hearing is a final administrative decision within the meaning
of section 3-101 of the code of civil procedure.
   D.   The city shall send a postimmobilization and posttowing notice advising
the registered owner of the vehicle of the right to a hearing to challenge the
validity of the impoundment. (Ord. O-10-021, 11-4-2010)
CHAPTER 19
SPECIAL EVENTS
ARTICLE I
SPECIAL EVENT REGULATIONS
SECTION:
19.101. Title
19.102. Purpose
19.103. Policy
19.104. Intent
19.105. Definitions
19.106. Permit Required
19.107. Procedures For Application And Approval
19.108. Fee Schedule
19.109. Issuance Or Denial Of Permit
19.110. Revocation Of Permit
19.111. Records Kept
19.112. Revisions To Applications For Permit
19.113. Penalty
Sec. 19.101. Title.
This article shall be known, cited, and referred to as the CITY OF WOOD DALE
SPECIAL EVENTS CODE. (Ord. O-16-039, 12-15-2016)
Sec. 19.102. Purpose.
It is the purpose of this article to provide for the issuance of special event
permits to regulate events on the public streets and public property of the
city in the interest of public health, safety and welfare; and to provide for
fees, charges and procedures required to administer the permit process.
In addition, this article provides a process for residents to apply to host
block parties and private parties that may need a temporary relief from the
noise control ordinances. (Ord. O-16-039, 12-15-2016)
Sec. 19.103. Policy.
It is the policy of the city, as implemented through this article and any
procedures adopted hereunder, to recognize the substantial community benefits
that result from special events. These events provide cultural enrichment,
promote economic vitality, and enhance community identity and pride. They also
may provide opportunities for family activities and funding for our community's
nonprofit agencies. Partnerships between the city, event sponsors and the
community are valuable in ensuring successful events. Therefore, the city will
strive to accommodate special events when possible.
The city recognizes that events can be difficult to implement successfully and
that the city requirements may represent a portion of an event's costs. When
setting fees and conditions for events, the city will be sensitive to the
impacts on the cost of the event while balancing the city's obligation to
protect public health and safety. It is the goal of the city to have successful
special events that enrich and enliven the community.
The city also recognizes that certain events are site specific; therefore
flexibility is important when determining event locations. (Ord. O-16-039, 12-
15-2016)
Sec. 19.104. Intent.
It is the specific intent of this article and any procedures adopted hereunder
to place the obligation of complying with the requirements of this article upon
the applicant or sponsor, and no provision hereof is intended to impose any
duty upon the city or any of its officers, employees or agents. Nothing
contained in this article or any procedures adopted hereunder is intended to be
or shall be construed to create or form the basis for liability on the part of
the city, or its officers, employees or agents, for any injury or damage
resulting from the failure of the applicant or sponsor to comply with the
provisions hereof. (Ord. O-16-039, 12-15-2016)
Sec. 19.105. Definitions.
The following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall mean:
ANNUAL EVENT: An event recurring each year at approximately the same date which
has previously complied with the permit requirements of this article.
APPLICANT: The authorized agent of the sponsor who completes the application
and acts as primary contact for the special event.
BLOCK PARTY: A party for all the residents of a block or neighborhood,
typically held on a closed off city street.
CLOSED ROUTE: A route along or across a public right of way on which
nonemergency vehicle traffic is not permitted to proceed for the entire
duration of a special event.
EVENT PARTICIPANTS: A person in attendance at an event, including spectators,
vendors, event staff, city staff, and all others present for the purpose of the
event.
FAIR/CARNIVAL: A stationary event, held for one or more days.
NOISE CONTROL PERMIT: A form to be filled out by residents for private parties
or block parties that provides temporary reprieve from noise control
ordinances.
NOISE CONTROL PERMIT: An application that may be used to apply for exemptions
to the noise control ordinance for a specific event.
NOTICE OF INTENT: A notice to stage a special event submitted by an applicant
which informs the city of a proposed event.
PARADE: Any organized group marching or in procession, whether on foot, animal,
or vehicle.
PROCEDURE: A procedure adopted by the city staff, to implement this article, or
to carry out other responsibilities as may be required by this article or by
other codes, ordinances, or resolutions of the city or other agencies.
RACE/RUN: An organized event upon a public street, sidewalk, or trail in which
ten (10) or more persons participate by walking, running, riding a bicycle, or
operating a wheelchair.
ROLLING CLOSURE ROUTE: A street, sidewalk, trail, walkway, or other right of
way closure to accommodate an event, thereafter as the event passes, the right
of way is reopened for use by the general public.
SPECIAL EVENT: A sporting, cultural, business or other type of unique activity,
occurring for a limited or fixed duration (1 time or annual) and presented to a
live audience, that impacts the city of Wood Dale by involving the use of, or
having impact on public streets, sidewalks, walkways, or on other publicly
owned property which interferes with normal vehicular or pedestrian traffic and
requires the use of city services or property (owned, leased or controlled by
the city of Wood Dale). It could also involve an event that occurs on private
property but has a significant impact on public services.
SPONSOR: The person or group responsible for the special event to be held.
TRANSPORTATION MANAGEMENT/PARKING PLAN: A plan developed by the applicant/
sponsor to identify and mitigate traffic/parking impacts, conditions, and
proposed solutions associated with a special event. (Ord. O-16-039, 12-15-2016)
Sec. 19.106. Permit Required.
A special events permit must be obtained from the city in order to be approved
to host a special event. Events include, but are not limited to: races, fairs,
festivals, contests, carnivals, business promotional events, and other events
that may impact city services or property, or an event that occurs on private
property but has a significant impact on public services.
A block party/noise control permit must be obtained by a private party or group
wishing to close roads to host a block party, or by a private party hosting an
event at their residence that involves the use of a stereo, amplifier or live
band. (Ord. O-16-039, 12-15-2016)
Sec. 19.107. Procedures For Application And Approval.
   A.   Sponsors and applicants to host a special event must complete a "city
of Wood Dale special event permit application", which is included as an
appendix to the ordinance codified herein. The application will contain
information that is specific to this code, DuPage County health department, the
international building code as adopted by the city of Wood Dale, and any
applicable state or federal laws.
Completion of this application does not absolve the applicant from complying
with any local, county, state or federal laws or guidelines that are not
specifically outlined in the application. The application is intended to make
the applicant aware of the most common requirements that may be encountered in
hosting a special event and is subject to review and revision as laws or
ordinances are amended.
The following guidelines should be followed for the application:
      1.   A special events permit application must be submitted to the city by
the special event applicant/sponsor, listing location/route, date, and time of
the event. The application must be filed at least thirty (30) days prior to the
date of the proposed event to allow adequate review time, provided this
requirement shall not apply to a special event which is sponsored or
cosponsored by the city. A notice of intent for annual events must be submitted
by January 15 of the year in which the event is to be held and will be
processed within thirty (30) days. First time events will be encouraged to list
several options for location, route, date, and time.
      2.   City staff shall review the notice of intent and determine if the
event can be accommodated. Staff may meet with the applicant/sponsor to
prioritize locations and/or routes. The applicant is required to provide to
staff a complete package of information on the proposed event, including a
tentative site plan and activities involved with the event.
      3.   A notice of pending decision on first time or significantly changed
events must be mailed by the city to affected businesses/residents (to be
determined on a case by case basis by the staff) along with a request for
written comments or concerns.
      4.   City staff shall meet with the applicant/sponsor to discuss comments
received and possible conditions and fees that may apply to the event.
      5.   City staff shall make a decision on the application and set any
conditions and fees, in accordance with this article, and upon payment issue
the permit.
      6.   The applicant/sponsor must provide notification to the affected area
(to be determined on a case by case basis by the city staff) regarding approval
of the event, date(s), time(s), and location/route, to take place fifteen (15)
days prior to event.
   B.   A postevent evaluation may be conducted by the city staff, if
necessary. The evaluation may include a survey of affected residents/businesses
and a meeting with the applicant/sponsor and city staff.
   C.   In deciding whether to approve, approve with conditions, or deny a
permit, city staff shall determine whether:
      1.   The event, as proposed, can be shown to function safely;
      2.   The diversion of police resources to support the event will not deny
reasonable police protection to the city;
      3.   If substantial police, public works or other city staff will be
required to provide public safety for the event, the sponsors will be notified
of these potential costs and invoiced for the final cost to provide these
services;
      4.   The special event will not cause irreconcilable interference with
previously approved and/or scheduled construction, maintenance or other
activities;
      5.   The special event sponsor/applicant has provided an approved
transportation management and parking plan for the event;
      6.   The location/route meets the criteria established in the procedures.
(Ord. O-16-039, 12-15-2016)
Sec. 19.108. Fee Schedule.
   A.   Permit fees and charges are based on a flat fee schedule as specified
in the master fee schedule depending on the type of event and duration/
participation level.
   B.   Additional fees for permits may be required if tents, structures,
plumbing or electrical for the event must be inspected and will be charged
according to fees set forth in this Code.
   C.   If City resources are needed to provide notice of road closures,
detours, or other conditions, the applicant will be provided with an estimate
of the costs prior to issuance of the permit. Basic block parties and minor
road closures should not require additional charges.
   D.   An application fee as specified in the master fee schedule is required
when the applicant/sponsor files the application (commercial applications
only). Permit fees assessed by the above schedule are payable fourteen (14)
days prior to the event taking place after approval of the permit.
   E.   If it is determined that additional police or Public Works personnel
will be required to staff the event, the sponsor will provide a down payment of
fifty percent (50%) of the estimated fees fourteen (14) days prior to the
event, with the balance being due within thirty (30) days of receiving a final
invoice from the City.
   F.   If the event sponsor provides written notice to the City that they are
canceling the event at least fourteen (14) days prior to the event, the fee and
additional costs will be refunded minus a processing fee as specified in the
master fee schedule. Events canceled less than fourteen (14) days prior to the
event will not be eligible for a refund. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-19-2018)
Sec. 19.109. Issuance Or Denial Of Permit.
City staff will review the proposed application and distribute to all
potentially affected entities, including the Community Development Department,
Police Department, Public Works, and Wood Dale Fire Protection District. Each
of these entities may require additional information from the applicant/sponsor
and the City will not issue a permit until all entities have approved the
event.
Once the applicant is found to be fully qualified, the permit shall be issued
and shall state the expiration date thereof, which shall not exceed the listed
dates of the event.
If all requirements of this article have not been met by the applicant, City
staff may deny the issuance of a special events permit and shall notify the
applicant in writing. The applicant may request further discussion with City
staff to determine a change in any conditions or logistics that may allow for
the permit to be issued. (Ord. O-16-039, 12-15-2016)
Sec. 19.110. Revocation Of Permit.
Any special events permit issued in accordance with this article may be revoked
by authorized City personnel if the holder of the special events permit is
convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article, or has made
a false material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes
disqualified for the issuance of a special events permit under the terms of
this article.
In the event of such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the
authorized City personnel and copied to the other affected entities, and given
to the holder of the special events permit in person or by certified U.S. mail
addressed to his or her address set forth in the application.
Upon the issuance of such notice, the special events permit shall become null
and void and shall be surrendered to authorized City personnel. (Ord. O-16-039,
12-15-2016)
Sec. 19.111. Records Kept.
City personnel shall cause an accurate record of each application received,
including those special events permits that are approved and denied, along with
all supporting documentation.
The authorized City staff shall cause to be kept in their office an accurate
record of every application received and acted upon, together with all other
information and data pertaining to the application or event. (Ord. O-16-039,
12-15-2016)
Sec. 19.112. Revisions To Applications For Permit.
City staff may periodically make changes to the special events permit
application package and block party/noise control permit form as changes occur
to any local ordinances, Building Codes, or State or Federal laws. (Ord. O-16-
039, 12-15-2016)
Sec. 19.113. Penalty.
Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be
punished by a fine as specified in the master fee schedule. (Ord. O-18-024, 7-
19-2018)
